although i waited for the technical issues to be fixed before continuing to play, it was great at launch (everything was there just technical issues ruined it). i can now 100% say that it is now worth playing and it is amazing.

Does it still have some bugs? Yes, but all the game breaking or annoying ones have been fixed already.
Does it live up to the hype and have all the things the devs promised before launch? No, not really. There are some parts of the game that are clearly lacking, be it story or gameplay.

But that doesn't stop it from being a great game with a lot to offer.

I tried to like this game, came back because of dev's promises that it is fixed. It is not, only in starting district I encountered similar amount of bugs to what I saw when I played (and finished) the game on console after release. Animations are still broken more often than not, physics for cars and ragdolls has also not improved. 

The icing on the cake was that my game has stopped being able to save/load - it just sits on the load/save screen trying to load my list of saves and game restarts do not help. 

Things like this should not be included in a 2 year old game that claims to have just released a "Big Patch" when it is as buggy (or even worse in my case) as on day 1.

Way back in 2012 Cyberpunk 2077 was first announced and details of it trickled in afterwards until it finally appeared 8 years later and we all know what happened then. The hype and anticipation leading up to release, alongside the game itself, all started to fly apart at the seams and come crashing down. It quickly became clear that it wasn't ready for release - it was riddled with bugs and issues that left a sour taste in the mouths of gamers. CD Projekt had taken their eye off the ball and dropped it massively, landing themselves in a hole from which there may have been no redemption.

But they never gave up on the game, nor did a number of fans and now, 2 years later it has redeemed itself and is what it should have been back at launch day. With many bugs squashed, quality of life improvements added and a lot of technical issues resolved (though there are still some lingering issues and it's quite demanding on hardware), you can slip into Night City and enjoy a rich, diverse story while roaming around to make allies and enemies alike. With the announcement of an expansion and a full fledged sequel on the cards, Cyberpunk 2077 is finally getting the recognition it deserves after a labour of love.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an awesome game! The story is involved and well done. The graphics are really nice, sometimes having scenes that look like they're straight out of AAA movie. The characters are likable while being realistic, especially with the immersive conversations you can have with the NPC. 

Still, the game itself does have some issues. Occasionally the game will get stuck trying to do basic things like blocking you from jumping to another level if your too close to the wall. Sometimes it'll start a phone conversation while another NPC is trying to talk to me. These are just some examples of things they could improve on with new patches. 

Overall, I would say that there is room for improvement but the game really is amazing. Cyberpunk 2077 is a very ambitious game and as long as you can get passed the small issues it has then you will love the game. It has absolutely been one of the nicest games I've played and deserves some love for the story and the details they've included into the game alone.

I'm probably going to be repeating the same things you are hearing in the other reviews but here anyway.

This game is incredible, the story is fantastic, the different dialogue options you can choose from, the different ways the story can go based on your decision similar to the games made by Telltale, is all great. The characters are fantastic and their dialogue is top-notch. 

It definitely had a rocky start, but its nowhere near where it was at launch. I would say 99% of the bugs I saw when the game first released are gone. Are there still bugs? Yes. But they aren't impactful to your game whatsoever, usually its just an NPC going through a closed door or something.

I picked this game up while it was 50% off a couple of months ago and here it is 50% off again (at the time of writing), the game goes on sale often and if you have been interested to play it I would definitely pick it up.

I has been quite the ride for Cyberpunk 2077. I was really hyped for this game, but with the launch state worse than the first SpaceX launches, I decided to just put it down and wait for the fixes. 

Mind you, I didn't had any technical issues, just ONE crash while trying various settings and having a taste for the game (BTW, THIS is how you handle in-game settings and loading times, R*) . 

And glad I waited, because now the game is, dare I say, in it's prime. Not only the game itself is quite polished, but with Edgerunners anime, it's having a renaissance in the average gamer's mind. AND there's a big expansion coming with even more updates from CDPR. 

It's a good time to jump in indeed.
STYLAX

The plot is great...
V is a nomad/street kid/corpo who's out to prove himself as a merc. As he climbed up the ladder of the merc reputation, he was offered a high tiered job which is both challenging and one that changed his live. Maybe forever.

This is my second playthrough on Cyberpunk 2077. The first one I played on the PS5. I 100% the game but I felt its better to play this with Ray Tracing + High framerate + Keyboard and mouse. I wasn't wrong.

The graphics is insane if you have at least a RTX 3080 with Ray Tracing turn to full blast. Almost every moment seems like a good time to activate the photo mode. 

I've never played RPG shooter before this, so the gameplay is a little odd to me. The fact that it can take a couple of headshots to kill an npc seems ridiculous in my opinion.

Adding to the weirdness, you can spend a lot of time customizing your character but you'll hardly see your character since its in first person view most of the time. Except when you're riding a bike and change the camera mode to third person. 

Overall, its a replayable game. I feel the main quest is kinda short, so take your time with the side quests while in the middle of the main quest.

[h1] Cyberpunk 2077 - A good game, but with its flaws [/h1]

A game that is very good, but still has its flaws, leaving it far from perfect, let's start with the positives: 

[olist]
[*][h1]Graphics; [/h1]

The game has very good graphics, and has a wide variety of scenarios, really immersing you in a cyberpunk world, passing from the city to the desert, always well detailed, most often played in high quality (and for medium period, will be explained later when I talk about bugs) 

[*][h1]Gameplay: [/h1]
 
A good first-person rpg , plus the non-perfect gameplay, at some point realize that the enemies are not very intelligent, giving the impression that the same enemies, changing only appearances, still has a diversity of weapons and ways to play, it is worth noting that one notices the affection of the developers for the game. 

[*][h1]Sound: [/h1]

Well, that one point partly negative and partly positive, the dubbing of the game is excellent (this in my root language than Portuguese), but on the other hand the weapons are insufficient at some points, you do not feel the sound difference between weapons of the same type, seeming that the best has no difference from the weakest. 

[*][h1]History: [/h1]
 
Well this part and very complicated, because honestly, the story and some points and very weak, what saves her and the character of Keanu Reeves, without Johnny Silverhand the history  of the game would not hold, it is worth pointing out one thing, different from the main story the side quests are wonderful, because that was they managed to make me care about an Artificial Intelligence of cars and  a vending machine,  a story that telling most side quest provided me with almost 60 hours of gameplay. 

Good going through these points that I consider the best, but also  are not perfect, but now we go to the worst part, the BUGs. 

[*][h1]The BUGs:[/h1]
 
Good this is a delicate point, because even after 2 years of release the game still has bugs, but as I did not play at launch I cannot compare, just say my experience. 

So yes I had some bugs and some really messed up the game, in some moments key mission characters got stuck on the ground, but just carried a save that solved, but let's talk about the bug that messed up my first 20 hours of gameplay that simply made it impossible for me to play with the graphics above average,  because when entering the inventory or even the pause menu when returning to the game it was locked at 14 Fps, the only solution was to put in the medium because so it did not happen anymore, it is worth noting that I started playing in version 1.6 is this bug was fixed at 1.61, that way the next 30 hours of play I could play with the graphic at the top and with an average of 55 Fps,  this all in FullHD ultrawide. 

Apart from this bug, the others even did not get in the way so much, more to say that the game is without bugs would be an exaggeration. 



 [h1] Final considerations: [/h1]

Cyberpunk 2077, a game that promised a lot and failed to deliver everything, but that does not make it a bad game, it is rather a good game, however  it is insufficient in some points, it and a good game, more is not perfect, more and able to make you have fun without a doubt. 

A good game, with a story even having its problems and comes captivating, 2 years after launch and a game that I recommend, and buying in a promotion of 50% is very worth it, here in this analysis is my recommendation.

While this game did not deliver all that was promised at launch, I think its safe to say that time has been in its favor. I just bought the pc version here on steam yesterday, and I was amazed. Coming from the PS4 version to this is almost a huge leap. Playing at 60 fps with no glitches, (other than some caused by my tinkering with graphics) I'll say it's a real treat. I've been fully immersed and i'm more excited than i was at launch to experience this game. The world is beautiful even without ray tracing turned on. The characters are interesting with detailed models and the gameplay is solid enough to keep me happy. Typing this now, all I can think about is jumping back into V's shoes. I'm extremely happy with it and can't wait to see what CDProjektRed has in store for us in the future.

Very fun game, I would describe it as a futuristic version of GTA with a much better combat system, much better story, much better graphics, and way more dialogue/world building. This game is extremely dialogue heavy, so be ready for that. I usually like to play games without sound so that I can listen to YouTube/audiobooks as I play, but that isn't suggested for this game since there are such immersive stories. I have a pretty high end PC and the game played very well for me with few bugs, better performance than Elden Ring. Most likely the prettiest game I have ever played, with the best graphics I might have ever seen. Game can be a bit jarring at first because you have to do a lot of tutorials, and the combat system isn't very fun. Once you learn the complex game mechanics and you can upgrade your cyberware, the game gets really really fun and you can mow down huge groups of enemies effortlessly. 

I played the game only because I really liked the Cyberpunk: Edgerunners series that just came out, and I seriously recommend watching that as well. I'd say that the series is better than the game, but the game is extremely interesting/unique in this game as well. Main story of the game can lag a bit at times, but makes up for it later on. Side missions are better than any game I've ever played and almost feel like part of the main story. Gonna have to play Witcher 3 after this at some point too.

This game had a very bad reputation when It first came out, as it was extremely glitchy. 2 years later and Its pretty much perfect. The story is engaging, the game-play is fun, and the characters have decent stories. The romance is pretty shallow,[spoiler] as you do a couple missions and then have a sex scene, which just puts you into a relationship.[/spoiler] Most of the small problems you might have, like maxing your level too fast or enemies dying too quick can be fixed with mods very easily, as they added a modding platform to the game. All-in-all, This game is very good and I definitely recommend it.

One of the worst launches in recent gaming history, severely over-hyped, many missing features and bugs still present. Still, objectively, this is a good game. It did not reach its full potential, but it sure is a -relatively- good start.

I don't think you can get more poetic than a game based in a setting critiquing capitalism that was pushed out too early by a corporation. In spite of the originally buggy release it's clear that CDPR cares about this game, this IP and they are continually adding fixes and actively supporting the modding of this game. Speaking of modding it is refreshing to see devs who are fostering that skill in their community which makes the games better and helps them envision what kinds of things we want to see in future games with this setting. There are times that it can still be quite buggy, but for the most part the game runs fairly stable and especially given how it's on sale as of the time of writing I can absolutely recommend dropping something on it to give it a go. The stories and attention to detail in this game are phenomenal if you pay attention and it's clear that this is a game that has had a lot of passion put into it.

The game looks and feels amazing. The soundtrack is absolutely awesome. I grabbed it on Steam after patch 1.6 hoping all the problems were fixed in the meantime and I was not disappointed. Too bad the game had such a controversial release when they practically rushed it out. If they would've launched it in the state it is today it would've been a whole different story. Meaning I would've paid full price and not wait for a sale. But in the end it's not all about the money from my perspective, it's about the state of the game when it's released to the public. I've learned from Bethesda to never ever ever pre-order anything anymore. Luckily, CD Project Red did get it right after a couple of major patches. The release of this game was a level beyond failure. It was cyberpunk 'with at least' 2077 bugs. As for now that the game is on a "closed-beta" level I will say buy it but not on full price. Gameplay and story is marvelous. The story is in the same universe as the edgerunners but is not the continuity you are searching for, the story is not the same. Has plot twists here and there and character development feels real. Customization has more options than any other game I've played so far, thats a plus. There is a lot more to say about this game, has a lot of content, the loot seems unlimited, the collectibles are all nice, and it exhibits all the aspects of a good open world game.

The negative side is the remaining bugs. And I'm not talking about the things you will experience in the open world, those are hilarious, and are now features. The bugs YOU will hate, are the story based ones, where you cannot proceed because something didn't spawn, for example. But the save system is just like skyrim so you will have multiple points of coming back. 

Overall i value the game at 30EUR, with score 9/10. Liked it a lot.
Besides the occasional bug, this game is fantastic! I loved the map, storyline, and options in this game. Would recommend

Since its release, I had heard a lot of negative and positive surrounding this game. After waiting a while for some fixes to come through, I decided to buy it. It sat in the library for a while as I played other games. Then I watched Cyberpunk: Edgerunners. I NEEDED more Cyberpunk in my life, so I booted up the game and got sucked in immediately. The game is beautiful, and it has a lot to offer. Plenty of story and a plethora of skills and pathways to choose from to play your way. The game really can be played a variety of different ways, and at whatever pace you choose. This, in turn, gives the game replay-ability. Love it!

This game's a pretty good example of a love/hate relationship... People will either dislike it, just for the sake of the poor launch and other things that could've been done better, or will fall in love.

I personally fell in love all the way. I've always been a fan of cyberpunk/future dystopia concept or art, so this game pretty much hit the sweet spot for me.
Yes, there are still some issues, bugs and glitches in the game, several things that could've been done better and properly, the game's also missing some mandatory features as standard such as for instance vehicle customizations or access to different kinds of transport, etc... Simply things that would make this game even more GTA-ish, if this game is supposed to be the rival for GTA.

But what this game is mainly all about and what I love about it, is the atmosphere it produces, the emotions, the story, the characters and their individual stories, the dialogues, the neon world, the music and much more. This game makes you feel things. It dragges you into this world in a beautiful and sinful way. The size and depth of this game is also great, I've played many hours in this game and still feel like I barely explored the half of it. The music and soundtrack in this game is one of the best I've listened to, if not the best - fits the game perfectly and highlights all the emotions and atmosphere.

If you're a fan of this world like me, you're gonna forgive the game all the issues and mistakes and just will have a blast.

Does this game have issues and bugs? Yes. Does it matter? Not really. Cyberpunk 2077 is damn fun to play with whole lot of interesting characters and well built city in all it's aspects. Sometimes you just want to kick back and enjoy all the city has to offer. And once you are done, you are pretty much ready to go for another round. It is not perfect, but it slowly grows on you in a way, that you will crave more even after 50 hours in. And with every update, the game gets better and better.

CD Project Red cares. They still update the game and give a bunch of free DLC's and constantly fixing the game. The game get's better and better with time. As story, visuals, content and overall atmosphere the game is really fun and makes you wanna come back to Night City every day.

After 74 hours of game play, I still haven't finished Act 2 of the game and that says a lot about Night City in general, there are so many side quests and stuff that you can explore. You get immersed and you can easily get distracted when going to a quest and end up doing a bunch of gigs or NCPD scanner quests. After a rushed release, I can easily say that 2 years later, the game is almost perfect (bug wise), haven't had a single crash nor a game breaking bug. The developers are still working on the game actively and the game is getting better and better. 11/10 would romance Judy again.

Game is stable now. Recommended with Limited HUD mod and No More Hardcoded Keybinds mods.

I take my hat of to CD Projekt Red for sticking to their massive game and putting in the work to iron out many of the initial faults and issues that occurred after the game launched. I also congratulate them on the success of Edgerunners, which has many of us (myself included) hoping for future seasons.

PROs: The story-line is engaging, the characters are well written, and as far as issues go, in my entire playtime I've only experienced two crashes and a handful of non-major errors.

CONs: The game is very punishing on hardware.

I would recommend Cyberpunk to anybody who has been sitting on the fence about playing it like I had been.
The game is fire. PLUS. They got a sick ass anime. What more can I say?

It's got some bugs, but those that don't make the game funnier are just negligible. There're a mountain of side quests that will have you moving all around the city with various methods of completion for each. The game gets a bit broken when you have the gorilla arms and the jump legs (can't remember what they're called), but it's all the better for it. Cyberpunk 2077 . . . is a very flawed game. Very enjoyable, but also very very flawed.

The easiest way to do this is a Pros Cons list

Pros:
- Big map
- Lots of activities to do
- Great Combat
- Amazing Customization
- Wonderful characters and writing and voice acting
- Amazing Graphics (if your PC can actually run those great graphics, however I ran at the lowest settings and it still looked awesome)
- A story that's surprisingly emotional
- Great combat

Cons:
- Stealth (if you don't use netrunning that is, which is what is intended, but throwing knives are SUPPOSED to feel like an alternative
- As soon as you finish a character's story, they just kinda become a background NPC . . . no more unique interactions, nothing, unless they're a love interest in which case you'll get texts every once in a while . . .
- Feeling as if you're dying the whole time can get . . . pretty annoying
- Glitches are still present, most are just visual, but there are a few functional ones as well, like occasionally not being able to activate your Operating System like Sandevistan and Berserk, even when the cooldown is already finished
- Your choices don't feel very well, varied. Although V as a character is not very set in stone before you the player come along, it feels like your choices aren't very impactful of the world as a whole, or to who V is as a person. In contrast to The Witcher 3, a game with a protagonist with plenty of established lore, that game allows you a wider array of actual choices
- Sometimes content feels repetitive

Now as a note, a lot of these cons are only something you notice roughly 50+ hours in anyways. So, who knows.

I've seen some people saying that patch 1.05 turned the game around and that it's far closer to what was promised. That's pretty amazing to me as I started on patch 1.06 and it is still an incredibly glitchy mess. In many areas it still feels incredibly rushed. Including the big finale. 

By the end of the game combat would fail to exit when the last enemies were dead half of the time. So it happened a [i]lot[/i]. Gameplay menus such as inventory would all be disabled when it happened, too. Had to load a save to get out of it.

NPCs would sometimes start glitching where every frame would alternate between them t-posing and in the correct position. Producing a rather unpleasant shimmering effect.

Items, most notably [i]proximity mines[/i], sometimes are under solid ground so that you can't see them normally. You can only see them by scanning icons. If you happen to be approaching a minefield, scan early or you might just blow up from a mine that's invisible unlike the rest in the game.

You can walk right into a couple areas that are supposed to be inaccessible at that point. You can't get out of them though, you have to load a save. 

The game is also desperate for a flashlight. Some areas are completely unlit. Shouldn't have to crank the gamma just to navigate a room.

And the big secret ending? Without spoiling, it literally hard cuts from moping to combat. No building tension or anything. Mass Effect 3's ending was done better than this.

Basically, only the prologue missions are worth playing. And if you've seen the game trailers and are familiar with other cyberpunk content, then you've already done half of that.

Worst of all: When you get the cat, you can never interact with it again. Doesn't even move, just spawns in a different spot in the apartment and meows forever from that spot until you leave.

I think the best way to understand the appeal of this game is to look up the sort of youtube content that is made for it.  While there are some very good videos from around launch analyzing what there is in terms of story and themes, the majority of the content is showing off how effective a particular build is at murdering a building full of people.  One to two minute showcases of throwing knives in slow motion, cutting nameless gangsters to bits with katanas or using the hacking mechanics to make entire rooms of people kill themselves.  In all of these videos there is very little context to the murder, and as it turns out that is true of the game itself.

The majority of the content in this game that pretends to be an rpg and is actually just a riff on GTA is markers pointing to a building or an alleyway full of people to kill.  There is some effort put into making this fun, the base gunplay actually feels quite nice and there is enough depth to the character building to allow the player to customize their V to be the kind of murderer they want.  The problem is that the combat becomes trivially easy if you put any amount of effort into buying upgrades for your character.  The game turns into short bursts of identical looking violence, spread across an entire city's worth of map markers.  Perfect for short and stylish videos on youtube but not ideal for what is supposed to be a decently sized game.

There is a story in between all the boring murder this game fills itself with.  At times it can even be decent with some well written and well acted characters.  There are absolutely the ingredients for a smaller and much more focused narrative about a younger mercenary who doesn't want to die and the digital ghost in their head that's killing them.  I have a long list of gripes about how the actual story plays out but that's a much longer review.  What is there didn't end in a satisfying way for me and even if it had, the way the game is structured would have undercut it all the same.

On the subject of bugs, in theory the game is "fixed" now.  In practice there were no shortage of physics glitches and animation errors and other ridiculous issues.  The game crashed on me more then once, but thankfully never softlocked on me.  I'd put the level of glitchiness at around the level of Skyrim, which is still way too glitchy.  This game does not actually deserve the redemption that gamers have given it.

TLDR: Useful as a murder simulator and not much else.  This could have been a visual novel and it would have been way better, cdpr plz unionizer.

Despite all of the negative press around the game at release, this game CURRENTLY is a marvel to play. The world feels real and lived in and the characters have fleshed out personalities that feel real. The combat is smooth and satisfying for the most part and the RPG elements are implemented quite well with satisfying abilities and skills. I'd say Cyberpunk is not only playable, but an amazing experience

Honestly, it's hard to re-play something you had initially no hope for, which hurt all the more considering I had pre-ordered the game and had though (like practically everyone else) that this game was going to be the be-all-end-all of games. After playing those initial 20 hours in 2020, getting a quarter of the way finished, I chose to uninstall the game and be content that I had wasted 60 dollars on yet another mediocre game. After seeing all of the negative reviews, all of the videos, I felt that I had nothing more to gain. After all, why care for something that was never good and would be never good.  

That's how it was until I heard an anime came out with the same name. I don't watch anime and have no positive or negative opinion on the show, but I thought that it was decent enough to warrant my attention to be put back on the game. There's something Cyberpunk as a genre that not a lot of other media has for me, and I see a lot of that charm now more as I've been introduced to a lot more of the genre as the years go on. Judge Dredd, Philip K. Dick, Altered Carbon, etc, I've read all of them and see a lot of that in Cyberpunk 2077. Clearly the game isn't a novel, but it does have some of the passion from those writers put into the game's story and setting. 

I don't think this game warrants game of the years, as it clearly isn't the type of game that sticks with you past maybe a couple of weeks after finishing, nor does it have the replayability of New Vegas, but it still is maybe worth getting in 3 to 4 years when it's on sale and you want a game to play while off work. It's not great, but it's not terrible either.

You do wonder whether the producers of this game are all frustrated film makers and, dazzled by the involvement of Mr. Reeves, have just made a film that you, the player, only happen to be a part of.

All games with a large scope need a strong story to hang the game play on (the Witcher series and Mass Effect being two personal favourites). However, Cyberpunk 2077 has gone too far the other way and is all about the story and less about the game play. Yes there are the glitches that afflict other games involving large volumes of NPC traffic and yes there are lots of side missions but if you want to progress the main story line, expect to be sat watching a LOT of dialogue.
Good story better game play. Since its still getting updates, but I recommend waiting to see if the DLC is good but if it goes on sale its definitely a must buy, as long as your PC can run it.

[h1]TL;DR: Worth the money, on sale or off sale.[/h1]
If you were staying away from the game because it has a bad reputation, it has improved exponentially with each new patch and is only getting better.

First, I just want to start by stating that I'm [b]not[/b] from the Edgerunners crowd, I tried to play patch 1.3... but ended up playing patch 1.5 when it released.
Secondly, I have a little over 50 hours of playtime in the game as of writing this, if that helps validate my opinions.
I got the game cracked and played it for about 12 hours before deciding to buy the game legit (which I do not, and will not regret).
Since I started playing the game after multiple patches were released, [b]I experienced very few bugs in my 50 hours of play time... 3 to be exact[/b].
(my hardware was probably to blame for one of them)
The vehicles are still a bit buggy, the driving needs work in general but other than that it is extremely playable.
I was a bit apprehensive of updating to 1.6 (I played my cracked version of 1.52 for 18 more hours after I bought it on Steam, even going as far as beating the game once) but after finally deciding to move my save file over to Steam I realized there was almost no difference... except maybe a 5-8fps loss, which was disappointing but tolerable.
The story is pretty decent, the graphics are incredible when maxed out, FSR 2.1 is great for lower end systems, and the detail put into environments is impressive to say the least. IMO the gameplay is relatively hard to master and definitely requires a decent amount of quick thinking on your part. This game isn't something you can play mindlessly, roach race (the playable in-game arcade game) is though... which is a really cool feature. Photo mode is also something cool to mess around with occasionally, especially if you love virtual photography, and there are multiple play styles which are all unique and equally fun.
Over all this is the best game I've played in a while, and it's certainly worth the month it took me to get the money to purchase the game.

Despite everything i have been trying to do to get the RedLauncher to function, there is literally nothing I can do to fix the issue regarding its missing Qt files. I have updated my drivers, my OS, made sure i had the C++ x86 installed. I set any settings to default that I could. I meet the minimum requirements for the game as well and it runs fine if i skip the launcher. its the Launcher itself that wont run, and there is nothing I can do to fix the issue, and it would seem to be the case for anyone else who has this issue as well. Hell, ive even tried running them from the folder themselves, the launcher gives the same issue and the setup doesn't do squat. Clearly there is something that fucked up along the way and at a download speed of 4mb/s I really don't want to wait an entire day to reinstall the ENTIRE game to have a /chance/ of it possibly working.

Dont get me wrong, it runs if I SKIP the launcher, but I don't gain access to all of what the game has for content.

TLDR: Despite everything the company has done for the game to try to fix it, the game is fine. The prelauncher however is what breaks everything, and if it wont work for you, the best option you got is to tell the launcher to F-off by using "--launcher-skip" without quotations in the general properties of the game in the launch options button.

I would 100% blame that on the fact that this game had the burden of straddling multi gen console releases on top of being one of those 'RTX' flagship games. That is so many systems, so many different configurations, and spread the development way too thin. 

On release I actually never had any problems, I have a fairly uniquely configured Aorus laptop I got several years ago with great cooling and the following for reference:

Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8750H CPU @ 2.20GHz   2.20 GHz
RTX 2070 (Desktop GPU, not a limited laptop one)
1920x1080
SSD

Do I have everything on high? No, but I do have most on high settings. I do not have RTX Ray tracing on, I turned low particular settings that did not make much of a difference / do not occupy much of the field of view but have huge performance costs. And some of the post processing effects (some vignette effects stuff like that)

However, since release I have played through it again with DLSS enabled, and that is a great piece of technology. Greatly increases performance and the background 'blur' actually simulates depth of field.

A desktop with a better CPU and the same level of graphics card I imagine will run this game without a problem. I honestly think this game is not worth getting for console, even next gen.

[h1]Non-Numerical Review[/h1]

Like many others, I was convinced to pick up this game after watching [i]Cyberpunk Edgerunners[/i]. I do not regret purchasing the game, however, it still has some outstanding issues.

The city does feel alive visually, and some parts of the game are story rich, but there are very few minor NPC interactions, which makes the world feel less alive. You're always heading towards some sort of objective, and while most video games do work like that, lacking such small distractions is a disappointment. Along with this, it's been over a year since release and there's still glaring performance issues. For reference I have an RTX 2080 Super, which isn't that good, but even on low settings I got semi-frequent stuttering, which caused the audio to also crackle and increase my headaches even further.

I do enjoy seeing the progress they've made since launch, as it does seem to be doing much better than before, but with issues like these still in the game I really wouldn't recommend purchasing unless on sale. If you need a Cyberpunk aesthetic fix: watch the anime, or hell watch something like Cowboy Bebop.

[h1]Numerical Review[/h1]

[b]Graphics: 5/5[/b]
Night City looks beautiful and dark, makes me feel like I'm in a rebel ghetto from Star Wars.

[b]Story: 4/5[/b]
The main story is great from what I have played, and the side-gigs have fun little one-offs. 

[b]Gameplay: 4/5[/b]
Not the most revolutionary thing, but body modification is always interesting. The whip arms (I forget the name) are amazing.

[b]Performance: 2.5/5[/b]
Still has performance issues even on low settings, which many others also have experienced.

[b]Overall: 3.5/5[/b]
Great game, but still needs fixing up in a good few places.

[h1]【Worth It?: 9/10】[/h1](NO SPOILER) 
This game focus on world-building and stories. The gameplay is nothing revolutionary or groundbreaking, but it's fine for the game. The support of mods also gave it extra spice and customization.

[h1]【Replay-ability: 6/10】[/h1]
The lifepaths you choose make no difference to the world and story. However, the choices you make can lock away interactions, so it can be argued that a second run can be done to make sure nothing gets locked, and you can aim for a different build for another playstyle.

[h1]【Story: 9/10】[/h1]
The stories and world-building are very detailed. Developers considered every part of the world and showed complexity and interactions between humans and machines. The quests have split paths that are hinted at to players through interactions. They are often obvious, but few are subtle. Decisions can change a quest, unlock secret endings, or even lock up interactions. I made a few mistakes and ended up being super paranoid and was doing research on every potential split to make sure I got the best results.

[h1]【Gameplay: 7/10】[/h1]
The gameplay is nothing revolutionary. The driving is a little slippery, Enemies are so blind when I stealth. I move faster than NPC in quests. Some of these can be fixed with mods. However, there are still pros to it. You can play with different skill trees aim to make a specific part of combat extremely powerful. You will quickly end up OP if you follow a specific path when you level up. The unique weapon class like smart and tech weapons are interesting. Not to mention the cyberware that let you quick-hack or even slow time. It's very interesting.

[h1]【Visual/Style: 10/10】[/h1]
There are so many details put into the game to convince me that it can be the future. Day-to-day items are reimagined to give off a high-tech vibe. The city design is also filled with unique buildings. I can just cruise around the game and take screenshots to use as later references for my drawing. It's very inspiring.

Everyone is familiar with how ridiculously overhyped Cyberpunk 2077 was. The expectation were so high that no game could realistically meet them ever - Cyberpunk was supposed to be THE definitive RPG, open-world game, shooter, adventure, experience, etc.

Of course the expectations were not fulfilled. Exacerbating the issue were multiple technical problems, bugs and general lack of polish. Regarding those I am happy to report that at the time of this review's publishing the game mostly works fine. There's still some roughness around the edges, but barely any of the hilarity we witnessed on release remains.

So what about what this game is and what should you expect? This is a story focused open world first person RPG. The world is indeed open and freedom of traversal is absolutely there, but surprisingly enough I don't think this was a focus of Cyberpunk 2077. By far the strongest elements of the game are story, characters, quests and general atmosphere. In all honesty the учзукшутсштп character interaction, which is a huge part of the story anyway, is what makes this game. Voice acting, animations, dialogue and direction overall are very impressive. It is the process of getting to know the characters, forming relationships with them, growing to love or despise them and going through change together, that defines what it is like to play through Cyberpunk. The game will not show you its best if you approach it as an open world sandbox of sorts. Even the police chases are likely to disappoint you.

All this doesn't mean that the base gameplay loop is poor or lacking. I would characterize it as solid, easily above average yet not breathtaking. Exploration, leveling, side activitiesб inventory management and crafting all feel decidedly run-of-the-mill. One notable exception is combat. While not inspired in terms of how dynamic or visceral it feels, it gets elevated by the breadth of possible approaches. Those include stealth, both as avoidance and stealth kills, several schools of melee combat, close, medium or long range firefights with their respective weapon types and skill trees, and quickhacks which are essentially combat magic.

On the technical side this game is a resource hog. There is an optimized settings guide by Digital Foundry, but at any rate you will require at least a mid-range rig to enjoy the beauty Cyberpunk has on offer. But boy, does it offer! Character designs are excellent, the world is vibrant and at the same time appropriately dreary and feels lived in. All the modern tech is being put to good use of course. My only gripe would be repeating NPCs - they do not seem to be procedurally generated on the fly, but rather are summoned from an extensive library of pre-existing designs. It results in seeing same faces and same outfits here and there. Is this immersion breaking? I would say no, but the more demanding among us might disagree.


As for the sound, it is just plain decent. Not stellar but not subpar either. The score stands tall though - Cyberpunk has a lot(really a lot!) of great music and even boasts a number touching leitmotifs reserved for the story beats.

Longevity wise I would expect a single playthrough to clock in anywhere between 60 and 120 hours and there is definitely some replayability easily warranting a second playthrough.

Overall on the whole Cyberpunk 2077 is a very memorable and emotional journey. There aren't that many like this one. I am easily putting it right next to Undertale in my personal masterpiece rating, and it is not a crowded bunch.

Do I recommend it? Yes, absolutely. Even those with only a passing interest in this project should consider getting it on a discount as every penny spent is well worth it in my opinion.

Played it for the first time about...2 months ago now I guess?   Using a chunky potato of a PC, and even still, it runs pretty good.  Yes it's got some janky bits, and some performance issues, but I honestly can't say that isn't because my PC is below specs.  BUT, I think it says a lot, that even on a PC that is below specs, with only a minor amount of graphics reduction, I run just fine about 95% of the time.  All those insane bugs the game was infamous for, I really rarely see any of them.  Seriously the game is WAY more stable than it was at launch.  So if your issue was the performance, which is the reason I delayed playing it for well over a year, I think you can safely play it without any real issues.

Now, that disclaimer out of the way.  This game is really fun.  I love the amount of actual depth and story the plug into even the most minor of side jobs and gigs.  I'll be doing side quests and forget that this isn't the main storyline, but I forget because the writing and acting is so good, that it feels like I'm doing someone else's main story.  And then be like "oh..right, this is just V going to the store for milk"    The amount of effort and love the team put into this game, really does show.  From the various influences from the genre, that shine through in easter eggs and namedropping, to just the overall tone of the missions and events.  I've always been a huge fan of the cyberpunk genre, and so I was really looking forward to this game.  I'm actually not a huge CDPR fan, and frankly found the Witcher games to be very boring.   So I wasn't actually optimistic about this game when it launched.  But this is a very solid game, for anyone who is a fan of the genre.   I highly recommend it.

Written 11/19/2022 with 42 hours in the game. 
The Story: I pretty quickly reached the point of no return for the main story around 20 hours ago and forced myself to back up and play a bunch of the side shit. Do this, it's worth it. The main story is far too short and gives you a sense of urgency that makes doing anything else impossible. In order to experience the full game, you have to break your immersion and pretend your character isn't *****. This sucks, but it's possible to get around it.

The Bugs: I've had to restart the game a few times when it got really fucked up. I feel like the small bugs build onto each other until you really can't handle it anymore and have to just save and restart. It's playable, sure, but you can absolutely get soft locked into certain situations and that sucks.

The Mechanics: Shooting is pretty good. Driving anything but the best cars is a shit storm unless you're going slow. Tech hacks are decently fun. The coolest part of this game is the way it makes you feel powerful as you gain more powerful cyberware, guns, cars, etc. It's a gritty world that I could see myself living in.

My Hardware: I'm running a Ryzen 5 3600x, GTX 1660, 16gb of good RAM, and NVME SSD. My monitor is only 1080p, 75hz, so I'm used to things not being *fancy*. The frames are doable on the recommended settings about 90% of the time. When it starts really slowing down, I'm usually in a super busy part of the map or have been playing for a few hours and need to restart anyways. 

Conclusion: The game is fun. It's buggy, but the bugs are manageable 99% of the time. A restart has solved every major problem I've had. The story is too short and I doubt I'll be purchasing the DLC until it goes on sale. But if you can get the game for half-off like I did, I think you should play it.

Update after finally finishing the story. It sucked. It made me feel bad for doing what I felt was the most selfless thing. I don't know, maybe that's just life. Play the game. Get your ending. Your choices matter, even though the game clearly wasn't even close to ready. It's still not. It's not a finished product and it never will be. I'm sad about it though, which shows impact.

I love this game.

First heard about it probably in 2019, as it was advertised in the Steam Store, anticipating it to come out in Spring of 2020. I thought it looked interesting, I've definitely been a fan of SF, but then wondered if it would be good, haha, tired of games trying to appeal to me with a theme. I saw some videos where people were talking about all the features in the game, sounded exaggerated I wasn't thinking you could do everything in the game, how is that possible in any game? Also, the wall-running made me dizzy in Titanfall 2 so I remember that part, I thought it could be interesting but I found it overrated in Titanfall 2 (turns out it was cut from Cyberpunk 2077 as many games cut content) I shrugged and added it to my wishlist. 

So some delays, we found out why. And I was working security at a mall in a fancier neighborhood during the cold a$$ winter, getting very bored and lonely during the pandemic. So I got Cuphead for the Switch. That was some fun. Then I decided it might be worthwhile to check out Cyberpunk 2077, which was getting some buzz. I didn't know how, but I wanted to play it. I knew no way or would play any good on my PC. I got it on Stadia full price around Christmas 2020.

This game is so good. As someone who didn't follow it after its announcement in 2012, but instead around 2019, with skeptical interest, and played it at full power with bad Internet on Stadia (and some connection luck during the holidays), I thoroughly enjoyed the game. V's voice (the actress is in character, hence the rough quality to the voice), Jackie Welles, Goro Takemura, Panam Palmer... Even Johnny Silverhand during his a$$hole stages in much of the main storyline and to a lesser extent some of the side quests, I just love their voices and characters (Keanu as Johnny grows on you, he's an a$$hole for sure)

Advice for first playthrough, finish the side quests or gigs first, as much as possible and delay the main story as much as you can. There's nothing you have to do. Lots of interesting B-stories, take your time. I say this because I felt the suspense and wanted to get to the main story. I won't say it's a let down, but it's not what you expect, there's mystery and room for you to figure things out.

In the end the game made me realize that Judge Dredd, Akira, Blade Runner, Philip K. Dick stories, all this stuff I like is in the Cyberpunk genre. And the game with its gorgeous graphics represents it very well in the Blade Runner / 5th Element Style while being original (at least in my opinion, or original in a Shakespeare sense lol, a reworking of existing ideas)... Once you investigate Michael Pondsmith if you haven't before you see the genius he inspired in the tabletop Cyberpunk game and what a good adaptation Cyberpunk 2077 is of that. Probably many people know, but I didn't know, a lot of the videogame comes from the table top game. 

Then the playing style fits for me. I like shooters and cinematic style games if balanced well with gameplay. And humor, GTA games, Assassin's Creed Odyssey, Origins, Valhalla, Black Flag and Far Cry games. I like RPGs too. Less patience for those. I think it's fair to call Cyberpunk 2077 an Action-RPG. Not a demanding game but a fun cinematic experience, kind of like a favorite SF series with some good action and environment from the characters. Perhaps a bit of The Sims.

I don't know, it's not a perfect game. Driving is wonky, still a few glitches on Steam Deck, I'm loving it on Steam Deck almost like a new game, ever since the FSR 2.1 update. On Stadia it was awesome too but that's shutting down. There were some bugs on Stadia but it was generally smooth. Some floating phones and Sliverhand cigarettes 🚬 at first, but patches fixed a lot of that! I will pre-order Phantom Liberty for sure.

Yeah and of course Edgerunners was awesome. Surprised I wasn't alone in loving that! I'm at 62 hours as of writing this with 138 hours on stadia, clocking in at 200 play hours total and I still love this game. Haven't got all the achievements or full completion but pretty far with my first female Nomad character (Nomad is my favorite). Then have a female Streetkid. And a male Corpo, not that lifepaths matter but I find Nomad has a slightly longer and more interesting beginning... So, yeah, lol. From where I'm coming from, a great game.

My PC is well above the RECOMMENDED system requirements, and yet I still struggle to maintain consistent FPS, heaps of stutters often dropping below 30fps. 

Again, the underlying game is GOOD, and I don't think the bugs are really a problem anymore. But I just can not recommend this game unless you have a serious high-spec top of the line PC. If you don't, you WILL NOT enjoy this game, and you should wait until the performance is patched more.

Could say a lot about this game but i'll be very brief :

- Night City is alive. Don't dive in free roam mindset. Follow the stories and quests. This is not a GTA. CDPR strength lies in their storytelling through goal oriented gameplay. 
- Beautiful + superb atmosphere. Stop somewhere. Anywhere. Look around. Everything is unique, detailed. It oozes with quality, you can feel the pure love, effort and work which went into this game once you play it. Then again, free exploration feels pointless if you don't follow the quests and tasks.
- Play with mods.

Obviously has flaws which you can read everywhere or experience first hand. They don't need long to be evident. You can sort of feel the development was maybe spread thin across getting story telling, rpg elements and gta like format. Most of the flaws seem to come from this wish to do everything to please everyone. 

But one thing they nailed for sure : I miss Night City and want more of it.
I recommend.

Good game. Clearly has a lot of effort poured into the characters and script writing. Performances are top tier. Atmosphere is some of the best world building out there. I love all the different ways you can take the story. Playing what I felt was the same way twice yielded surprisingly different results in story missions. High replay value. Being able to see all the areas (and some characters) from the Edgerunners anime is a treat.

Gameplay overall is repetitive, but fun. I would argue it's hard to have an open world game NOT be repetitive these days so It's not really a knock as far as I am concerned.

Stealth leaves something to be desired. I've played a lot of Deus Ex, and it has that vibe down. I went in thinking I could play the same way, like a stealthy hacker. This is not the case. While there are plenty of stealth gameplay elements and skills, it doesn't scratch the stealth itch for me.

Outstanding run and gun gameplay, if you love borderlands in any capacity you are going to have a blast shooting people.

Driving controls are pretty awful, but you get used to it. Do yourself a favor and use the 3rd person view (Q).

The upgrade and crafting system is robust. I found it very confusing at first. I played about 30 percent of the game first playthrough without any cyberware. There is a LOT of junk to carry, I don't even look at what I'm looting 90% of the time since I'm just going to scrap it for parts or eddies.

Min-Maxing armor as it comes to you will have you looking like a hobo, thank god they have a wardrobe feature that acts as a skin to this. MASSIVE options for character customization.

Elephant in the room: Is this game glitchy? Yes. Is it any better than GTA or Skyrim in that regard? No. 
It's gotten better with patches thats for sure.

It can play on a moderate to entry level gaming PC without issue. That being said, the sky is the limit for visuals in this game, even a 4090 can't take advantage of your high end refresh rate monitor at max settings. It is easy to find the settings to play at an acceptable framerate (30-60) and still enjoy the way it looks. So in that regard, if you love to tinker and benchmark, this game is a must.

It's an overall enjoyable experience. I picked it up 50% off though, and would recommend everyone else do the same as I cannot recommend you spend the full £40+ on it. The quests and writing are mostly strong with a few standouts (I especially enjoyed Joshua Stephenson and Johnny's) which tackle complex and interesting subjects, the graphics are gorgeous even on relatively modest rigs, and the music goes hard. Other users have pointed out shortcomings though. 

It's undeniably still a buggy mess, not well optimised, and a lot of the main side characters feel shallow. Judy and Panam's quests and personalities feel much more developed than Rivers' for example. It also suffers from "open world syndrome" where you're running around following objectives in a city that has a terrible uncanny valley feeling, where it's not quite alive and immersive enough that it becomes off putting. A less major gripe is that a lot of systems, like crafting, feel fiddly and superficial. What's the point really when the best gear is the iconic stuff anyway? And why bother with any sort of puzzle if the game's just going to hold your hand the whole time?

Overall though, the gameplay experience is polished, clean, and mostly makes up for its major shortcomings. The gunplay is tight, character progression feels meaningful, and there'a a good diversity of play styles catered for. I played a stealthy netrunner ninja type, but I certainly didn't feel like I was missing out by not taking a different route. I wouldn't come into the game expecting a revolutionary RPG experience, but it has strong enough fundamentals to make it worth your while.

Legit one of my favorite games ever. 10/10 and I mean that unironically.
Since the day it launched. Even through all the bugs, strange design choices, lag, terrible optimization, etc.
CDPR created one of the most interesting and engaging stories ever, and built an incredible and diverse world to house it. I've never been quite as captivated with an 'RPG' story driven type game as I was with this one. 
I was lost in Night City the moment I loaded up for the first time. 
Nowadays, most of the hiccups have been ironed out by either CDPR's updates, or the modding community. It runs smoothly, looks beautiful, and is a blast to play. It's sort of quirky, the gunplay is strange compared to most modern shooters, but even with the quirks and rough patches, I can't put it down. Really looking forward to seeing what the future holds for the world of CP2077.

upgrading items and collecting loot, hacking all sorts of terminals and caches to earn eddies, buying vehicles, customizing your character with lot's of options and creating outfits. Crafting items, changing weapons sights, interactions with random people, side missions that you get from people you met on the main missions. 
Also, having the camera edit is amazing, you can literally pose your character in many different places and make sick photos, so many poses, options, creativity can be off the roof with this feature.

And one important thing which makes this game kickin' arse, the combat. The combat in this gaming is fantastic, the satisfaction when you shoot, the sound of the guns, the impact when you hit, the slow motion
the entire mechanics on it are amazing. I could say that the hand to hand combat is not that great but its still okay.



the downsides are not that big at all :
you can sometimes find yourself watching people glitching inside eachother, glitching character animations, sometimes interactions don't work. event triggers sometimes do not work and you can't continue. 
crashes sometimes, low fps drops (barely noticeable)

I think this game needs another two or three years of bug fixing. Purchase this in 2024.

Game play wise, its your standard Deus Ex style game that gives you many options to complete each mission. You can sneak in through vents, or go in guns blazing. Or you can kill everyone with hacks without even entering the building. Its up to you.

The place where this game really shines is its storyline and all of the side story archs that are in the game. And there are a lot of them.

I recommend not touching the main story until you have finished all the side jobs. As some of them have story lines that are better/rival that of the main story arch (Dream On, or The Hunt for example).

By the time I went through the game, and finished everything, it felt like I had just watched the series finale of my favourite show. I just felt sad and depressed that there was no more.

Luckily, there's an expansion coming next year.

It took about 14 hours before the game really clicked with me. The initial story segments are nice, but then my first real meeting with the open world was painful. The game is not very good about communicating where you should and shouldn't go. Most of the quests are considered "low/average/high/very high danger" instead of recommended level. You might follow "average danger" quest and end-up in open world area full of enemies with skulls above their heads, which will kill you in one shot. Once I figured out where I could actually go to it was much more manageable.

This game allows you to build your character mostly as you want, and whatever path you choose you'll probably end up overpowered. Want to go with bladed weapons? At one point you suddenly become a ninja that bathes in blood of their enemies, healing while killing, becoming invisible, and 90% of time spending in slow motion. Want to hack? Suddenly you sit at your desk and put the whole army to death with hacks. Want to stealth? Before you know if you clean up whole mall of enemies without being seen under 30 seconds. Batman can hide. What about explosives? Well, hope you find the bodies to loot afterwards. Crafting? You become a god of infinite money-making, with all the best hardware in the world. Oh, and there are guns too. I didn't try them out, but I'll bet you can do crazy things once you spec into them.

You can reset some of your build, but the main attributes of your character are set in stone. So if you'll go all-in into Intelligence and Cool(stealth) there's no re-speccing into a gunner or melee. But there's no problem switching from one Reflex weapon to another. Almost all weapons are in Reflex section, by the way. I feel like some Attributes do much more than others, but also, there's probably no way to make unplayable character.

The story... was a mixed bag for me. Good chunk of it is about your relation with another character, Johnny. But most of the time you build that relation you're in the open world doing stuff in your own order. The result, for me, was incoherent. At one time me and Johnny were best friends, because the quest assumed we would be, and next scene we're trying to kill each other. Most jarring was the very beginning, Johnny just tried to kill me for the first time, and within 60 seconds of it we were talking like old pals.

I generally liked the main campaign, although I feel the endings were not gradual enough. You basically choose one of 3 packages, and you take everything that comes with that package. (This is not a true ending, but an example). If you decide to side with the police you get them to help you in the final confrontation, but also need to join the police afterwards, and live happily in the 13 precinct till the end of your days. You cannot ask the police to help, but decide to live the rest of your days as a nomad. I also found no ending fitting for the V I was roleplaying. I was roleplaying a punk, as you know, this is cyberpunk, who disliked Johnny. There is no option for such person. I took second best thing, and it really didn't feel like my V.

That said, the V is pretty cool. S(he) is less defined than commander Shepard, but mostly an existing character. There is, for example, a moment where you can talk about your past love life, and V has some stories to tell. It's not a representation of you, it's a V, which you can influence a bit. That said, there are not that many places you can influence. Sometimes I had to get into a trap on purpose just to trigger a sidequest, or do things I don't think V would do, just to get to a quest.

The sidestories in this game are pretty good, but they are all isolated affairs. For example you might win a boxing tournament, and it will have your friend Viktor in it. But if you ever meet Viktor he will not comment on you being a boxing champion. There were quite a few places where my actions from other quests should/could influence what was happening, but there was no option to leverage it. 

The game also has very little mechanics that make the gamer feel like the game acknowledges the player. You gather reputation, and at some point you might even max it out. But start working with a fixer, and he will treat you as a newbie who only just came to a city, and no one heard about you. In other games NPCs on the streets might comment on you, or you might hear in the radio about your exploits. Not here. For the most part. There are chat messages you can get from NPCs after quests, where they'll present some kind of epilogue to their story. Or send you some photos. On very rare occasions your love interests might talk about different quests you went trough, but for me it only happened once. Usually they were just static part of the background once their quest-line was over. 

The one thing everyone complains about is the police AI. I didn't play this like GTA, but man, the police is irritating. Policemen act like a gang, if you move near them they'll attack you for no reason. I had a situation where I was interacting with a coffee machine and police started shooting at me. Police aggression disables your fast travel, or access to quick sell points. I really suggest installing a mod that disables random police attacks, and just makes them fight you once you start committing crimes. 

You can implant a lot of cyberware into yourself. You cannot uninstall once installed cyberware, but you can exchange it for another. While it provides fun customisation I didn't really like the system. Most of the implants don't change how V looks. One would want to be able to chrome out as much as other characters you meet, but the most you can get are some stickers on your hands. Furthermore, most of the cyberware is only available in one store. There's about a dozen of them in the world, so if you want to find the best version of hands implants you have to check all stores until you find one selling a legendary option. But some cyberware end up on lower rarities, and you have no way to know which one is the best. It's totally unnecessary, since the purchases are tied to your reputation system anyway. All cyberware stores should have access to all items you have access to... wouldn't be to unrealistic, but much more enjoyable. There's similar issue with high-level crafting, when you might spend hours looking for schematics that you need, because you don't know which store sells it. Or just check the wiki. But it all was very unnecessary and needlessly convoluted. 

In general your choices are just roleplaying for the sake of roleplaying. To make your V yours. But there are few moments, that I call jRPG traps. You know, like in jRPGs you will permanently miss out on ultimate weapon if you didn't look under your bed during the opening scene of the game? And you will find about it only after 100 hours of gameplay, in a game with no decisions and consequences? Well, that is exactly how cyberpunk does stuff. You decide to hit a guy that, by the game description, is the worst human in the world? Sorry, best cyberware is now out of your reach. Who cares that in this game you constantly kill people for less than that guy did, this one time there are consequences. And there are 3-4 places like this, where out of nowhere you'll be punished for roleplaying.

The game has some bugs. I got blocked out of completing one quest. But most of the bugs are simple glitches, things floating here and there and funny open-world shenanigans. Honestly, Skyrim after 10 years is still much more buggy.

Don't trust the haters, play this. It's fun, but imperfect. It has high quality, and runs well considering how it actually looks. It's not a dream game, and probably doesn't live up to the hype some people had, but if you look at what is there you'll find just really good game, one of the better ones you can play in 2022.

The game has very rich storyline. Gets buggy sometimes but the combat system is really good. I like the addition of body modifications like mantis blades, gorilla arms etc. The only issue i have is the driving. It doesn't feel very responsive and has delayed input which makes the vehicle/bike very slippery when applying brakes and has poor handling. Apart from that the side content and various gigs provide extra insights on the characters otherwise the main story is not that long. Do the side quests as you play along the main story because the side contents have a lot of branching which can get very interesting.
It is a very good video game, with a good story and the mechanics are quite fun, apart from the bugs and all the commotion that arose at launch I would recommend it to anyone who wants a good story.

Well this game is making me angry.
What game mixes this quality of story telling, with this amount of voice acting and animations?
What game mixes this graphical quality, with this great performance? 
What game have this quality of world details and small story changes that impact your story?
What game is having 100 hours of unique and fun gameplay that barely ever feels repetitive. 
Im judging this game after some patches, but this is mind-blowing, how a game so good can be so berated by gaming community? This is making me angry. Whatever the reason is, people are hating this game, it has nothing to do with actual quality and objective measurement against competitions games. Is it buggy ? In 100 hours of this massive-story telling-rpg is absolutely ridiculously fine.  This is one of the most expensive games in history and the production value breathes at you at every turn, in every way.

Playing without the interruption of loading screens feels like the new era of gaming.  The seamless nature of the gaming experience is impressive. No matter how large an open world game might be, frequent loading screens can make it seem smaller and less interactive.  Cyberpunk shines by providing players with a truly immersive gaming experience. The game is fleshed out using vocabulary, fashion, and architecture that make Cyberpunk 2077 a visually unforgettable experience.  This game attempts to merge the best parts of RPG and FPS, and in that effort Cyberpunk 2077 succeeds. 
While this game is a success, there are elements that need some fine tuning, but for this casual/ intermediate gamer, this game checks all the boxes.

I was a Cyberpunk fan as soon as the first trailer came out for it in 2013. I knew nothing about the game but even from that short trailer I knew that the company behind it was passionate. 'When it's ready' was such a powerful message. Even though it wasn't gameplay footage, the quality of the video was nothing like I had ever seen before. Fast forward to 2020 and the launch was horrid. The message was no longer, 'When it's ready' the message was now 'When our stockholders say so'. It was so sad, I had been hyping myself up for almost a decade. I had talked it up to my friends saying that it was going to change videogames forever. It was so bad that I didn't want to pay to play it, I had seen so many videos of just how short the game fell. I was saddened. Since then, CDPR has been working diligently to gain back the attention of its initial audience by fixing bugs, releasing free content, and polishing the game overall. About a month ago I bought the game since it was $30 on steam, I thought the worst that could happen is that I play it just for the story. Almost 130 hours later and I'm loving every second of it. It's still my first playthrough and it gets repetitive at times, and the world doesn't feel as alive as I'd like it, but it manages to capture my attention and keep it. Currently, its about at 60% of what was promised but I'll take it. With the wide popularity of Edgerunners its brought in a whole new audience and returning players. With a sequel in the works and it being on Unreal Engine 5 (by the time it releases it might be ported over to Unreal Engine 6/7) I'm very excited for what's to come. Now is the best time to play this game and the next best is tomorrow. Enjoy Night City, chooms!

[b]TL;DR[/b]: Probably worth a buy the next time it's on sale, but still a flawed game.

The Good:
[b]The World:[/b] Night City is a fantastic setting and the world is big enough that you don't feel like there are walls boxing you in. The world is consistent and fun to explore and easy to get lost in.
[b]The Sub-Plots:[/b] Time and time again, I found myself getting lost in one side-quest or another. The characters that these lines explore are well thought out and feel human and it felt like a genuine opportunity to shape who your character was.

The Bad:
[b]The Main Plot:[/b] Gosh, this was the least interesting quest line in the entire game (Okay, I'm being a bit hyperbolic, but it was rough). It works for a little bit, but eventually you realize that the urgency that the game places upon the completion of the quests is entirely fake and then the invisible thread tugging you along the plot is snapped. It almost has to be for the rich, exploratory gameplay that the game encourages in every other aspect to work. There's no real choice in how the story evolves until the very end and, based on what you pick, the game ends in a slightly different flavor of melancholy. This would be fine, but this is a game that asks you if you'd rather live a quiet life or go out in a blaze of glory, and none of the endings deliver on either of those, instead you end up (probably) going out in a disappointing puff of smoke.
[b]Difficulty Balancing:[/b] My hubris led me to playing this game on hard in my first playthrough. That was a mistake. increasing the difficulty doesn't make the AI better, it just makes their guns stronger and armor thicker. You'll die in (literally) two or three shots while, picking up the same weapon that just killed you 27 times and using it on an enemy will take 10 shots to kill. While, perhaps, it is realistic how easily you go down, the result of this is that most of the weapons in the game are worthless. Don't even bother with pistols, assault rifles, and (usually) melee weapons (though some enemies are impossible to hit with firearms... so keep one of these around and hope they don't kill you as you mad rush them with it). The only effective combat strategy in my experience is to maintain stealth as long as possible and use a sniper rifle that can one-shot headshot to extend how long you can maintain stealth.
[b]Player Characterization:[/b] You have no real choices in what kind of person V is. This tends to be fine in stories like 'Life Is Strange' where you're not expected to imprint on Max super strongly (though I would argue that even that game does a better job than here), but this game prides itself on the sheer length of customization it gives you to V's appearance. But despite all of these options, the type of person V will be is the same from playthrough to playthrough. There's no good way to play a V with a different attitude or outlook and what choices there are are shallow and superficial. Frankly, save for a few pivotal (and incredibly obvious moments), your choices don't matter very much and when they do, it seems to be in mostly insignificant ways. 
[b]Linearity:[/b] For an open world game, Cyberpunk is rather linear. The sheer real estate taken up by the main plotline compared to the side quests is massive and it drive a lot of the game. The way the main quest line progresses, there tends a lot less waiting compared to many of the side quests where you have to wait a day for a character to go do something. This is realistic and even a little immersive, but at the end, where you're running out of side quests to do, it's really just a strong push to get back to the main quest.

The Ugly:
[b]Glitches:[/b] I finally bought this game because I had heard that it had been patched and most of the glitches were gone and, based on what we saw at launch, they are! But people floating in midair or stuck in the T-pose are disappointingly common. I encountered two or three glitches that stopped me from completing a quest altogether, and quests glitching to uncomplete an objective you finished are somewhat common. You can look past the glitches and see a great game, but boy glitches are still here and common.
[b]Driving:[/b] Gosh I hate driving in this game. It feels so slippery and hard to control. It's not that big a deal, you can use fast travel if you really hate it, but boy, the minute there were pedestrians or traffic, you end up with a lot of unintended fatalities.

[b]OVERALL:[/b] It may sound as if I'm overly critical, but I really did enjoy this game. It's almost certainly not worth retail though. Pick it up on sale and hope that they fix a lot of the ugly bits.

TL;DR It's good for one 40 hour playthrough and only if you don't look up anything about how your dialogue "impacts" the story, and don't waste time on all the gigs and shopping. Unless the dlc turns it around, I would never buy this until the full price tag drops below $20

I played the entire game. Did all the side quests and gigs, and most of the NCPD requests, before the final quest and I was so impressed... For all of like 30 minutes. Don't get me wrong, with all the updates and everything the game is good and stable. The ending is sort of somber and melancholy, much like other cyberpunk media. But the ending is also incredibly lackluster compared to the crazy hype of the opening sequences, lacks any real variety (hence why I call it an ending, instead of the "multiple endings"), and i spent more time going to and from quests than i spent on all the actual quests combined (and driving back and forth between the same 6 vendors).

Spoilers From Here On:

The intro sequences are phenomenal. They are varied and bombastic. Each starting scenario will bring you to the same place eventually, with you and your buddy Jackie taking on a crazy heist job, where you inevitably get injected with rockstar-turned-super-terrorist-turned-digital-construct-turned-cyber-tumor Keanu Reaves. While they all bring you to the same point, to be brief, that point is about the craziest and most interesting premise for a game I've ever heard of, along with the promise of spending lots of time with Cyber-Tumor Keanu.

The game is filled with (seemingly) loads of choices. It feels like you could slip and go on a wildly (or even slightly) different path just by picking a different dialogue. You can't. Your choices don't matter. Your side quests will always start the same, end the same, and take the same paths every single time. The only different ending you can get in side quests is the "i don't want to help you" ending, where the questline immediately and rather abruptly ends. All other quests, called gigs, are "talk at you for 30 seconds, go to yellow dot, kill 6-ish people and maybe steal something."

The main quest is the exact same, with the only difference being the final quest, which has "2" endings.
SERIOUSLY HUGE SPOILERS
Your options for how you take on the quest boil down to which characters you want to talk to while you do the same quest and what characters you talk to when it's all over. After which, you either "die" by being digitized and imprisoned/assimilated, or you have ~6 months to live. Those are your choices, all in a single dialogue choice, and nothing in the whole game affects them, not even a single line of dialogue to Cyber-Tumor Keanu. For one, let's be honest, you "dying" is not the real ending, and the ~6 months to live ending is also kind of a cop-out because in the moment you are making that decision, you are told it is absolutely certain, but then after the quest is over you're basically told, "no, there's got to be something we can do," and then the credits roll. After which you are deposited to just before the final quest starts with some added loot and nothing to do.

Nearly everything else about this game is good. The gameplay, the weapons and skills, Cyber-Tumor Keanu, build customization. The driving is fine, but all the money you spend on cars is wasted since the game gives you the fastest one for free anyway, and none of the quests are dependent on your car. The city is breath-taking at first, but eventually you just ignore it and stare at the Adventure Line!(tm) on you minimap. And while some of the side characters are really interesting, once their quest is over they just don't do anything, save for the 3 that you can choose to buddy with for the final mission.

I think the biggest problem is how little your dialogue with Cyber-Tumor Keanu impacts the ending. His interactions and dialogue are great. He could've been the thing that really turned the whole game around, but his endings are basically the same as yours. He either keeps your dying body and probably survives, or stays digitized and assimilates/gets deleted. So much potential and then nothing with no impact. Maybe they were trying to tell a tragedy, but it's just kinda melancholy, especially given the dialogue. I've felt sadder about much happier endings (hate to bring up the Witcher 3, but it's hard not to.)

After all is said and done, it's an ok game, reels you in so strong, and then just kinda meanders around and then ends without much happening. Not worth the price tag. Maybe when its full price drops below that of the Witcher 3, I'll recommend it, but not a moment sooner.
