The story is great, intriguing and complex and you'll legit care about the characters - especially thanks to the great voice acting. It's not as philosophically deep as the Matrix but it does make u think and Keanu Reeves is there. The game is beautiful, but it misses the melancholy that's characteristic of the cyberpunk genre. Plenty of neon tho, but there should be more. One can never have too much neon. 
Gameplay is cool but missing that oomph which could've been some sort of, let's say, technomagic. You can hack computers and even people, but maybe adding some shiny abilities to spice it up would be great, like grappling hooks, lasers, holographic illusions, lightning, the sort. That said, you can mount a rocket launcher on ur arm, which is cool. Also their crafting system is simple, doesn't require too much grind and doesn't make me want to commit sudoku like Skyrim's.
The game's reputation was tarnished by the bugs, and while there's still some you barely notice anything. But they can be annoying. 
However the game should be more vertical, you know? More action on the top of buildings, more access to higher places, people living in precarious high-up slums with little foot bridges connecting the various quasi-hanging neighbourhoods. Especially more flying options. Like bruh, a futuristic game that doesn't give you flying cars or drones? Missed opportunity imo.
All in all, solid 8/10 game, would buy it again.

Started playing this nearly 2 years after release, so didnt experience all the issues with bugs during release. This is a great game. Night city is massive and really well done. I enjoyed the main storyline,  but given the amount of side quests and gigs there are, I felt that it almost forced you to complete it too soon, such that you kinda feel that there is so much that you missed. Basically once you get to a certain point in the main storyline you cant go back and complete other parts of the game, until you have completed the storyline and then it lets you go back to the last save before the endgame, which feels a bit silly as all youve done is just wind back time. Nevertheless its still a great game.

The game is like a much larger and more impressive version of the Deus-ex games, which were great in their time, but always felt a bit small and constrained by the maps. That certainly isnt the case with Cyberpunk 2077.

There are some things that could have been done better in the game. Until you get a really decent car, most of the time a motorbike is much better for getting around as you can weave through traffic better. Even when you have some of the fastest cars in the game or are on a motorbike the acceleration differential between normal cars on the road isnt big enough. If they didnt give the AI cars such good acceleration you could feel like it was much easier to cut through the traffic.

Also In the roleplaying game you couldnt just load up with a much cyberwear as you wanted as you ran the risk of going cyberpsycho. In this game you can have as much cyberwear as you want and there are no downsides. They should have limited your cyberwear based on your Cool stat. So the more cyberwear you want the higher you cool has to be and finally the net running skills are really good in combat, but its not a choice of being good with guns or blades or being good with quick hacking, you can be good at everything. Yes you can do a bit more damage if you put points into pistols or auto rifles, but I didnt heavily specialise in them and still felt I could totally wreck with guns if I wanted to. But by the time I got very good with quick hacking and had good quick hacking cyberwear  alot of encounters didnt really need much in the way of guns. Maybe im being picky and the harder difficulty levels might make the gun skills seem more worthwhile, but certainly on Normal you are a one man army.

As much as it pains me to say this... I can't recommend this game at full price. Get it half price, heck even less if you can. 
I loved The Witcher 3, so I could not wait to play this game coming from the same developers and giving it 2 more years to bake in the oven after release. My awe of beautiful Night City turned into frustration after a few hours. This world is severely lacking, even while being nice to look at. Braindead AI NPC's walk through walls, cars, at times they even vanish and respawn if they are out of frame for more than a fraction of a second. No one else rides bikes on the roads except for you. Sure you'd see some gangs on the street by their bikes but never ride them. Breaks immersion IMO. Some missions are still, even at patch 1.61 buggy as hell. Picked up Cyberpunk just recently when it was on sale. It looks like most of the severe game-breaking bugs were resolved but there is some still existing. 

I regularly encountered what I would consider some type of memory leak or bad driver from Nvidia on my 3080 where it would eventually run out of VRAM and start to page the pc ram. Reinstalling different drivers from Nvidia did nothing to resolve the problems. 
This bug of course caused severe fps loss and I can only think that the game engine and the driver were not unloading resources properly. Saving the game and opening and closing it would resolve it. This obviously occurred much more frequently inside the night city areas. In the badlands I hardly encountered the issue. Outside of this, a few weird encounters with npc's acting strange.

So first things first. Gameplay/Gunplay is fun and addictive. You can specialize in multiple weapons or just go brute force and melee.
Quickhacking is very powerful and breach protocol are interesting but the breach protocol got kind of old after doing it hundreds of times.

Story-wise it was interesting, I liked the different paths just like with Witcher.

Side missions were for the most part just to kill time, make some coin, upgrade your levels and skills.

If you are on the fence about buying it, wait for it to go on sale and play through it, its worth it but not for full price.

Solid game after all is said and done. Got a lot of flak (deservedly so) for being unfinished at launch, and to this day there are still some nasty bugs. Save loads take a minute or more to pop up sometimes (on an NVMe SSD) and after completing the game, I was stuck in a limbo state where I couldn't do anything, not even jump or shoot. Restarting and reloading that save does nothing, and the game created over two dozen unique saves during the last mission for some reason. Not sure if I'm softlocked or if I'll just have to revert a decent chunk of progress because I was too dumb to make a manual save right before trying the final mission. Does that also mean I'm screwed out of endgame rewards? Will I have to mod them in? Hope this gets fixed ASAP, especially before New Game+ comes into play because this sounds like an issue that could brick saves entirely.

Overall a fun game, probably great for Skyrim modding fans that want a little something different to tinker with to be honest.

I, like many others, came around to buying this game after watching through Edgerunners. I can wholeheartedly say that I'm glad I did - and I'm glad I waited. While there are still optimization issues needing to be fixed (largely the difference between Medium and High settings for some graphics features, which are disproportionate to actual visual difference) the game's never crashed on me, I've run into no progression-blocking bugs, and the bugs that remain are largely humorous at most when I do - rarely - run into them.

The gameplay's mostly fine - melee or netrunner are your most enjoyable paths compared to just shooting things. Something to still be tuned up is the handling on vehicles 'cuz oh boy does it feel like you're driving on butter when turning. But there aren't any critical gameplay flaws otherwise and I hear the melee system is even getting a revamp in the near future.

What you'll stay for is the voice acting, narrative direction, and the immensely potent art direction for the design of the city, the badlands, all of it, not to mention the superb sound design and tracks. There's never a bad time to hop on a vehicle and cruise from destination to destination rather than use fast travel points, because there's more radio stations than you can shake a stick at and all of them have excellent music. The main and supporting cast are varied, rich in design, and excellently cast and acted - that goes for Keanu as Johnny Silverhand as well, and particularly the voice acting for V whether you're male sex or female sex, to the point that I wound up feeling V as a distinct character rather than a blank slate for myself - and didn't feel it was an impediment to the RP part of this RPG.

Clocks at about 60+ hours, provided you're like me and do all the side content before wrapping with the final missions. It's definitely shorter than I'd have expected, but considering the game was rushed out by executives, the lack of an extra 10-20 hours can probably be blamed on needing to fix the game before adding to it. And the Phantom Liberty DLC is due to drop in 2023, meaning there'll be plenty more to come.

All in all? I'd give this a solid 8.5/10 now. It's well worth the price.

I give Cyberpunk a 6/10. The game is enjoyable and fun for what it is. If they advertised this as a linear story-based action game I'd give it a 9/10(excluding the bugs). But, for what they promised, an RPG like the Witcher 3 or Fallout, this is really, really bad. There is no long reaching choices, the only RPG like mechanic is the skill tree, and even that is sub-par. The only things that effect the outcome of the ending are a few side quests and your dialogue choices with Johnny Silverhand at the end.
If you go into this game expecting what they promised for the past 7 years or so, you will have a bad time. But, like me, if you waited 2 years and tempered your expectations, the game is good. The story is great and so are the characters. But this just isn't an RPG. Not at all. If you understand that, then pick it up on sale if you're interested.

[h1]The good[/h1]
The good outweighs the bad by a longshot!

[b]Soundtrack[/b]
The soundtrack is amazing, just cruising and listening to the radio is a nice experience. Quests are often accompanied by very fitting cyberpunky vibes.

[b]Night City[/b]
The city is extremely well designed and intricate. From the soundscape to how the highrises tower above you and they way so many nooks and crannies are explorable. You can tell a lot of heart has gone into designing it.

[b]Voice acting[/b]
Every major character has a great voice actor tied to it.

[b]Main quest and side jobs[/b]
The main quest is [i]amazing[/i], and when the world feels the most alive and radiant. Side jobs generally hold a very high quality and makes the world feel more alive by fleshing it out with different concepts, characters and so on.

[h1]The bad[/h1]

[b]Night City[/b]
The city just feels dead for the most part. There are a few exceptions where you stumble on fun dialogue between two NPCS. Anyone hoping for a cyberpunk GTA will be disappointed. NPC AI is really bad.

[b]Driving[/b]
Driving is still buggy, but alright as long as you don't collide. You can go flying like there's no gravity, or just wedge under cars and launch them. Cars sometimes spawn of out nowhere, as well as pedestrians. Some vehicles just had their own life, at least for me, and just drifted out of control at certain speeds.

The game had an incredibly rough start, with major gamebreaking bugs and glitches, although I myself never really encountered anything too bad I have seen videos of them. I bought it the day it came out, and actually had a pretty good time, but I never really got into it that much. 

Now, 2 years later I can without a doubt say that it's one of my favorite games of all time. I encountered very very few bugs throughout my playthrough, and the ones I did weren't game breaking at all. The gameplay is good, but what really stands out is the exceptional story telling and character development, and amazing voice actors. I love story rich games with great character design, and Cyberpunk is no exception, I really can't help falling in love with all the different characters Night City has to offer, Especially Kerry, Judy, the Aldecaldos and of course Johnny. 

The game is really beautiful, but might require a semi hardcore rig to get the best settings, at the moment I myself got an Intel i9-11900F and NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3070 and 16GBs of RAM, and had all my settings on Very High, with around 80-100 fps.

That's about all I have to say, it'll probably be one of those games that I'll revisit every year or other year.

TLDR: Great game with exceptional story telling and character design and fun gameplay. Couple years later and pretty much all of the gamebreaking bugs are gone.

TL;DR - They certainly put a lot of effort into this game and while it's technically worth $59.99 from that standpoint, the quality of what has been delivered isn't that of a triple A title. I'd suggest waiting until this is at least half priced, at which point you can go through and enjoy it for a great story with some amazing characters.


2 years later... this game still feels quite unfinished. I waited the 2 full years to play it because I had read all the reviews about how bad the bugs were- I can't imagine having played back then given how messy it still is. I think at this point if you want the "true Cyberpunk experience" that everyone anticipated and the dev originally advertised, you will have to wait until the sequel comes out (UE5 engine thank god)... which at the time of writing this I don't believe is under development yet. So that's going to be at least another 5-8 years.

I'll give credit where it's due-

>The writing and story is top notch. The dialogue feels very real- it really simulates making friends with many of these characters. 

>Some of if not the best written characters I've played with in a modern game- core characters particularly. Their personalities, facial expressions and body language are really well done. We are stepping into a new age of detail here, in my opinion where I truly see how far we've come from the early 90's

>Some of the characters (story related ones) have amazing detail and effort put into their visual design. Skin imperfections, freckles, pores, veins, scars- the list goes on. The attention to detail level is very high.

>Voice acting is high quality. Main story characters effectively convey a full range of emotions.

>The combat/skill trees feel like you have a lot of choices that offer dynamic gameplay.

As for the issues- there are a bunch that I will criticize, but I want to be clear that this game is a must have for any PC gamer. There is obviously much content cut from the game and plenty of bugs. The biggest issue of all is how the city kind of feels somewhat empty despite being full of NPCs. Once the graphic novelty and story begin to fade away, you're kind of playing GTA with more in depth combat.

>The game has system crashes that are seemingly random. It's gotten worse the longer I've played and there's a plethora of the same complaints on reddit. It might be the current patch.

>The city feels like an empty facade; hardly any of the storefronts are real and 99% of the NPCs you can have no interaction with. It's almost like playing GTA from 15 years ago with modern graphics. Everyone in the world is basically a zombie with the occasional bad guy mixed in.

>Quest NPC and vehicle pathing will plow through terrain objects in hysterical fashion
>Quest NPC and vehicles get stuck
>Terrain objects you're not interacting with will randomly shoot across the screen at high speed- literally happens when they come in view.

>Pathing lines for direction/quest trackers have broken Z axis and will occasionally send you up or down steps, placing you above/below here you need to be and or in directions that are less efficient. They also seem to update late; EG, you will be closer to the objective in a different path but on your map radar it will still direct you going a further way around.
>Enter/exit wrong side of cars, including hijacking driverside can happen as hijacking passenger side.

>Upon death, enemy bodies will get suspended on any and all objects and float in awkward positions; this is something you'd expect from a $10-15 game and not a $59.99 triple A title. Dead bodies will appear contorted and bent in unintentionally hilarious directions. Most enemies you kill will land in some ridiculous position. For a game that went above and beyond with detail in so many areas, this part is pretty messy.
>Enemy body parts/limb severing is very low quality. Basically there's no blood and you'll just see an arm in the middle of a white floor with nothing around it- looks super janky.
>Blood on skin shifts around as a whole like a separate texture layer. On close ups and during the story quest it looks pretty bad. Blood also bisects through body parts; there will be a 2d sheet of blood in the middle of a body part and it looks like the blood is floating.

>Volumetric clouds can have a massive FPS drop (1-5 FPS) in some areas despite playing on an i9-12900k and 600w RTX 4090

>Cut content is rampant. Storylines will have you in places that make it out to be something that will be used later to only find out that it's been removed because of "insert story excuse here" and they get to cut some content/save time to force the premature release back in 2020.
>All adult content was basically cut out despite sexualized marketing for the game. There's no actual strip clubs, despite some cool looking ones out there with doors that will never open. Braindance doesn't exist for fun- it's purely used in detective work despite being talked up all game as a pleasure thing. As I searched there's two "Joytoy" (hookers) in the entire game. Genitals are in the charbuilder despite not being part of the game in any way, which begs the question why it even exists in the first place.

>Vehicle physics and control is very exaggerated and not in a great state, unless you are in one of the endgame models at which point it's "ok".
>Sprint will occasionally stop working and require game reload to correct
It was a DAMN rough start, but I quite enjoy the game now

This game is fairly large, so 35 hours is like less than 1/3 of it, but it's off to a fun start. 

Graphics: they're fine. It doesn't matter though. That's not what you're here for. You're here for the aesthetic, the vibe, the feel, the flavor, and, on factory settings, the film grain and motion blur bring that and leave all those sharp edges at home. They got the feel right and that's what's important.

Impact: For all the running and gunning, senseless slaughter, and satirical ads being hurled at your eyeballs with enormous force at breakneck speed, there's an emotional side to cut all that raw, saccharine violence. It's the salt on fine chocolate or bitters in a sweet cocktail trick and it works here as well as it does in food. If you come along for the ride, savoring the bittersweet moments, it'll hurt a bit, making all the sandbox staples of murder and mayhem feel fun again, even if you've played em' all before.

Conclusion: It's Deus Ex with less originality and more emotion. It has more heartfelt moments than most 3A games, but the mechanics, gameplay, and formula are ripped from Dying Light, GTA, and The Sandbox Handbook. 
It's f***in' fun. Try it. 

P.S. Oh, and the bugs everyone heard about on release seem to be brought down to the level of any other sandbox game, so I guess they fixed most of em'.

even though all the bad press 2077 have, personally i think I'm not dissatisfied by it.

Sure i wish the quests&sidequests is as high quality as Witcher3's where even the mini quest is not as straight forward as it seems, and there's always some plot twist in the end, and all animated and voiced instead just a flavor text found in briefcase/body. but 2077 have much more of them quests&events that its unrealistic to have all of them animated and voiced.
and sure i wish the plot is not Keanu Silverhand oriented where V is a side character dragged along for the ride, but its V against the system, the world, and the megacorpo. but as far as I go in the storyline I quite enjoy the ride. 
The experience its finally an open world cyberpunk game, before 2077, personally I am craving for a good cyberpunk theme game, nostalgia of Syndicate, quenched a little by Shadowrun&Deus Ex, dissapointed by Dex, but none actually hit the mark. that is until 2077 came.
The Visual and oh the visual candies. Sometimes mid game, i just stand there, just absorbing the view, windowshopping all the street vendors, the foodstalls just admiring the details, in some randos who just flatlined's home and thinking, damn this is not bad place you have here, i wonder how it feels to live here for a couple of days and just chillin. the vibe of the city, the luxury of the corpos, even the badlands somewhat aesthetic and make me wish i would want to experience all this vibe IRL. 
there is some bugs in the beginning, but getting less atrocious every patch update.  

Overall personally I can't think of anything on the market that would give me a better cyberpunk genre experience than Cyberpunk2077.

After finally finishing Cyberpunk 2077 on my 4th return to the game to give it another chance, I can say I'm glad I did. After putting aside the initial frustration I felt at the game for its "undercooked" release and coming to the game in a mindset of actually completing it. While watching the story rather than just rolling my eyes and slamming the "skip" button I decided "why not just see how Keanu does in this?" and I was not disappointed by the twists and turns the story takes you on. Coming from someone who originally used to call this game "cyberpiss" back in the day, I completely retract that statement and can happily say this game sits in my top 10 favorites for sure. The modding community and the fact that CD PR has given open access to the modding tools for the game only opens up more opportunities for variety of gameplay as well. Full price or on sale, I highly recommend this beast of a game.

Although pre-ordered, didn't play until patch 1.6 where it became stable, Like witcher 3, was full of bugs but now, its a great game. If you're a fan of system shock and deus ex (and their sequels) you'll love it. If you have read neuromancer, you'll love it. If you are pressed for time as you're old enough, this is worthy of the time investment. If you enjoy games as art, this is that. If you want a rip-and-tear shooter this ain't it. 

Is it a great game? now, yes.

Pros:

- Large variety of firearms which are well-modeled and feel satisfying to shoot
- Wide variety of cybernetics/upgrades that promote large build diversity (ignoring how we only have 4 arms and 3 main OS choices)

Cons: 
- Lots of stuttering (even with lowered graphics settings)
- Driving ranges from mediocre to "I stopped at one street and am still drifting for 3 more", so this makes car chases painful to do
- Delamain's taxi service isn't usable outside of an Act I quest
- NCPD Assault markers don't show which gang is fighting there, leading to you accidentally taking fights that are very much above your level

Lemme tell you where this game is at now. What you have here is a deep game. Don't rely on your knowledge of old tropes and themes. There are times this game feels too real for comfort. Times I've taken on certain side quests as a reprieve from the emotional impact of the previous one. Trigger warnings have to be given for mental abuse, physical and sexual abuse. Sometimes playing this game is genuinely harrowing, other times it's a wonderful joy. But it's always fun, and its always impressive in it's storytelling, and the depth of its characters. Some things could be streamlined, but this game is one of those rare near-perfect gems. Mature, unique, deep, engaging, and plain old fun.

Quick review for anyone interested in this game. Most of the bugs from launch are ironed out, any that you rin into will not in any way be game breaking, but will definitely ruin immersion for a short while. These bugs include loss of audio in cutscenes, t-posing in and out of cutscenes, and strange glitches such as npcs teleporting around/cars exploding for no reason. Night City has a lot to offer, and the game offers a variety of unique and diverse build paths for anyone looking to make multiple runs through the game. Where the game is fleshed out, it feels incredibly immersive, although unfortunately a large chunk of the map is quite empty and void of content. Overall I give the game a solid 5/10 after my 40-50 hour playthrough, I bought this game on sale for 30 dollars and consider it 30 dollars well spent, but absolutely would not recommend anyone pay full price for the game.

After the numerous bug and glitch fixes that plagued this game upon launch, some frustrating, some downright hilarious, this game is functionally in a playable state for me. I've had only one crash to desktop, which coincided with having to verify the game file integrity. Other than that, smooth as butter 90% of the time. I get a few frame stutters and freezes that come out of it each time, on occasion, but that might just be my drivers for my graphics card. Also, I get a non-game breaking bug once in awhile where the entire game loses all color and becomes black and white, textures also disappear when it happens. Almost like the game was sent to the shadow realm. I swear the first time I saw it, I thought it was an artistic choice until I realized, no...that's a bug. Its an easy fix, just save the game, reload the save, and it corrects itself. Other than that, I didn't pick this up day one, waited almost a year and a half after release to buy it, payed $30 US, definitely worth the $30.

-- Bugs --
There are some occasional bugs, some silly and a couple rather game breaking that can require some save/loading. 
At one point during the mall mission for the Voodoo boys all the doors were blocked and I had to reload and trigger things in a different way to get through.
At another, all the lighting completely disappeared and I had to restart the game for everything to look right again.
You'll see pedestrians flying in the middle of traffic from time to time. That kind of thing.
It's recommended to keep multiple saves, although the game does seem to keep some from key points from the past several hours of playtime or so.
-- Controller --
The "skip dialog" button is fantastic but they mapped it to the same as the crouch button and there didn't seem to be a way to remap the controller in-game. This can be quite frustrating for certain sections when dialog just pops up and you accidentally skip it trying to re-enter stealth
-- Combat --
The mantis blade executes knock you out of time slow mode. This is pretty dumb and you learn ways to prevent the execute animation from happening just to avoid this
played for almost a month. Good game, like the cyberpunk vibe and concept and uniqueness of the cyberware and weapons. Much better game with mods. Sometimes you do get a few cursed bugs but is aight.

Honestly, if you told me this would be one of my favorite games a year, or two ago i'd laugh because of how much of a buggy mess it was. While I haven't watched Edge Runners yet it's part of what got me to try it out since it got people to come back to it, and notice how significantly it's improved which eventually led to me finding out about it causing me to take an interest in the game again. Now like all games it ain't perfect, and never will there are still it's fair share of bugs, but the game is playable, and it generally wont mess with your experience, I've done a full play through explored alot of it's content, and haven't really discovered a major bug that stuck out to me. With bugs aside though the game has an excellent story, it's an emotional roller coaster with one of the coolest intro's i've experienced in my opinion. I enjoyed, and had fun with the combat it's fun testing various play styles, and using a rather large assortment of weapons, and cybernetics. As I said the combats fun, but it's not really ground breaking, melee combat is similar to Skyrim, but is improved, polished and has more too it. Gun combat is likely what you'd expect, but I personally found it pretty fun experimenting seeing what I could do, or pull off with guns while using the Sandevistan like shooting grenades mid air to set them off earlier and other things.  The main cast of characters you'll be interacting with are good, they usually have a good questline linked to them, and make some small appearances in some quests while in some cases they can alter the ending of the game, or give you a different ending option. As you likely already know Keanu Reeves plays a significant role in this game being Johnny Silverhand which he nailed, did an excellent job with I really enjoyed the role he played, and found him extremely interesting. Personally I tend to take high interest in the sound tracks of game, shows, and movies so I always appreciate a good soundtrack which they didn't disappoint me with this games sound track at all, I can't speak much about the raido stations since I didn't listen much to them, but I enjoyed most of the tracks playing throughout the game. Overall ignoring bugs, and past issues this game had i'd give this game an 9/10 on the game itself, and a 10/10 overall the last game that got me this hooked with it's story was probably Red Dead Redemption 2 while it'd likely place in 3rd or 4th place for my favorite games of all time.

Performance on PC still isn't great, but is better than it was at launch. I really enjoyed the main story and most of the side quests. The game offers a lot of content if you are looking to do everything ( one playthrough where I did nearly everything took me approximately 135 hours), but if you don't care for side content you could probably complete the main quest and the important side quests in about 20-25 hours. Choice and consequence is present, but don't expect it to be on the same level in that regard as the Mass Effect trilogy, Fallout New Vegas, or other similar RPGs. CP2077 also excels when it comes to atmosphere. If you like the visual style and feel of Blade Runner (OG & 2049) you will appreciate this. Would recommend.

I had a really good time playing Cyberpunk. There's a lot that can be said in a lot of different areas, and probably all of that has been rehashed ten ways from Sunday. So what was my big draw?

The big draw that kept me playing was the immersion. This is a combination of the graphics with RTX, incredible voice acting, and the attention to detail to the characters. I romanced Judy and the story line with that was amazing. The icing on the cake was the detail that CDPR added after that story arc. I don't want to spoil anything, but sufficed to say adding the options to continue interacting with characters that you've grown to love is something every game developer that cares about their players should. To me this is a selling point.

Really, any problems I had with Cyberpunk are problems/tropes I have with the genre in general. The only thing I'll mention in particular is guns. It always annoys me to no ends that guns of the same caliber do different damages (at least dramatically different damage, because there's a tiny variation).

Seriously though, amazing immersion, storytelling, characters, and an engaging plot that isn't flat.

Clearly this game has come a long way from its release. I'm engaged in the story so far, the gameplay is pretty fun, and the environmental designs are really nice. More than anything, it's tempting me to get the TTRPG its based on and see if that's worth playing. 

That said, it's worth noting they haven't removed all the problems. The game occasionally crashes, or freezes, not to an unplayable degree, but enough to be noticeable. Sometimes details don't load right away, leaving characters you're talking to (or trees/plants) as vague, blurry blobs, but that usually corrects after a few seconds. Less technical side, there's little to indicate if some side missions are too dangerous for you until you try to tackle them and get wrecked. Maybe that last one is more my fault than the game's though.

In general, recommend playing it. The problems are mostly minor, and even the bigger issues are far between. The game's a lot of fun.

I purchased this game probably a year after it was released (when I finally managed to get my hands on a new graphics card), so I missed all the initial mess, and the game was much more complete when I played it. And I enjoyed it well enough for its story and game play. I got almost to the end of the game before I got distracted by something else and put it down, until like so many the Edgerunners anime on Netflix sparked my interest again and I came back to it and started over from the beginning. This time I played with mods installed, which I highly recommend. The vanilla version is good on its own, but mods let you tweak or change all the little things that annoy you.

Now the game:

The story is decent. After the first few missions of the game which serve as a sort of prologue before the entire map opens up, the story centers around you trying to find a way to remove Johnny Silverhand's (Keanu Reeves) digital ghost from your brain before your entire psyche is overwritten and he takes over. New friends are made, enemies are faced and defeated, and there is even a chance to enter into romance along the way. The usual stuff. 

I feel they missed an opportunity with the three "life paths" you choose from in the beginning. Other than a few dialogue options, and an initial starting mission, the different life paths don't really offer any real differences. All the quests are available, and I believe all of them have the same options for completing them, and all the endings are available from each one. It really takes away from the replay value.

As many have said, it's a little disappointing to go through the process of character creation when the only time you get to see your character is in the menu screen or when riding a motorcycle. A few mods have attempted to implement it, but the animations look silly. Considering games like Skyrim have achieved first-person-to-third-person modes of game play you wouldn't think this would have been that big of an ask.

I also wasn't very happy with the driving in the game. The steering felt really sensitive, with the car whipping back and forth when you try to steer at high speed. I found motorcycles to be way more responsive. And it's way easier to drive using an X-Box controller than mouse and keyboard. Fortunately you can switch between them seamlessly.

The game looks good, graphics-wise, although your mileage may vary depending on your hardware.

There are tons of mods out there for this game now too, from graphical enhancements to quality-of-life tweaks that make it more enjoyable. 

But anyway, to sum up, what started as an over-hyped disappointment has become a pretty enjoyable game worth playing.

Watch Edgerunners, and this will be a treat.

I was put off by the glitch reports at launch, despite absolutely loving the idea of this setting, but Edgerunners made me reconsider. I think they've come a long way since the initial bugs, and are still patching things to make everything more stable. Those who look for glitches will find them, just like in any other game, but the atmosphere and stories here are undeniably worthwhile.

If you:

a) have the horsepower to run this thing,
b) are willing to forgive a few flaws, and
c) liked the atmosphere of EdgeRunners and want to spend more time exploring it,

you won't be disappointed.

There's going to be a few bugs, but you'll also find a world full of interesting NPCs, cool storylines, and an open world that supports a wide variety of play styles. The main quest has some great moments, and some of the sidequests are absolutely amazing.

Be warned, however, that Night City is a futuristic dystopia, with all the trappings that go into that. You'll see sex, drugs, and violence everywhere. If you're not okay with that, this isn't the game for you.

So I just played Cyberpunk,
and I expected some bugs and glitches so my expectations were set low however in the end the game still managed to disappoint me. 
You are in this huge city full of lights and people, a world you think is filled with stories and encounters to the brim, just take the first door you see, and notice that  95% of doors are made never to be opened.
The quest and story are decent some parts are even good, but it only took me 15 minutes to accidentally find an "infinite money/items and exp" glitch, had some T-Posing NPCs and gun bugs where my gun was invisible or my body was invisible or couldn't aim and shoot. However, I expected such "minor" glitches and bugs and played on. The bugs and glitches I encountered, later on, were also on the same level as these. However What broke the camel's back was the horrendously bad-made races, I will just say rubber banding.
I finished the game's main story and a decent amount of the side quest. I lost interest in buying all houses and cars because of the money glitch I encountered by accident.
Some nice things were the references and easter eggs to the Show Edgerunners, I appreciated these. 
As Conclusion I can say, don't buy the game at full price buy it when it's on sale for like 50% if you want to play.

Still a little screwy in some parts, definitely needs more tweaking but it is still fully playable.  it's a beautiful looking game and yes, I would love to see the world much more filled out but the reality is not everyone is running a quantum supercomputer and in order to render the world to "cyberpunk" standards (ie: packed like the streets in Blade Runner)we would need one so based on that, I feel the world is decently filled.  
     To an old guy like me, a game like this is like a 20+ hour choose-your-own-adventure movie with great replayability, well worth the money if you are into William Gibson's writing and Hollywood style adventure scripts.  
     I've played through once and feel I only tasted a small portion of what is to offer in this game, and I keep wanting to go see what else I can find.  
     This is a worthy addition to any collection.

Cyberpunk is a very ambitious game that tries to have a strong storyline like Witcher 3, with an extensive worldbuilding, and also an open world that feels alive like GTA or Red Dead. 

The storyline is strong, albeit not on the level of extremely good like Witcher 3, but most of the sidequests can be interesting and makes you think about the fucked up world of Cyberpunk. Gigs are one of the core timesinks in the game, small sidequests with a story you can get into if you like to read texts and small details but if you just like to run and gun and listen to dialogue, you can still understand it and have fun with the gameplay.

On the worldbuilding part and having it feel alive? It fails heavily on it.  I'll not discuss the buggy parts since that has already been discussed to death by everyone else but the perfect description for Night city would be that it is a very beautiful art piece, but not one that can be interacted with. AI for NPC's is bad, and also extremely buggy. They don't actually do much and you can't interact with them. NPC Variety, and most importantly, all of the enemies feel the same. A lot of gangs with very different stories and styles were always hyped up in the trailers but ingame, theyre pretty much all the same and there aren't much interaction with them. Just enemy A and enemy b with different clothings. Could have had a good faction system with influencing the gangs that there is a lot of thought to  but not noticeable in game.

Worth it to buy on sale, the experience is fun, and the main quest is fun with Johnny (Keanu Reeves) being an interesting companion for the whole game.

Still busted. But now it's like Skyrim. The difficulty slider is just how unfun you want to make melee combat. The gameplay sucks, but the story and world building is probably the best in a long time. Definitely worth when on sale.

Honestly, i do love this game. the story line is amazing, graphics great, game play choices... all fantastic.... and yet it pisses me off 20 times a day as it crashes more often than not when something is just finished being done or in the heat of battle. its damn near unplayable for me at times. the story and immersivness suffer so badly because of it. I'm rocking a 12700k and a 3090 ftw3 so i shouldn't have any issues; not oc'd and up to date and still crashes every 20 minutes! 

Please do better, cant recommend until i can go a full session without it dying

The game is fine but has so many problems even after all that has been done to it. If you are purchasing Cyberpunk 2077 because of Edgerunners you will be disappointed. If anything Edgerunners is more accurate to the source material then this game.

For one, while visually striking, Night City is a very empty place. Driving around is also annoying since the AI drives so slowly and will crash into you constantly. This could have easily been solved by simply expanding the road to make passing other cars easier.

Next, there is too much side stuff that ends up being repetitive, slowing the game down, and also provides a disconnect from the story. I don't think the game needed around 160 NCPD scanner missions where you enter an area, kill all the enemies and then leave. Also, instead of having 100+ gigs that have the same problem, just create 20 that are well written and interesting. After slogging my way through all of the side content I just wanted the game to be over.

Also, this game is not an RPG. The "Role-playing" is very weak and honestly should have been like Fallout: New Vegas.

Lastly, the story is very weak. I never like plots where there is a time limit that never matters since it creates a disconnect between the player and the story. The first act is probably the best and I wish they stuck to that instead of changing it to incorporate Johnny Silverhand for no reason.

There are so many other problems like the various bugs that are still present but that would make this longer then it needs to be.

Overall, Cyberpunk 2077 should have just copied the tabletop RPGs that it is based on. It's a good game that will never reach the full potential it should have.

Give it a shot.

After the rough launch I decided to wait with the purchase until issues are fixed.
After watching Edgerunners and seeing reviews for patch 1.6 I decided it's time to buy it and I must say I do not regret it.

Story and characters are great, deep and very well written, world is beautiful, gameplay is very fun, and allows a lot of experimentation.  The visual spectacle is unlike other games I've played.
Combat balance on higher levels suffers slightly but it's not anything mods can't fix.
It runs extremely well on rtx 3060, on 1440p ultra and rtx on, dlss off, no drops below 45 fps, even in the middle of action.

As for bugs - yes some remain, like an npc t-posing in the middle of the street, or car spawning above street and falling down. I've encountered singular occurences, it didn't really break the game or stop story progression.
Any gamebreaking issues I've had were caused by mods and went away when I disabled them, so be mindfull of how you mod the game.
Long story short - beloved by everyone Skyrim has more bugs and issues than I've seen in 1.6 CP2077.

it's a little buggy now, but I've experienced nothing game-breaking, and the things I found inconvenient, they almost immediately patched. it's a great story, and I love how customizable your playstyle can be.

that's not to say I don't have gripes. seeing as it first started out as a TTRPG, it would've been a bit nicer to have freedom in your character, rather than just playing as "V". V's story was amazing, don't get me wrong, but they're treated as nothing more than your average muscle for hire, which I found exhausting, since I've found the most fun as a netrunner.

I also found it disappointing that your choice in "class" really only affects the intro, and some dialogue options. wouldn't it have been cool if it affected major plot points? maybe, in street kid, your previous trip to Atlanta could've caused some people to come looking for you, giving us a fantastic questline, while also answering the question of "what did V do in Atlanta?". maybe those guys who terminated you, and tried to kill you, in corpo, could've come back to finish the job. I want to see my choice really affect the world I'm playing in, and for me to be a former Arasaka employee, and have no one care? it seems kind of empty.

my last gripe is very trivial, so don't expect anything profound. I think there should be more additions to driving. I don't mean different cars, or flying vehicles, or even NoS or anything. why can't I use my turn signals? why can't anyone? why do traffic lights turn green almost immediately when I come to them? it breaks the immersion, for me, and makes driving feel unsafe. "no, I don't want to drive! some asshole's gonna take a blind left turn, and wreck my car!" the fact that I'd rather fast travel than drive really makes it hard to care about buying other cars.

I bought Cyberpunk right after Edgerunners released, I played a bit, then decided (with some recommendation from a friend) to complete the series before continuing the game. I have to say that Edgerunners made me open up my mind after refusing to purchase this game when it was released (and filled with bugs). I'd say that I love Cyberpunk 2077, I liked its theme since the E3 announcement, but led to disappointment when it released, but with Edgerunners, I finally played it.

What makes it bad is the immersion-breaking bugs, like.. bug that make NPCs teleport during the story and cars popping in-out in the city. I think the story, theme and songs all contribute to the immersion, but are broken easily with those bugs.

After I played it, I can recommend to my friends, but I'll have to say that they have to "ignore" the bugs, and focus on other aspects of the game to enjoy. Note that, it took me quite long to finally look past it.

Overall, good stories, had many beautiful moments, soundtrack is a blast, some bugs kills immersion. Would recommend.

Didn't follow any pre-release promotional stuff, so I'd say I'm not among those that were overhyped. 

Tried out the game after 1.6 released. 

My experience with Cyberpunk 2077 is comparable to a fancy visual novel with a very dark and sombre undertone. 
The game is functional, and combat is fluid. I had quite some fun - either going in gun blazing, or assassinating. Driving around Night City at night was exactly the rush that I expected, a gorgeous experience. Side quests are either nice or amazing, great stuff. The emotional moments, especially the death of[spoiler] Jackie [/spoiler]and the ending(s). They hit me quite hard. It wasn't a crying-my-eyes-out kind of emotional, but it did hit me deep.


Now... here comes the grievances:

- [b]The game felt very short [/b]in comparison to Witcher 3 and Skyrim. Really tried to convince myself otherwise but I'd be lying if I said I didn't wish there were (a lot) more to experience and explore. I really, REALLY wanted to participate and experience the opening half-year sequence of events with Jackie, as GAMEPLAY, not a montage. I am aware this is most likely cut content - their conscious decision, 'unfortunate' is all I can say.

- [b]Progression made little sense[/b]. [spoiler]After the heist, V's life is on a timer, [/spoiler]yet I have the leisure to be allowed to pursue romantic interests and do boxing. The game seems to have not made up its mind whether to pressure me into rushing or giving me free rein. [spoiler]Also, by having Takemura kill off Dexter, I feel like I lost my most urgent goal of vengeance, felt very disappointed.[/spoiler]

- [b]Story's pacing felt off.[/b] [spoiler]So many interesting characters got killed off early - if not too many. I got left with 4 romantic interests, 2 which are locked without mods, and Takemura (whose interactions with you also ends after a couple of main quests). Now I'm left with a bunch of whoever the f- fixers and a bunch of newly introduced characters that only ever get a chance in a side quest.[/spoiler]

- [b]Different life-paths made essentially zero difference in gameplay or story throughout the game.[/b] 90% of the differences are inconsequential dialogue choices asaik. Chose Corpo, and I really wish I could play more corpo-rat V: the setting was interesting, there were immediate goals, and I could smell the incoming dilemmas. In the end, I got only a weak whiff of what Corpo V could have been.

- [b]Main mechanics are dormant and un-impactful.[/b] This is the most frustrating complaint I have about the game. It felt like the devs came up with many good ideas for the game: relationship progression, health deterioration, lifepaths, time sensitive crisis, reputations, etc. But they just ... idk, don't click together that well. They all could have been valid and engaging core mechanics, yet they barely interact with one and another... and most importantly, NONE of them are meaningfully integrated with the main story, and it devalues all those mechanics as a result, stripping them any value they would've had. 

Other than that, the game is playable, and you will have quite some fun if you lower your expectations. Plus, it seems like the 1.6 patch Cyberpunk is far better than the Cyberpunk at launch, so I won't complain too much, every big game's got its flaws, and this one's just easier to spot. I'm also aware that many of the issues I've raised is likely due to the process of cutting content last minute, leaving many parts of the game hollow husks that remain, but soulless.


TLDR: The game's alright, although undoubtedly with many many could-haves. Obviously rushed/unfinished, and I would not have put 'recommended' if it weren't for the bits that did shine through. 6/10.

Cyberpunk 2077 had a rocky start yet most of it was on the console releases. On PC I had zero crashes, some silly bugs and glitches here and there. Nothing too immersion breaking. Finished the game, liked it. Started a new run at the end of -22. 
Now they have patched up the game and made it even more smoother to play.
Yes, there is untapped potential in this game.
Still it was and it still is an entertaining game with good story and where you can create your own way to survive the streets of Night City. Would it be melee, ranged, stealth or via hacking, all of the paths are fun in their own way. 
Only big negative from me to this game is the lack of verbal choice to approach the missions. You can sneak in, you can hack yourself in, you can break through the doors or even tinker your way through obstacles or just rush in guns blazing yet what is missing is a verbal, "Charmisma" or "Cool" way to progress through missions. We have lot of violence yet it would be so much fun if you could have a way to try figure our how to verbally get a chip or verbally try make a target surrender or just cheat and make fool of the enemy via deception. 
Will the incoming DLC offer something like this for us? We will see.

This game had a rough start, but it has come a long way. Cyberpunk 2077 is easily one of my favorite games now. 

Pros:
-The story is absolutely amazing, it is full of twists that leave you not knowing what to expect next.
-All the characters are unique and interesting, each with fun quests that present options for determining their outlook. [spoiler] There are several romance options that can add spice to V's life as well. [/spoiler]
-The gameplay is a lot smoother than it was, the devs have done a great job making it enjoyable.
-Character progression has lots of options, each path you can take when developing your character has different strengths and weaknesses. 
-The setting is completely unique and interesting. Not once did I ever question anything about the setting. I was immersed in it from the start, and it never grew old for me.

As great of a game that I think Cyberpunk is, its not without its faults too.

Cons:
-It still has bugs. I encountered many bugs in my play-through, but in 100 hours of gameplay (Post Patch 1.5) I only had 1 game-breaking bug that was fixed by reloading the previous checkpoint. Most bugs that I saw were just graphical errors, and most of the time they were self-correcting.
-Where Cyberpunk's strength is in its story and characters, it lacks in features. While not completely feature-less, don't expect something like GTA V. The world is full of gigs to complete and bad guys to kill, just don't expect to be able to customize your car or play a round of golf in your downtime. 
-Night City can feel empty in some places, I believe this is a result of its rushed development. There are some parts of Night City that seem empty, or lacking anything beyond surface details, but it was rare for me to feel this way.

To put my review into final words, I would absolutely recommend this game for the story alone. The bugs are manageable, and were easily ignored for me. If you love a good story game, then Cyberpunk for you.

its a very good gun game in an open world with vehicles and awesome parkouring system. everything that is offered in this game is worth the price in my opinion. But i would suggest on getting this when it goes on sale which is just as good. You can have builds that you can do for whatever fits the players play style, making it a joy to play. The only downside to this game is the occasional bugs every now and then again, but other than that, the game is a blast to play.

There are still a couple glitches in the game like not bein able to pickup items/loot boxes or a quest item not spawning. The way I fixed those glitches was that I either completely exit out the game and load it back up or I simply leave the mission and return once I complete a different mission or a mission that requires a scene to go  through.

I originally pre-ordered and game and put 20-30 hours or so into a save before stopping up until just around a week before writing this review.

I originally didn't have much intention of playing the game again, but having watched Cyberpunk Edgerunners, I felt like I had to, and I'm glad I did.

The game is still extremely buggy in its current state, although mostly minor bugs, though some bugs do affect gameplay and at times required me to reload a save to fix, but it wasn't enough to make me hate the experience. I still feel like I have some qualms with the story, but the acting is really good, and I enjoyed the story regardless of my problems.

Night City is extremely immersive when the bugs don't get in the way of it, and I think I heard that CDPR plans to continue making games in this franchise, so I can only look forward to it and hope they make an experience even better than that of Cyberpunk 2077.

Overall, I highly recommend the game and I enjoyed my time with it. I think the experience is more than worth the full price tag.

This game is the best single player RPG I have played in years, the game is worth your money and time now. The game is so much fun, I couldn't get enough.

I initially avoided picking it up as I wait for reviews before I buy most of my AAA games. A story I hate telling, that this game has 'done a No Mans Sky' because of course it should have released in the state it is in as of 1.6. CDPR persisted and put their reputation on the line.

The story is phenomenal and drags you in. This isn't really a game to play while hanging out on discord or in the living room full of people, at least not in the first play through, you'll break your immersion and miss parts of the story and the great writing that don't deserve to be. You ought to let yourself get immersed in the brilliant world that has been brought to life and inhabiting your "V" for that time.

The voice acting is very good, each character is exactly that, a character - totally unique and exiting. Consider your choice when choosing what gender you are as it has a much bigger effect than any life path you choose. Female V's voice acting is incredible, she has a raspy/sexy/sassy voice that as a male player was great to listen to. Her voice also blends well with johnny's in those scenes - I feel female V and Johnny interact more naturally also, Johnny loves women, but his relationship with V is nice to think of as a character building/arc experience for him beyond the obvious. Her voice can dispense emotion when required but maintains the tough girl mercenary the game demands of V. The only downside of a female V is that you cannot romance Panam or Kerry - FYI Panams romance is worth doing for the art of it... My god. While you won't be upset with male V, he comes across as a real asshole - this might suit what you are trying to RP as though.

The writing and world building are great; this game takes you on an emotional ride. If you finish all missions and learn about each character, you will end the game feeling like you are saying goodbye to some real friends and villains. The scope of the game is humbling, you occasionally get reminders that V is still a shit kicker is a shit city even when you feel on top - that there is an entire echelon of uber rich humans living in luxury habitats in orbit and you as V are walking around alleyways with people immersed in VR masturbating. The game tackles serious themes, especially relating to the soul, transhumanism, corporate imperialism and addiction. I found myself pondering on the larger picture, like any real world set dystopian game it suggests a world that is possible. The final hours of the game are tear jerking, and the multiple endings are worth playing out a few times to experience them. The build up and execution of those final hours left me feeling emotionally exhausted in the best way. When you finish the credit scenes, all I wanted was more.

The Leveling and RPG elements work well together and are unique enough. You level up and get a stat and perk point. Higher stat levels unlock higher level perks in the tree. You level skills/proficiencies by 'doing' them - which unlock additional bonuses and occasionally perk points. As you do things you get street cred which effects what items / vehicles / jobs are available around the city. Higher cred = better gear and jobs. Unique items are plentiful and the game really does fall into that Morrowing/Skyrim/New-Vegas/Witcher 3 feeling when you start again - thinking a build up and going for iconic weapons etc. Customization is great, depending on how deep you want to RP there are enough character customization / clothes / cars / play styles you can really create anything you like.

I cannot wait for more Cyberpunk. More stories in this universe, more mods and I can only hope we get spoiled for a paid DLC as impressive as Witcher 3: Blood and Stone.

Thanks CDPR for the best voiced protagonist for a long while, and the best RPG i've had the pleasure to enjoy for years.

No but seriously, Cyberpunk is great. If you like RPG's, if you liked the Witcher games, if you liked Edgerunners and just want to explore the world -  all good reasons to give it a try. Story is compelling, touching on some cool topics such as Cyberpsychosis. Not the best story you'll ever play, but if you immerse yourself in it, the ending(s) certainly packs a punch. I for one thoroughly enjoyed the story. 
The experience as a whole definitely leaves some to be desired - no real police system, no vehicle combat (yet), not as many interactive spots or accessible buildings like bars or BD clubs as I would've liked. I don't expect to enter every building, but I would at least like to sit somewhere and let my character eat or drink. Combat is good, not great. I have the most fun with a blades build, so I would recommend that. Has a lot of potential with cyberware to be an interesting and diverse combat system, but like many aspects of the game, it falls a bit short. All in all, combat is enjoyable, but it's not on the same level as many AAA titles. Stealth is definitely encouraged.
Regardless, I have nearly 500 hours logged and to this day I'm learning new things about the game and finding new places. I know many people knock the game for having unused parts of the map. I've never found this to be an issue. For me, the world is what keeps me coming back. Night City is incredibly dense and full of attention to detail. Some areas feel underutilized (Badlands), but never really dull. In short, if you're interested in exploring a cool world, it's worth trying for that alone. 
I have high hopes that continuing updates and the coming DLC will make this game what it was intended to be. As it stands, the game is great, but could always be better. Keep the updates coming, CDPR. (Also, mods are awesome and help with a lot of issues.)

[h1]Good:[/h1]
[list]
   [*]Fun and diverse gameplay
   [*]Great atmosphere and exploration
   [*]Modding scene to fix many issues/add features
   [*]Visually beautiful
   [*]Incredibly good soundtrack
   [*]Fills the void after Edgerunners
   [*]Good story and characters
   [*]Good side quests (not just fetch quests or "Go to ____ to kill ____")
[/list]

[h1]Bad:[/h1]
[list]
   [*]Bugs are noticeable and irritating even after the amount of time they've spent fixing the game
   [*]No dedicated dodge button on PC makes the mechanic near unusable
   [*]Somewhat grindy due to slow levelling
   [*]Complete freedom is somewhat a lie, a lot of the quests force you to follow certain routes by making you unable to draw/shoot weapons in some areas or placing enemies who are incredibly difficult (possible, just very frustrating) to kill
   [*]Poorly optimised, can't get good performance on a middling power PC without sacrificing resolution
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Far from perfect but very enjoyable nonetheless, I'd recommend picking it up whilst it's on sale - I personally would struggle to justify paying full price, especially with a paid DLC coming soon. But that might just be me being cheap.

I would say that this is a spiritual successor to Deus Ex. It feels more BladeRunner like. You're able to visit people's memories in the form of VR memories. The problem is that it's all main mission type of stuff... There's no point where you ever actually do that on your own, and experience these sorts of things without it being a main mission sort of thing. So each time it shows up... it's pretty much highly scripted.

Speaking of which... there is way too much dialogue in this game. Just skipping every conversation takes forever... It takes as long as any other game's movie clip... JUST TO SKIP. So... basically... try to think of this as a genuine attempt to replicate a real person's life. The play by play of it.

I don't know... personally... I get bored with most  of the characters. I beat the game... and I didn't get much story except that I evidently contracted a second personality, I had sex with a really cool prostitute who was specifically programmed with my brain scan. And I guess I live in a satellite or sometimes.

I just interpreted skipping the conversations as the main character being a psychopath and running on his own AI. Whatever personal information the world knew about him, it was just the AI doing it's work. He's just there to get his next kill. 

Crazy weird game.

I generally didn't find leveling up all that interesting. It'd be cool to see people borrow from Deus Ex and Breath of the Wild in order to reduce the number of menus you need to be familiar with. Sometimes complexity can come from a simplistic presentation, is all I'm saying.  

It's also rather easy to level up in this game. 

There's some BGS style hacking game play. Instead of knocking on a door or something, you can hack into their brain via blue tooth, basically, and blow out their optics, so you can run by or creep up on them for the attack. You can also hack a washing machine to distract guards and such.

The launch of Cyberpunk 2077 was, of course, disastrous and I probably would've never came back to this game if I experienced it at its earliest stage. I started playing about six months after release, and though the game was still rough around the edges, it was playable and mostly enjoyable.

One big problem I had going in was understanding all the language within the game, and deciphering the plot. I felt a lot of things were just skimmed over and there wasn't a lot of explaining. I was extremely confused about how Alt came to be an AI and what Mikoshi was, for example. I think the writers could've done a better job at explaining what all this stuff is and what it means because you can't just expect me to go into the game and understand. I had to do a lot of researching for it to make sense.

At times, the game is very cringy with its dialogue choices and tone of voice, but that's a minor issue for me and I've kind of gotten used to it over time. I also would've loved to see all the romance candidates be open to all of V's gender options. I don't appreciate the game not letting you choose your own pronouns and I think there should have been an option for they/them terms.

I do have ideas that I think would make the game better, but I do enjoy it very much. I love the array of combat approaches and all the different pieces of cyberware we can install. I appreciate the options for stealth and I think the game does a pretty okay job with it. Quickhacks are so cool, along with the ability to gain access to cameras and drop enemies through their perspectives. I also love how many minor stories there are if you pay close enough attention. The gigs in particular have some amazing plots you may have missed if you're not very detail-oriented. 

Overall, I would recommend the game in this stage of development because I experience very little problems when it comes to crashes and bugs. I'll get the occasional texture distortion here and there, but I think the developers have done a great job at fixing the game and living up to many promises made by the marketing team. With the release of Edgerunners, this game got a second chance and I think it was well-deserved. Thank you to everyone who worked so hard on this game!

Just finished my first playthrough, which took 56 hours. I didn't 100% the game but I was pretty close, so I think I've seen almost everything the game has to offer which means I can now review it. I had great fun, I really enjoyed playing as a stealthy netrunner with suppressed weapons and lots of quickhacks. I felt the Fixer Gigs were a bit repetitive and that there were A LOT of them, but it stopped just short of being too many. I didn't care for the street racing side quests because the physics of driving in this game are quite realistic and well done, which means it can be challenging to drive with stability at high speeds, meaning I found the racing side quests very frustrating. I liked the character levelling system and the variety of perks and upgrades available to your character. I found the characters to be well-written and I got genuinely attached to some of them throughout the course of the game. I found it interesting that the game eventually takes on the aspect of the doomed protagonist like, for example, RDR2 does with Arthur Morgan. The difference is that Arthur learns of his doom late into the game when you're well-acquainted and attached to him. On the other hand, V's imminent doom is revealed to you quite early into the game (at least, in my opinion) which meant it didn't strike me nearly as hard as if the big twist were done later into the game at which time I would have grown attached to them. So I think this aspect of the story could have been done better by putting off the big plot twist until further into the storyline (e.g. a week or two after the Arasaka heist instead of immediately after). In any case, I thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough and opted for The Sun ending as I felt this was the most fitting conclusion for V's with the personality that I played them as. 

If I had to give this game a score of 0-10, I would give it a 7.5 and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPG/FPS hybrids. If I had to describe it in a quick way, it's like if Grand Theft Auto and Watch Dogs had a baby. If you liked those games, give Cyberpunk a try!

The game is objectively good, not perfect but way more enjoyable than many others:

+ Incredible world building
+ Good variety in approaches to missions and playstyles
+ Compelling storytelling and believable characters
+ Enjoyable combat with many build options
+ Good music in all situations (combat especially)

- Rushed and still unpolished even after the 1.61
- Missing core features like shooting while driving
- Driving experience is subpar at best
- Laughable police spawns that basically spawn beside you
- Too many book with 0 purpose
- Level cap at 50 doesn't allow you to max all skills and attributes
- Too many NCPD scanner activities, really took around 20 hours to do them all

Do i recommend this?
Yes, even after this you can feel the love poured in the project and it ends up creating an engaging content full worth the price when in discount.

I'm not one to pick up, play and finish games, I've probably got the final achievement for about 10% of my steam library, but I fell in love with the world, characters, atmosphere, and feelings. Played it straight through. Night City is a fun world to play in. The most visually impressive game I've played to date. Combat is fun (if a bit simple) at a baseline, but falls off with low lategame enemy variety. It's really easy to skip fast travel, put on the radio, and take in the sights of the game while driving around to some synthwave. 

There's a big gap in quality between the endings, but I can't go into it without spoilers. One (and a half) is a tearjerker and shows massive character growth and emotional impact, and the others all feel immature, cursed, or half thought out. Not all paths through the game are even close to equal.

Cyberpunk 2077 is without a doubt one of the best games i have played. From a writing perspective, this game is phenomenal. Cyberpunk managed to truly hook me and never let go. but that does not mean this game has no flaws. but they are few so lets get them outta the way first.

con 1: yes there are still bugs in this game. for example things not rendering, stiff animations and animations failures (such as mouths not moving when people speak), things floating in mid air. But its not really something that will take you out of the game. i have a pretty mediocre PC yet the bugs were not game breaking at all.

con 2: the streets feel empty and lifeless

now onto the pros.

pro 1: the story is absolutely amazing. throughout your entire run the main story never feels like its getting too slow, or tedious. And you get so immersed you can get lost on hours on end. And the side quest are the real icing on the cake. if you are going to play this game, do the side quest you want to finish first. like finish quest relating to some characters, make a romance story, pay off your debts, things like that. cus they will impact the way the story goes. and it will greatly enhance it as well.

pro 2: the characters. They are probably one of the most well written characters i have seen in media for quite some time. and not just V and Johnny. Even side characters like Judy feel so real its almost you personally know them. Like they are there with you. i know, sounds cheezy but its true. i cannot stress how much i appreciate the character development in this game. they feel so human, and your mood will genuinely change for the better when that one character calls. (for me, that character was Judy)

pro 3: the gameplay feels nice. The gunplay feels real and the guns pack a punch with every bullet fired. the cars feel alright, personally i like motorcycles the most, and the cyberwear weapons, such as mantis claws and the projectile system feel powerful.

pro 4: visuals are amazing. sure you might need high end computers to get the full spectacle of it, but even at a low end pc i still could really appreciate it.

now rapid fire.

pro 4: secrets all over the game that can change everything or nothing

pro 5: the bosses feel (mostly) great

pro 6: the world all around is very good. even tho its not dwelled too much upon

pro 7. most iconic weapons actually feel iconic

pro 8: the ending (at least the one i got) was just amazing, and i wont shake that feeling away anytime soon.


all in all, Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that i highly recommend to anybody who wants to dive into a amazing story and let yourself experience a true master class in writing.

It's been a long time since I've had this much immersion and fun in a game. The world really feels full of life, the immersion is so good you really feel part of the world you're roaming around in. The characters you meet are full of personality and I really like the diversity of personalities you come across (Johnny the most of course). The guns feel satisfying, the hacking is good, you make so many choices and go through life however you want to whether it be good, bad, sneaky, full force, hacking, whatever you want. There's hidden paths in missions that can decide fates, the swords feel really good, and I feel like the game is pretty balanced in challenge . I really adore this game. It quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. If you're thinking about it, this is your sign. Get it!

Also for good measure, the side job "A Like Supreme" is probably the coolest I've ever felt in a video game.
