Fun game, good story and fun gameplay mechanics. only complaint is that it crashes a lot for me when trying to open it (for reference I am playing this on a Surface Pro 9). Other than that it is a fun RPG experience I recommend.

So I will give an overview of the game. WARNING SPOILER ALERT IMCOMING!

First boot impressions: 
---------------------------------
Great character customization options
Freedom to design your character 1000%
3 starter options
Unfortunate that character gender plays a role in the romancing of said NPCs (which isn't found out until post character creation)
Great Graphics

Now we talk about play through!
------------------------------------------
Once you figure out what gender/parts your character has you hit the start button and are immediately thrown into an engagement with a character. This could change based on starting choice! The fact that you can fully customize your character and pick your parts you have allows for a really fun time in getting to design a character that best immerses you into the universe of Cyberpunk. The only problem is forced censorship post character creation. This game is rated M for mature. And no one under the age of 17 can purchase the game. With that being said, it is horrid the amount of forced censorship goes on not only in the game itself if you try to go full nude but in the romancing scenes. It's like you spend so much time caring for this petty censorship on a game a minor shouldn't be playing anyways. If parents are buying this game for their children they know full damn well what they are doing. It isn't up for someone else to water down the content and experience of the game and the universe because some parents lack the ability to understand what this game entails. Moving on, not only is the game so free of character customization but that character is already destined and prewritten to romance only one npc on each end. I dig the representation of a heterosexual (Panam)  or a lesbian woman (Judy). But I never for one moment though that sexuality would have to be designed to please every singular sexual orientation. In a time where sexual orientation would perhaps be more "free spirited" in the sense that people love who they love. And that relatively decays the experience to the game. In a game where I thought the freedom of choosing who you are and representing that in a universe as vast as CP, you would think that forcing limitations would still be necessary. And for what? To appease some grown ass adult with fragile heteronormative views? Like the world of cyberpunk is no stranger to being future based. So why are we still holding onto archaic traditional sexual orientations. Why not design the game fully free of said limitations. You are hard limited on the decisions you can make and the many paths they provide in the game or not many at all. The first ending I got I signed the contract and was sent off to become a preserved consciousness. But if that is the direct main ending or the one that most will get when trying to see just how far the Arasaka stuff goes, why is it that there isn't any plans to further expand on that. Like jump years from like 2077 to a more futuristic time period that you get revived back into a compatible body? I would expect a continuation in that sense is definitely much more interesting than that where you just go into basically a sleep stasis, only, your consciousness was constructed inside a data shard to preserve your life. Refusing the contract you go home, and like the Hellman guy says, you die. 

The game is amazing. The universe is amazing and very creative. But it puts so many restrictions on you from decision making to also needing to do a bunch of side gigs and jobs to be able to unlock weapons, cars, cyberware OS, etc. These are pretty boring and do kind of take a direct impact on player experience. I really enjoyed the anime for what it was but the ending again. Not everything has to be so dire, so tragic. I implore you to not get the game if you're thinking a good happy ending exists it doesn't. You die every time, in some way shape or form. There isn't much you can do to prevent it. It's like being handed a lego kit being told you can build anything but if you don't build what makes everyone happy then it was a waste of money from them to buy you the lego kit. 

I will say that the characters were really well done, the radio stations are superb. The only reason I'm down voting is to save other people time and energy. You will probably be better off buying the game on sale. Full price isn't worth. And if their 1.7 DLC is already as they teased. It's seemingly just adding another character to the mix. We have no clue if playable or just another NPC. I am telling it for what it is. The decision is yours to make. It's really great on the combat, really good on the story content (as long as you go in with very pessimistic mindsets). I await the day a game company puts out a title that fully understands that it's okay to push boundaries of creativity. Take out the forced paths bullcrap and censorship. Our paths in these types of games should be our own. 

Other than that this is my review. Take it as you will. 

TLDR; Game sets the illusion of freedom of choice but you really don't have it. And forced censorship. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

TLDR; A surprisingly engrossing narrative with spectacular world-building and game play systems. Seems like a completely different game than what early reviews had described. 17 hours in and not a single bug.

I had been following Cyberpunk 2077 since CD Projekt Red announced a new IP in the works. As a huge fan or the Witcher 3, I was sure this game was going to be incredible. Then it launched, and like many people I was put off by the reviews and the fact that early adopters claimed it was riddled with game-breaking bugs. Then things only got worse and CD Projekt red offered refunds to anyone who purchased it. I lost interest completely. 

Then, I watched Netflix's Cyberpunk Edgerunners and was so intrigued by the spectacular world building that I decided to come back and check the current state of the game. Many patches were provided since launch and most claim that the game had become completely bug free as of version 1.52. I was fortunate enough to get this on sale, but having played it I can honestly say that it's worth paying pull-price for.

Aside from world-building, the game has a great narrative and interesting side characters. Johnny Silverhand (Keanu Reeves) is a bit flat and stiff but that's a tiny complaint all things considered. The gameplay systems are incredible and rewards picking a certain style and sticking to it. That said, it's also forgiving enough to allow you to re-spec anytime from the main menu. 

I have yet to complete it, but the main story is not too long I believe. I've been so distracted by Night City and everything that it has to offer. From my perspective this is one of those rare games that's as long as you want it to be. Rush the story and have amazing 20-something hours of fun or explore every little detail and side quest that the world has to offer.

Honestly regret not picking this up sooner but now might be the best time to get into Cyberpunk 2077.

It's definitely playable, and pretty fun so far. 

However, there are still a few minor problems, like audio glitching out and not playing properly or animations bugging out randomly. The game is absolutely gorgeous. There's an insane amount of things to see and do. Lots of Easter eggs all over the place, throwbacks and references to fan-favorite games left and right. The combat is fresh and satisfying, and the cybernetic augmentations add a level of real time strategy into gunfights. The story line (I haven't finished the game yet) is interesting and deep, with player choice driving in game events and character development. Voice acting is great, with a few exceptions. The only real demerit on the game's record are the glitches. There are glitches all over the place, from characters walking through walls, objects floating in space, and scripted events clearly going off the rails. It breaks immersion to be sure, but doesn't ruin the experience. Overall I've thoroughly enjoyed the game, and will definitely see it through to the end of my first playthrough, if not more.

When asked to tell the difference between ideas and prose, Jack Kerouac said "Ideas are a dime a dozen". There were some really good ideas here, a lot of em.

If you really want it, get it on sale. It's "playable" (PC), but I wouldn't call it good*. 

Actually, kinda feel like I overpaid at 50% off, but, eh. I did finish it without feeling like I needed to just rush through the main story to get to the end (*cough* Witcher 2 *cough*), maybe more out of curiosity than anything. There were enough good bits sprinkled throughout that kept me thinking it would get good eventually, but really, they just seemed to highlight how weak the rest of it was.

Maybe it doesn't help that I really wanted an option to flatline Silverhand about 2 minutes in, and the writing, even though you get dialogue options to tell him to fuck off, keeps pushing you to have a deep and meaningful connection with a person you can't stand to be around. He even gets really whiny about "why don't you like me" eventually. Absolutely pathetic. [spoiler] I took "that" ending, and they still forced a 'deep meaningful connection' moment when I just wanted to tell him to fuck off and go away. It completely ruined the only viable ending for me. [/spoiler]

*The problem isn't just that there's still 'bugs', but that the execution of the world, story, voice direction, pretty much everything, is just sub-par overall. It's like they made a game because they had to make a game, not because they wanted to. I was hoping that the reviews saying the new updates made it worthwhile were right, but I think this thing was just cursed from the start, kind of a "you can't fix stupid" thing. The only thing that would really save this mess is to start over and do it right this time.

In my however many hours, I have done everything I could to get stuck and suffer the bugs of a game even masterfully designed and play-tested.

I got stuck twice (merely had to re-load 5 minute old auto-saves). And all the bugs I have encountered were purely visual.

This game now lives up to 90 - 95% of my expectations before it came out and story-wise, often exceeds my expectations, I now think it to be one of the best games I've ever played. Takemura so far is my favorite character and one of my favorites in any game or even movie that I've seen, this game is just phenomenal theatre and everything I want it to be good at, it does wonderfully. The animation is masterful, the voice acting is masterful, the sense of scale is easy to underestimate if you've played R* games like GTA or RDR, I love the writing, I love the feelings and sounds and experiences this game gives me, I have only surface level complaints and for a game this massive, that really does speak for itself.

Easily recommend to anyone 16+ and especially to anyone who likes good, unique stories. I'm still on my first playthrough as a "street kid" and the dialogue I've been having, again with Takemura especially, has just been so above and beyond what I have come to expect of open-world games. Maybe the best story in any game I've ever played and I have some other games that I really, deeply love, so to say that so easily ought to speak for this game well.

Only genuine complaints are: I wish there was more weapon variety and I wish there was more vehicle variety, or if that is not possible for performance reasons, then at least customization of one's own personal vehicle should have been included.

I look forward to when they figure out how to get Delamaine working as your personal chauffeur, I absolutely adore just soaking in the city as it passes by, such a gorgeous environment, I feel bad every time I think about how rough the launch was and that I partook in mocking this now masterpiece of storytelling and game design. Will minor bugs still spoil the immersion? Sure. But if you can overlook them, something which hastily becomes easy, you will have one of the best experiences of your lifetime. I cannot speak for the other two playthroughs, but the contrasts of grit and hardship at the start versus the inconceivable wealth and luxury that surrounds you during your missions more and more as you progress and even during the initial heist, the drawing of attention to and obsession with nuance is worth every moment spent in-game and worth every penny.

I bought this on discount but had I known how good this was, I would have paid $90 for this game and felt no regret.

The word "epic" exists for stories like this, and I say that as a space-horror and ancient mythology fan. Mechanically, top 10% of games ever made, story-wise, top 1% of media ever made. From twisted, gritty, stomach-churning, to expansive benevolence and exploration of the wonder that it can be and should be to be human. Stupefying grandeur executed marvelously, I haven't enjoyed a story this much since I was an adolescent exploring Fallout 3, a game which I harped on about as being my favorite story and game for years, even though I preferred Skyrim's world more.

My enjoyment of this game is like the feeling I had exploring Fallout 3 as a youngling with a world 15 - 20 times more pleasing, satisfying and in-depth in every sense than Skyrim. If you can run this game and know about it, you'd be an idiot to not buy it and play it at least once through. 

If it had no bugs, more gun variety and vehicle customization, easiest 10 out of 10 rating I'd ever give, for now its a 9.6 - 9.7, though before I end my spewing of admiration: when story cutscenes occur, at times, it is a 30 out of 10. Introspective, philosophical, meaningful dialogue like this comes once in a lifetime...AND ITS NEVER WHEN I EXPECT. Takemura alone, 10 out of 10, I'd replay just to hear his dialogue again. Frustratingly good game, only because its difficult to condense into words how f***ing good it is at times. A *lot* of the time. You will have days where all you are thinking about is: "What happens next?" Or you are thinking about the dialogue you heard the day before, it really is that good.

I tried this game out when it first released, and was disappointed. Recently, I watched Edgerunners and was convinced to give it another shot, and I'm glad I did. The game is absolutely wonderful. I try to walk on foot to every objective, just so I can look at the scenery and explore every area. The guns and weapons feel good to use (especially katanas) and the hacking is fun and feels rewarding.

My favorite part of the game has got to be the side content. The gigs and side quests so far have all been super fun and rewarding with loot and good pay. There are so many ways to approach a combat situation, whether it be stealth and hacking, guns blazing, or both. The game's loaded with references to other sci fi media and it's sick. The main quest is riveting so far and I feel invested. The sheer amount of clothing and body mods is almost overwhelming. I have encountered a few small bethesda-like bugs, but nothing major.

That being said, the game isn't perfect. Crowds feel kinda lifeless, there's no 3rd person mode, and the specs are pretty demanding. I play capped at 60 frames with an i7 9700 and an 8GB 2060 Super, and still get frame drops to 40ish frames in some areas. However, I absolutely love this game and everyone should definitely give it another chance :-)
As of release 1.6, it's working fine and feels like a complete game. The crafting is still a bit uninspired, but all in all it's worth the buy when on sale

The Good: the world of Cyberpunk is engaging, the lore is thought provoking. You can get lost in just walking around. This includes the story.

Bugs are mostly gone and many short comings can easily be fixed with mods.

The Bad: It doesn't matter what you use, controller or Kb/M. The controls aren't intuitive. Almost feels like you need a hybrid controller. 

The games not balanced at all. If you focus heavily into any of the trees you become a God at around level 20. The level cap is 50. combat, bosses, etc becomes boring even if the enemy is stronger than you because you will probably have a solution to whatever situation. The largest offender of this is Stealth and Non-lethal damage, which doesn't have any resistance and in many cases instantly knocks out it's target. Allowing you to enter a room with a cyberpsycho, snap your fingers and have them pass out without ever seeing them attack. 

Overall, games fun and with each patch and update it gets better.

Never had much interest in Cyberpunk, just wasn't my thing. That changed when I had a friend, who rarely recommends anything, recommend Cyberpunk: Edgerunners, the show on Netflix. Show was incredible and immediately ignited a desire to explore the Cyberpunk universe more. Bought this game, and since then it's been everything I've hoped and more.

The game is hard to play, not difficulty wise, mechanics, or bugs, but due to the content. It mirrors a lot of real life and is a real blow to the gut. It'll wind you, and make you sit there lost in thought for periods of time. Other times it's all wide grins and joyous laughter. Honestly? I think this is the most varied and engaging game I've played in quite some time... possibly ever. This game gets high praise from me. It's absolutely worth giving a try, and I don't think you'll be disappointed. Replay value is very high, storyline is great, and pretty much all around hits the mark across the board. Don't talk yourself out of giving this a go. It is worth it.

Excited to see what else comes out from CDProjektRed in this regard, and definitely going to have to track down some folks to play the TTRPG with now.

2 years after this game was released, at the time of this writing, Cyberpunk 2077 is in great shape: there're no game breaking bugs and there's a compelling story to follow. In some ways, this game reminds me of Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines: has a great city to be explored, a very interesting world to dive in, great characters and convincing relationships. And very much like Vampire, I feel this game has the DNA to become a cult classic. 
It falls a bit short when it comes to character class/build variety when compared to Vampire, but it delivers very well its first person combat. Guns are fun to shoot and melee weapons are great too, just don't expect as much variety as say Borderlands for example.

Important characters all have story lines that are nice to unveil (quest-by-quest), even though most of them don't feature meaningful choices that would alter their stories. There're some funny pop culture references here and there waiting to be found, and also all sorts of cyberpunk dystopian tropes. The writing is great, not up to Witcher 3 (imho) but still great. That said, don't expect to be guns blazing action heroing all the time, this is an RPG after all, and there're many moments where it asks you to sit down and listen to what characters have to say. Take your time to smell the roses. 

You can expect about 30h of gameplay if you're mostly focused on the main quest. Which is what I did, then I went back for side quests, and played for another 30h at this point, and the side content is not near the end. There's a lot of content in Night City, and I find a lot of value in how it delivers this content, as small (quest) chunks. It gives you this feeling of progression even if you have only 30min to play.

Despite its awful release, Cyberpunk 2077 now deserves another chance.

TLDR: Overall great game with a few flaws, definitely worth picking up.

Good:
-Story/worldbuilding. You can nitpick any RPG narrative philosophically but this is about as good as it gets. 
-Contrary to memes on the Internet, conversations often have branching paths that lead to different dialog and different results. I enjoyed going back and replaying some conversations to see all the options.
-Visuals. World is highly detailed with varying indoor and outdoor environments. lots of color, lots of mood setting. Very pleasant game just to stroll through looking for trouble.
-Environments. Lots of parkour which is surprisingly smooth most of the time. Also lots of empty open desert to burn rubber in outside the city.
-Mission paths. Multiple ways to approach most missions that reward different playstyles.
-Witcher-esque sidequests. every sidequest has a mini-narrative, usually told through documents, and those narratives often play off of the main story. Sidequests fall into a few categories so there isn't endless variability, but the differing environments and multiple approaches keep it interesting.
-Build variety. Lots of viable character builds and all core stats unlock special dialog options and mission paths at different points. Cyberware system lets you add lots of interesting abilities and focus on your preferred playstyle.
-Great audio engineering. The city is a cacophony of music, advertising, and human conversation. The badlands are silent and windswept. Pacifica is Pacifica.

Bad:
-Still crashes too often for a AAA game.
-Occasional bugs-- enemies failing to aggro, getting stuck in a vehicle, etc.
-Some sloppy details in places. Blood stains that float and have a shadow, all motorcycle horns being the same sound, repetitive radio news broadcasts are unskippable and broadcast simultaneously on all channels.
-Some things seem ripe for further development. Many cool cars, but not much to do with them aside from 4 scripted races that aren't very challenging. You can get O2 boosters for swimming but you pretty much never swim and the underwater environments are the same endless texture.
-Some important systems are never explained. The outfit vs. equipment thing confused me for a long time, and I didn't discover the Upgrade section of crafting until the late game.
-Hacking is fun but ultimately so powerful that it removes the challenge, even on Hard difficulty. Some nerfs like putting a cap or timer on friendly devices would be useful, or having enemy netrunners counter-hack things like turrets and cameras that you have neutralized or overload explosive devices just like you can.
-Enemy AI stinks overall.

All in all, it's fortunate that I waited to pick up this game as I feel like it's a much more finished product now than at launch, and very enjoyable in spite of its flaws.

I was really hesitant about buying this game due to the bad release that it had, but I decided to take a shot and finally try it out, and boy was that a good decision, I have been lost in this game for days on end, completely immersed in it's story and gameplay. This is a really good looking game, it's massive and filled with lots of detail everywhere, the soundtrack and audio in general is great. Of course, there are bugs, a lot of bugs, but for me, they were all mostly visual bugs, and the only thing harmed, was immersion. In the 48 hours I've played so far, I have not had a single crash at all, or any game breaking bugs, and for me that's the most important part.

Like so many others, I watched the cyberpunk edgerunners anime and really enjoyed it (you should watch it too!). I saw the game was on sale, so I figured 'why not?'
There's a solid 60 hours of game here, if not more. So if you can score the game during a decent sale you can hit the entirely-arbitrary '$1 per hour' critereon.
If you're looking for games with good characters and story (e.g. Witcher, Mass Effect) with a healthy splash of GTA then pick this up on sale. There's a really good game under here if you can look past the occasional Bethesda-style bug.

On the positive side, the story and world-building are top-notch, arguably the best I've seen in recent memory. The game successfully manages to walk the line between crafting a deep and carefully considered linear story while still allowing that all-important feeling of self expression with choices. Nothing felt 'forced' in that regard. They did an excellent job on the characters, I really can't overstate this. There's so many little moments of characterisation, and everyone feels fleshed out and real. I'm reminded of Mass Effect here.
The only problem I noticed was that your relationship with Johnny can sometimes whiplash pretty hard between the main story and side plots. One second you can be screaming at him to get out of your head, then the next your character casually asks for his thoughts during a side mission or something. The first time this happened was within the first five minutes of Act I, so there's really no excuse for it.
The gunplay is fun. This game has some of the best feeling guns ever. Heavy hitters like sniper rifles and precision rifles fire huge bullets and damn you can really feel it. I didn't touch melee combat outside of bare knuckle boxing, but the hand-to-hand was interesting enough to keep my attention through the boxing side quest. I really enjoyed the stealth aspect even though it was nothing fancy by itself, but hacking gives you some interesting tools to spice up both stealth and combat.
Graphically speaking the game looks great, there's no denying that.

It's no surprise that the main drawback is the bugs and roughness around the edges. It's been two years since release and it STILL feels like it was rushed. Most bugs or missing features are pretty minor, but they all add up. There are some quite frankly obvious issues that really have no excuse for still existing at this point. As an example, there's only one 'animation' for getting out of your car, so even if you're going 200mph when you exit you just open the door, step out and immediately snap to the ground, completely stationary. The fact that this is still in the game at this point is mind-blowing. Another issue being that most objects are strangely difficult to select - sometimes you have to look not-quite-at something to get the prompt to interact with it, etc. Of course, there's also the classic janky 'vibrating car' that can happen if your car happens to spawn inside something when you call it. I also saw a couple of NPCs T-pose very briefly. Be prepared for Bethesda-level jank.
Some other annoyances include the inability to put scopes or silencers on some weapons, for no particular reason, it seems. Also, some of the cyberware modifications you can buy are just... boring (or at least weren't relevant to my character). There are interesting parts to be found though, so keep looking. A lot of the perks and weapon mods also suffer from this - there are many that are just a small percentage boost, which is the opposite of interesting.

Overall though, the positives far outweigh the negatives (which are mostly just me nitpicking). I bought it at 50% off and would happily buy it for that again.

At the time of writing I've played a decent amount..saw the show and decided to pull the trigger on purchasing the game as I had read that almost all of the bugs were removed... from my perspective here's what I can say:

The lore in the game is amazing, just like the show.
The game is still full of bugs. I've seen enemies just not do anything, at all, its weird. I've seen just random shit that.. honestly is kind of annoying.. would I recommend the game? to someone who loves the cyberpunk genre and saw the show, sure.. just be advised, this whole narrative of "cyberpunk is now bug free" is one hell of an overstatement IMO.

The art, the design, the fun game play are what really keeps me coming back to this game. Its basically a futuristic bladerunner GTA. The world and lore is enriching and pulls you in, its a cautionary tale to society today and the influence of corporate. The constant juxtaposition of nature and faith with AI and robotics is a really intriguing concept. The details in the city are endless and fun to explore. The character design and ability to customise is super fun like an rpg you can change your character completely to suit any style. The influence of Japanese aesthetics really just makes this game so beautiful and different. As an anime lover I am fulfilled in every way possible - plus the actual anime on netflix was really good. 

But more than all that, this game is just so fun. The ability to customise, use different type of battle tactics (cyberware etc), parkour through the streets, drive a variety of vehicles. You can stop this game for a year and just come back when you want to shoot something, its just one of those games. 

I bought this on presale and played on release. It came out during covid lockdown and although this game was far from perfect then, it was my only release from a daily struggle of emotional stress and loneliness from being a healthcare worker in the worst of COVID19. It will always have a special place in my heart. I have replayed this three times each with different backgrounds (corpo, streetkid, nomad). 

My only wish for possible patches in future is that in the harder difficulties they make enemies be smarter rather than just inflicting higher damage. AI with the ability to learn patterns and interpret what your character could do next would be challenging and exciting. 

This game is my guilty pleasure. I look forward to seeing what the devs do with the DLCs.

So far I'm loving the game.

It's got its quirks and small bugs, but nothing unusual for such a massive open world game. Skyrim had more game breaking bugs and no one put it on a spike.

The theme of the game is beautiful. The attention to detail is wonderful. There are tons of little secrets to find, lots of random activities to do like random gang shootouts while you're exploring. The gunplay is just good enough to give you a sense that it's a shooter, but not over the top to make it frustrating, at least not on Normal difficulty which is all I'm playing on.

One minor downside I've noticed is that there is no penalty for stealing. Not a big deal, just means lots of free loot that I was going to steal anyways, so I guess it's a net-neutral feature because I do enjoy swag and not having to tediously pick it up.

I recommend this game to anyone that likes open world adventure games. It brings me back to the PS2/PS3 days which were filled with city games like GTA, Saints Row, Infamous, etc. If you like exploration and RPG character stat development you'll be right at home.

As a bonus, there are mods too, but I am currently not using any and still having a good time.

Oh gosh, I've played for 261 hours so I guess I should write a review. 

This game is absolutely beautiful. The story is engaging and compelling, the voice acting is top notch, the graphics are stunning, the lighting especially is just amazing. I can lose myself for hours running around in this futuristic world. 

The art design is some of the best I've ever seen in a video game. There are a lot of different areas and they look very different. 

There are a lot of different ways to play the game. Like crafting? Tons of that and a logical progression. Game too easy? Turn it up a notch mid-play. Like guns? Go for it. Like melee? Go for it. Stealth? Go for it. NetHacking? We've got that, too. Or mix it up and make your character good at lots of stuff. Because you can change the difficult you can get wild and crazy and make a jack of all trades, pick specific things, or just randomly pick things that suit you in the moment. I think this one of the best parts about this game. The one thing I miss though is being able to respec your ability points in addition to your perks. Because of the higher perks you can really hinder yourself if you were going for something and didn't pay attention to how many points you had left. 

But I wholeheartedly recommend this game. The team has done a tremendous job fixing the problems of the past, and the game runs smoothly and beautifully and gives me a gift: The ability to live in another world and be totally immersed in story, location, my character, and my situation. Hats off to the artists, developers, actors and everyone else involved in this amazing work of art. You have my thanks.

To understand my review you must first understand what a great game to me is..
A good game has emotion, story, visuals sure.. But a great game gives you the ability to experience all of those things for the first time in a new setting with a fresh unexpected mindset ready to be blown away. Experiencing feelings, euphorias, emotions throughout the game that are so familiar but so different at the same time. These games are rare!

Going into cyberpunk blind with no spoilers or really any idea of what the game is, gave me the best introduction to the game.

Cyberpunk 2077 is truly a action, adventure, RPG. Left me with a wow factor after 50hrs of gameplay time. Still excited to get home from work and see the story develop more.

Graphics are amazing 9.5/10
Talents and abilities are amazing 10/10
Story and character development is perfect 10/10
Quests and gameplay are immersive and keep you busy. 10/10
Side quest NPC background is just as immersive as the main story.
The full control over players decisions play a great roll in all of this. One of the best free-will gameplay scenarios I’ve ever seen. You actually grow relationships (good or bad) with these characters with an ever devolving backstory to each one. You feel every emotion you should to the characters. Every action you make plays a big roll in the long run in the constantly evolving story more than I’ve seen with any other game. Best way to describe the choice options in cyberpunk is “it’s not so much black or white choices, or A and B options all the time it goes deeper than your average rpg”.

8/10 based on what it is now, not what they promised or what people got back in 2020. 

Yes, it works now, wait for half-price sale or don't. Feels very lived in, reminds me of Just Cause 3 that way. There is plenty to do and ways to do it. The scenery is awesome. Run's great for me. It didn't take long, I was in Vortex mod manager making the game better with body and clothes mods. Tons of mods, however I did have install issues with quite a few, but it is early days for both for me and the mods. 

I did make the mistake of doing The Heist mission way too early, clear out the district before moving on. You can make easy money and get the mono-wire weapon among other things before Act 1 is done. I love the motorcycles, driving full pinned through traffic is a rush. The grind may get to you, but I started doing more gigs, on the way do NCPD and random bad dudes in the ally battles. By mixing it up you get loot and some story, so it doesn't feel so grindy. Then stop at one of many convenient Interact machines to cash in your loot. Teleporters everywhere too, sometimes it's easier to leave the car at home. Tons of crafting if you'd rather disassemble loot to make better stuff.

Projekt Red seems to have embraced the modding community. If you want to see how to make a game better, give users the tools and they will show you how for free. Workshop content would be nice but Vortex bridges that gap for now.

I greatly enjoyed the game especially after the patches.

What I Liked: Characters are well thought out and well written, the world is beautiful and interactive, the story is very good and the gameplay is engaging and fun. There are a lot of side quests, most of which are interesting. Character customization is fairly robust. The perk and leveling system has a huge amount of variety, allowing for many different playstyles. I had a lot of fun replaying multiple times and experimenting with different character builds. 

What I Disliked: I am a big fan of open world games, but I do not feel like the open world adds anything to cyberpunk 2077. Some of it feels empty or underutilized. The final boss is fairly disappointing, but did not take away from the endings. I would have liked to see more choices that have a large impact on the game, and longer prologue sequences for the 3 life paths. I would also like for there to have been an iconic DB-2  Satara, considering how many other iconic weapons are in the game.
I live in night city. This game changed so much that's a completly different experience from the first time I played on launch day.

I was not expecting much going into this game. I hate the Witcher series. But I think that might be the key to liking this game, and the root cause of all the negativity surrounding its launch.
Expectations were so insanely high from their fanatical supporters who loved their previous titles and thought this game would cure cancer. 
Spoiler, it cant.

First off, Yes, there are still game breaking bugs 2 years after its launch. But now modders have made the tools to allow you to bypass any issues that could arise.
I had a mission where a gate was suppose to open on a script. It didn't. There was even a website talking about this bug, and exactly what you needed to do to avoid it. Well, I had already triggered it, so nothing I could do but start over from the beginning right?
Nope.
Downloaded the no clip mod and just ghosted through the gate and continued the story.

Speaking of which, the story is AMAZING. The characters are fleshed out, the voice acting is on point. Characters that you thought would be minor and shallow slowly gain depth through missions until they are practically the main characters best friends.

Another downside, is the map. Let me just say this. The map is awful. Its the worst game map I have ever seen in any game, ever. I am constantly lost. I never know where I am. This is a unique feeling for me because I am ridiculously good with maps and directions. Playing this game has allowed me to empathize with people like my wife who cant make heads or tails of any map and have to rely on real time directions from google or whatever.

But seriously this game is ridiculously good. The gun play is smooth and satisfying, the story is rich, deep and very long. Its more like a novel than a game. The characters rival games like Mass Effect.

I love this game. Please try it, but go in without any expectations. This game will not change your life, but you will get WEEKS of high quality entertainment.

I have played this long enough that i believe i can confidently leave a review. First let me start off by saying that yes this game had a terrible launch, mainly due to the devs receiving death threats by parts of the community and a very pushy and demanding upper management/ investors. But they are slowly adding features that were promised during E3 which is awesome, along with a very strong and healthy modding community, this game has endless potential and replay-ability in certain aspects. And with the anime playing its role in reviving the game as well  i can confidently recommend cyberpunk to anyone interested in the game but were skeptical due to a poor release and other corporate drama if you kept up with it as closely as i did. Anyways heres my list of pros and cons 

PROS:
Outstanding story, multiple choices, endings and three story-lines.
Lots of customisation for your character to make them truly unique and mods to add to that experience.
Amazing voice acting and fun dialogue between npcs and interactable characters.
Beautiful scenery and so much to see in night city even after completing everything.

CONS:
The story is great and so is the side missions but i wish some of the missions were re occurring missions, definitely would add to the replay-ability for some players
Lack of vehicle customisation without the help of mods.
Still buggy but lots of the game breaking ones have been patched, but some still remain but most are harmless glitches
Some texture and graphical glitches in some areas and some floating objects that may or may not ruin immersion for some. 

OVERALL:
I highly recommend this game even and look forward to the future of the game, especially with the new expansion coming out for it.

The game is great..... except two things. Driving, and combat on higher difficulties. 

Driving feels absolutely atrocious and I keep having flashbacks to Ryder's commentary on CJ's driving in GTA SA. Every vehicle feels like a drunk hog and you basically have no control over a vehicle if it goes any faster than 30. I really hope they'll overhaul it when the expansion comes out. Right now, every car I've tried feels about the same, and the same goes for bikes, which for whatever reason feel more like hovercraft than bikes. It's honestly embarrassing that this game has worse driving experience than early 2000's games.

The other thing is combat... more specifically, the BUSTED difficulty scaling that makes every enemy take multiple blasts in the face with a shotgun to put down on higher difficulties. I'm not kidding. At level 10 with fully upgraded (for the level, since it's capped) shotgun you need 2 to 4 point blank chest/head shots to kill an equal level enemy. Don't get me started when the game asks you to go into a zone 20 levels beyond you and you get into a fight against mobs with thrice your level. Any stray bullet 1 taps you while you need to expend an entire backpack worth of munitions to kill a single enemy (thankfully 3 of those were clapped by NCPD, but then they decided to take a smoke break and I had to spend about 80 shotgun shells firing my Satara through the wall at the last enemy because I couldn't risk a single return shot... and all I got was like 2k eddies total from selling the 4 lvl ~33 guns and the NCPD bounty). The bullet sponge is unreal, and I'm gonna switch difficulty to the easiest because it's effin stupid to run the game entirely as stealth hacker / neck breaker. Especially early when all you have is Ping and Distract and pitiful 4 RAMs. Perks seem to do nothing at all to help you in combat this early, as you'd need like 500% dmg and not 5/10/15 and whatever other numbers you can get early. Heck I got +15% against humans and +20% shotgun dmg on torso and I've noticed exactly NO IMPROVEMENT at all. Well, at least shotguns drop enemies to the ground, unlike the rest of the guns which do their best to imitate chinese toy BB guns. Tried a gun with a silencer too. All it did was alert the whole place to me while the stealth headshot took less than 20% HP off the same level enemy. I've seen more combat realism in Fallout 4, and that's saying something.
I keep hearing that at level cap you get OP AF and 1tap any enemies and it MIGHT even be true.... but you don't play the entire game on max level, do you? Seems to me those people run into low level enemies and end up dominating everything with 1-2 shots like when you first control Johny in the Arasaka HQ flashback.. but yeah, at that point you got fully fleshed out character so it's a hard maybe.

Steam says I've been playing this game for 20 hours. I believe 16 of them were spent sneaking around breaking people's necks (as the only viable way to progress) and the rest were reloading last checkpoint and cutscenes :S
Ah well, gonna lower the difficulty as it seems there's no real incentive to play on the highest difficulty, you get nothing extra for it other than bullet spongy frustrations. At least in Fallout you get somewhat better loot for it.

If you said that this game has a GTA-style open world and Deus:ex-style cybernetics I would already think it sounded great, but there is more. 
- The hacking is really fun to play around with and if you decide to invest in that route its loads of fun in lategame. 
- The leveling system is refreshing, its nothing sensational but I like it. 
- For the first time ever (I think). I have to mention all the cool outfits, I really wish I could get my hands on these kinds of clothes irl. 
- Story is damn good too, it really feels like your choices has farther reaching effects rather than just being one of 3 doors. Loads of great characters. 

To sum it up: 
Game looks great, just great. I wish I could move to night city.

The story is captivating and I feel free to explore the world and the events however I like. 
Few games has mad me feel like all my decisions really matter.

It's a good game. It definitely still has some significant bugs (scenes fail to trigger and progress to the next scene, leaving you quite literally stuck, combat music has got stuck requiring weird workarounds (restarting the game didn't work to fix it), NPCs rapidly transforming, some items glitched into walls, not receiving rewards from certain quests, etc. but the frequent autosave feature allows you to save scum out of those glitches when they do occur while only losing a couple minutes of activity, so you can work around it at least. They definitely have no business saying they're done fixing bugs, because the bugs are still significant and do disrupt gameplay at times.

Other than that, the game itself is pretty fantastic. Shooting is solid, RPG mechanics are well balanced, story is very engaging and well written/acted. Stealth, slickness and guns blazing are all viable options in many situations. You really feel like a badass tearing people up in combat.

The biggest drawback aside from the misleading launch, is that even with the 1.6 Update, the game is still ridden with bugs. Some examples still present in the game; 

-With DLSS enabled, there are very persistent and distracting visual artifacts in the form of flashing purple lights, always somewhere on screen

-V's legs floating into the first person view while landing

-NPC's wander aimlessly, often colliding with each other which results in a comedic display of engine phsyics as their bodies twist and contort around each other

-NPC's will often phase into/out of existence, and will even walk into geometry throughout the city, things like light posts, street signs, billboards etc. It can be very immersion breaking

-Cars drive aimlessly, and I have noticed a few occasions where the cars will thrust themselves into the pavement, and continue to drive forward with only their front tires on the ground

-When selecting the option to change your appearance, the game will occasionally greet you with a blank red screen and no button prompts, forcing you to close the game manually and reload your save

The game is not perfect, but, that being said, there is a lot to enjoy with what is clearly a labor of love from CDPR. Highly recommend picking it up at a discounted price

Still has some issues that crop up, such as character models T-Posing and mesh colliders not activating, but these honestly don't happen too often. The game is still largely playable, and so far, the story has been worth it. Although it can be disappointing to have a AAA game with so many bugs even though it looks incredibly polished whilst it is operating correctly, the game does seem to have many merits that counter these issues. The inclusion of a character creation system in which a player can choose a cisgender, transgender, or intersex character is largely a plus in my book. Character creation is also rather robust, and has many classically cyberpunk styles for fans of the genre. Gameplay and story are both immersive and do their job as entertainment.
Personally, I waited for this game to go on sale when I purchased it, concerned with the issues that had plagued it in its initial release. Having played through the first couple hours of the game, completing what would seem to be the Streetkid story's initial story arc, I would say that this, even with the issues that it still seems to have, would have been worth purchasing it at a higher price-point. As I said, it isn't perfect, but it is really fun to play.

With 120 hours in so far I have encountered very few visual bugs and no crashes. CDPR have done a great job of bringing fantastic world building and in depth(while broken at points) rpg mechanics to Mike Pondsmiths cyberpunk world. While I have enjoyed my time in Night City, I feel some of the npc interactions and gang factions could have been more fleshed out. Maelstrom enemies should have a much better time tracking/spotting you. Plus more mech/cyber types to fill their ranks. Voodoo Boys should be pulling more varied nethack attacks. Not just reveal location and overheat. It would be cool if someone else had a suicide nethack for a change. Animals should be hardier in general and should have more animal looking members in the ranks ect. I have been playing on very hard difficulty and have been enjoy the challenge it brings initially but felt like there was a layer to combat that was either cut or under developed that would have been a good way to separate difficulty levels. Looking forward to my second and third playthroughs with broken sandevistan melee builds though :)


Also driving is hit or miss at times. Bikes should be way more nimble.

I've really enjoyed playing this game.  Before I get into what I liked, let's talk about hardware and what settings to run the game on.  If you are wondering if you are missing out between the Ultra setting and Ray Tracing settings, the answer is no.  If you can run it at the maxed out settings with no issues knock yourself out.  

From a technical stand point most if not all of the major game breaking bugs that made headlines seemed to be answered.  The only major thing I experienced was the game shutting down randomly, but that was my fault for not having something updated on my computer.  After an update I ceased seeing any random shutdowns.  

Story wise.  If you just go through the main quests and don't do the side missions you will miss out on a lot.  The side missions help develop the game world and what Night City is all about.  There are also some fun Easter Eggs and nods to pop culture.  

Game play, this will throw some players for a loop.   If you decide to just go charging in guns blazing you will get stomped initially.  Not saying you can't go the pure gun nut route, but you have to level into it.  The more perks you have in a skill the better bonuses you have that makes being a bullet tanking juggernaut of firepower possible.  If you played Witcher 3 you will feel right at home with the leveling and skill system.  Same with the equipment system.  Early level guns have low damage output, same gun mid game will have better stats and better damage output.

Play styles.  You can actually do stealth in this game.  It's reasonable stealth mechanics.  You don't have to do the insane planning that's required in the Hitman series.  You can also use on the fly hacking tools that supplement your covert style and in certain missions, going stealth pays out nicely.  Melee comes in some fun varieties, as long as you understand that distance is the enemy.  If you are clever with your movements you can end up catching two or more enemies in close enough proximity they are eating the same melee attack.  Gun play is pretty good.  You just need to understand there is no one gun fits all situation.  The best part is you can do a mix of these styles and your cybernetic enhancements and quick hacks can really make for some fun game play.

Biggest tip I can give without spoiling anything is grind out all the side missions you can before getting into the main missions.  It's not even a chore to grind in this game because the side missions and odd jobs are well thought out.  The rewards from the side missions also make things easier down the road.  For example I got some quick hacks out of one side mission that made it hilarious to use on more powerful enemies.  Do it right and you can chain up some hacks that can level the playing field so you are not forced to simply farm lower level foes until you level up enough.

I plan on replaying this game and I think it's worth the money.

This game is best enjoyed by those who have yet to jack into the cyberpunk fandom -- if you're familiar with all the tropes and plots, you might find this a bit of a rerun.  

I guess the best way to sum it up is it's an interactive sim in the vein of the OG Deus Ex, but with  less of the connection to real world conspiracy's you get in JC's Bizarre Adventure and maybe less of the "I'm saving the world here" feeling of the last great cyberpunk adventure of the second millennium, but with vehicles and better graphics to make up for it.

Update:
I must add that this game has very mixed vibes. It feels as if the core team of the game tried creating a super cool game with a rich story, very professionally made cutscenes and in-game renders. It's really fascinating how complicated and rich the short moments of animations and animated scenes are. 

There is also a ton of non-conventional player interactions, as well as a really vivid world that in fact feels a lot like real. This game really does a good job in presenting a futuristic city that feels alive. I never liked GTA games much, but this game has beaten GTA in many ways.

It hasn't beaten other games technically, but the design and creativity are supreme. I notice so many different and interesting patterns in the quests. The AIs, the movie/games references, the things like posters that you would pay a lot of money for in real life. It's really insane how many details you find. The paintings, the cars, the sound system. The voice-acting is on the top level. It's seriously the best voice acting I ever have seen.

Everything is really high quality, but at the same time the buggy quests, bugging dialogues and flickering objects/NPCs can really destroy all of it. One of the biggest flaws is that the game is VERY short. You will finish the couple of quests in the main story line and that's it. There are many side quests but it's nowhere close to GTA or games like Skyrim or idk, even RTS games with campaigns like C&Q.

I would really give this game a solid 8/10, but I personally hate the CEOs, who make a fucking game with the main protagonist fighting CORPS, but at the same time the said CEOs have been the same assholes to their very own employees. It's clearly visible in this game.

They forced many people to work overtime, they forced them to quit from mismanagement and stress. The talented people who made this game really special and amazing have left the studio because of them.
This is why this feels unfinished. This is why some game quests feel cut out of a bigger picture. Why does Jackie die so soon? Why is the main story so short, you find Takemura and you start working together after you just (indirectly) killed off his boss...

This is all present in the game, You see the great graphic design, great 3D models, great story and quests with interesting ideas. It's not a crap game from Ubisoft or EA. It's a game with super cool ideas, but unfinished and with technical issues.

The gameplay though is a whole new level, this is what gaming should be about.
It reminds me of the old quality games you played as child and could actually have fun with.

I hate EA, hate Ubisoft, hate all the companies which have dragged down the modern games so much that they are mostly trash and money grinders against kids or some kind of vulnerable people.

In this game you can do all the things you usually can't do in any other games. You can interact with computers, the environment, hack, watch TV, read the journals, sneak or fight melee.
It's really unusual to find so many cool mechanics in an FPS game like this.

This game is actually a really good game, but it's a bit of a mess technically, mostly.

I would fire the management team (especially for all their LIES and all their manipulation and they got paid so much for bullshitting people) and leave the programming/graphic designers/other crews. It really impresses me what they animated and how they merged all these elements so well.

GTA is over-hyped, this is a game that is much more interesting and has had way fewer people working on it. The problem is that it's too short and isn't really bug-free.

In short words - it's underrated in terms of people who have performed a great work to make it. It doesn't deserve such criticism as a game. It deserves criticism against the management of the teams.
I have played hundreds of hours between GOG and Steam. Highly recommended.

It's always been RPG for me when it comes to games, ever since I first played Morrowind. Skyrim blew my mind when it came, then Mass Effect 2 was why I bought the PS3.
Then came Witcher 3 for which I bought PS4 and is the best game I played since. No wonder I was super excited to get my hands on Cyberpunk 2077 - but I read the reviews, and only had a slim PS4, so I passed.
fast-forward 2 years later - I'm into anime these days I found Cyberpunk 2077 edge runners on Netflix, which is pretty damn awesome.
I also have a decent Gaming PC these days (12-gen i7-12700K, RTX 2080ti, 144Hz monitor), which I rarely use, the game was on sale (50% off) most recent reviews were positive (nice feature, by the way, steam!), and I read the original reviews again which always said the game was terrific on PC even in day 1.
That's more than enough to convince me - so I bought it. I'm only 12 hours into the game but listen to met - it's freaking amazing. The visuals are the best I've ever seen, the storytelling is on a level of its own (though like every RPG it has its boring parts, just hit C to skip them), and the best thing (I hope I'm not jinxing myself, fingers crossed) - not a single bug! All runs smoothly (will check on those FPS soon), and the mechanics are great (driving could be improved though).

I will update later on - but based on my experience so far its a 10/10 for me.

My absolute favourite game. I bought it at launch then waited a couple months for updates before playing. Best part of this game is definetly is it's world. Gorgeous, vibrant and full of character. The map rewards you for adventuring as lots of content can be found by just being curious and deciding to go off the usual trail. The main mission, while I wish it were longer, is an emotional roller-coaster of hope and desperation. Every character has so much personality, you become attached to many of them. Combat such as quick hacking makes fighting feel very unique. Even after you finish the game, there's lots of other cyberpunk content to chew on such as official comics, plenty of great mods and of course the incredible edgerunners anime. Character customisation is a bit limited, can't add much cyberwear to your character and you can only choose from presets instead of sliders, however that's a rather small nitpick as I really appreaciate a game with lots of customisation. And where Cyberpunk lacks in it's character customisation, it makes up for in its clothing options. Loads of interesting clothes and accessories to discover and cycle through. All in all, I've recommended this game to many people, even before it's sudden explosion in popularity, and I will continue to do so as I believe in the team behind this franchise and I am very excited to see how Phantom Liberty will turn out.

I'd say this game came along way from it's launch. I'm glade they didn't pull an EA or other gaming company tactic of instantly abandoning the game. It's not perfect, but it's in a really good place overall.

Pro's: 
- The game is absolutely beautiful if you have a rig that can run it on the highest graphics, My 3090TI actually warms up pretty badly when playing this with everything basically on Ultra but it's stunning.
- The game play is mostly fleshed out and there are few bugs that interfere with your play through.
- Bug's in general are mostly gone, I've had a few weird moments but everything is running like it's supposed too.
- The stuff they added from edgerunners is slightly heart wrenching but I love that they added it all in 2 years after the game launched. It shows the Devs from CDPR still care about this game at least some, although they cut alot of the content they were going to release, which sucks, they haven't gone full abandonment on it.
- The game is overall fun to play and mess around in, it feels a lot more alive than when it launched.

Cons: 
-I'm not sure how the game looks or runs in low quality graphics, but this game is really, REALLY, graphically intense if you want it to look the best.
- If you watched edgerunners, there are a lot of references and songs that will remind you of that story and possibly make you sad as fuck.
- There isn't as much choice as most people would want from an RPG. You have usually three or two options in every major decision, sort of like mass effects paragon system, not as bad, but it's usually go nuts on everyone, act like someone who cares/or like a baby and whine. When the third option is around, its usually considered the "rebel's" path but it's only available in a few situations. The same is about who you align with but thats more towards the end. You can get choose to have your friends help, choose to have the corps help, or go full rebel and solo it. It's not the worst, but it's also not the best in terms of options.

Overall, the game is pretty fleshed out right now, and really enjoyable. Most people came back because of edgerunners and start going full PTSD when specific songs play or you go to specific areas. I hope CDPR keeps it up and learns from their mistakes. Also, I hope they paying for Anime about edgerunners, or that the company that made the anime keeps doing cyberpunk like anime. I'd say now's a good time if you don't have it to try it out. Hopefully they do another cyberpunk but without the launch they did for this one.

After the initial disaster, after 2 years of patches... now I can say that this is my favorite game after the Mass Effect saga. 5/10 then, 9.5/10 now.

Graphics are incredible, and if you have a low end PC you can use mods to downgrade it to the max. My PC has an integrated graphic card and it runs OK... imagine that.

The dialogues are kinda childish, but the overall plot is great. It grants you much freedom. If you enjoy a story about living to fight another day, becoming a legend regardless of the outcomes, you will enjoy it. There are many different endings, and each of them have very different results.

Gameplay? Incredible. Kill. Kill. Steal. Hack. Talk. Explore. The city is HUGE with an incredible amount of things to do. Most of them are a bit repetitive, you just have to kill or steal. Sincerely, I prefer that than too many different missions. The main missions grant you enough variety of missions, if I don't have time to spend 1 hour in intricate missions I prefer just to click on the map, go there, kill, loot. The design of the city is amazing, the details, the different locations... gorgeous.

You can customize your character to the max. The appearance, the clothes, the weapons, many different abilities (hacking, mele, shooting...).

Just buy it and play it. Now.

PS: Don't watch the anime. It's gay.

[b]This review has been written by someone who didn't play at launch, bought the game with a 50% discount, and came from Edgerunners.[/b]

[h2]Pros[/h2]
 - The best thing about this game is the atmosphere; if you watched Edgerunners and wanted to immerse yourself in the world, the game's perfect for you
 - The game hits the "cyberpunk" nail on the head; the aesthetic is consistently what you'd expect and it slaps
 - Bugs are super infrequent, and the only ones I've seen haven't affected my gameplay
  -  - Default pose bug happened once near the beginning of the game, during a cutscene
  -  - Sometimes I'll get into V's car and try to drive, but V gets out for no reason
  -  - A door closed behind me and wouldn't reopen, companion stuck behind it, but he phased through it lmao
 - Graphics are really good even without a super tricked-out PC, as long as you have DLSS — I'm running a heavily CPU-bottlenecked RTX 2060, which runs ~20 frames without DLSS and 60-90 with it activated
 - I've only experienced part of the Streetkid route at the moment, but the story is coherent so far
 - KBM controls feel great, so you don't need a controller
 - The music goes hard
 - Expansive skill tree
 - Keanu
  -  - [spoiler]Playing as Silverhand is a power trip[/spoiler]

[h2]Cons[/h2]
 - Without a NASA PC, you probably won't be getting a consistent 144 FPS, if you care about that
 - It's really hard to care about any of the characters except V and Keanu
 - Up to where I am now ([spoiler]Act 2 just started; V popped his first pill and is about to leave his apartment[/spoiler]), the combat has been fairly basic and doesn't accommodate Blade builds
  -  - This will probably change as I unlock more weapons and abilities, but the fact remains that it's normal first-person shooter combat (with a bit of hacking and melee) for at least the first six hours of the game
 - Driving feels awful during the few minutes it takes to get used to the input lag and sensitivity
 - People will clown you for playing this game if you came from the anime

Biggest positive
* They got music so right, just somehow the bass in the music sounds amazing without just being thumpy, the music sets an awesome vibe for the world

Positives
* acceptably decent story
* some unique gameplay - maybe just slightly modernised deus ex
* the world is half decent, it's no grand theft auto, but it's a decent attempt
* your player can actually have genitals
* game actually looks good with HDR enabled (my retinas are burning)
* there's a decent amount of content

Negatives
* characters dont have much depth
* graphics are hard to get right if you dont have a top of the line machine
* cyberpunk elements of the game are basic - basically just a shooter / stealth game.
* guns are basic - all these crafting mechanics and basically never use it because you just find something with higher DPS. Imagine borderlands guns, but look less interesting, and the elemental effects dont matter.
* clothing is basic - mods arn't very interesting / have minimal effect
* pretty much all player skills can be ignored, they are all garbage
* whole world can feel a bit samey
* cars are shit / handling is poopoo

Biggest negative
* 75% of the game you're busy looking at the hud, not what's going on in front of you. - c'mon this is cyberpunk, could they not have made the hud part of what you see - a minimap in the top right, what is this, 2010?

This game is not without its flaws. It had many upon release. Most have been cleaned up in post-release patches but there're still a few. The world that CDPR has created here, though, has plenty of potential. Really interesting take on the semi-dystopian future of technology and massive corporations stomping on regular people.

Keanu Reeves gives a great performance as Johnny. Most of the other performances for most of the other characters are quite good too. The story is a bit of a downer, but still interesting & compelling. The gameplay is solid. Gunplay, hacking, stealth, melee weapons all feel different yet still viable.

Some of the design choices are a bit odd. The driving mechanics are subpar at best. There are some mods that can provide some QoL enhancements but it's a bit rough around the edges. If you're interested but still lukewarm on the game, wait for a sale. I still think it's worth a play for most people. I am looking forward to seeing if CDPR can flesh this world out a bit more with the next installment(s).

There are literally hundreds of thousands of reviews so my posting of this is like taking a leak into the atlantic and expecting it to raise the sea level, so i'll try to keep it brief for the few who may see this. I'll break it into 4 parts: the great, the good, the bad, and the ugly.

-The Great: The story & lore are so in depth it'll take 100 hours just to read all of the shards you find. It absolutely engulfed me into the game right off the bat. The combat is smooth like a red hot knife through the skulls of my enemies, and there are numerous builds to choose from. My first run was a full-on assault character using a sniper rifle and a revolver. Second run is a stealth build with a revolver and throwing knives. The perk trees are almost overwhelming in my opinion, it feels like almost too much to keep track of.

-The Good: Load times, for the most part. I usually don't wait a crazy long time for the game to load from the start menu but after that you rarely get load screens. The optimization is good too, my pc isn't crazy beefy but I didn't have to make it 480p quality in order to run it well, so it still looks good and usually runs at ~70-90 in areas that aren't packed with npcs

-The Bad: Glitches aren't nearly as rampant as they once were, and the ones I ran into were (mostly) not game breaking. Initially it was just t-posing characters and stuff having trouble loading in, and then there were a few game-breaking ones like getting soft locked out of completing a minor side quest, also locking me out of getting an achievement. If you somehow see this before playing the game, QUICKSAVE BEFORE EVERY SINGLE NCPD ENCOUNTER. I had like 3 on my first run say i needed to grab the item to complete it despite already grabbing it, and so i got locked out of completion. Crashing wasn't really a big deal on my first playthrough. Got to like 75 hours and it only crashed 3 times, but now i'm on my second playthrough like 10 hours in and it has already crashed like 6 times, so i guess it's not THAT bad but it's not a good thing either.

-The Ugly: Other than being soft locked out of 100%ing the game, there isn't really much that is really THIS bad. The only thing that really upset me while playing was the feeling like I was lost during most of it. Not like... in a literal sense, there's just so much fucking stuff to this game that you need to learn so I found myself looking up guides on skill trees and that god forsaken hacking minigame. Don't get me wrong, I eventually got the hang of it but the game gives you one quick tutorial while rapid firing all sorts of other info at you. I still don't exactly know what "daemons" are and I'm around 100 hours.

TL;DR: Good game, not as buggy as it once was, save before every single ncpd mini mission if you want to 100% it. Definitely recommend, especially if you are a Destiny veteran and enjoy the leveling system that Destiny had.

Don't know how it was at release but meanwhile it's a great game with excellent storytelling.

Regarding bugs: In over 130 hours saw only a handful graphic glitches like floating objects. No major issues.
Cyberpunk to this day has the most immersive story lines I have ever played.

It has a Bladerunner vibe, Area 18 of Star Citizen, similar kind of depth to it. I had no intention of getting it when it was 60, bought it half off this weekend, but I see why people would have been excited about it.

This studio is very good at story-driven gameplay. Proved it with Witcher and did it again here. Very similar next gen facial expressions where once again, every now and then in dialog the characters will emote and you will read it clearly(sometimes off timed with the automatic movement, the shuffling, which can make it a little confusing), but when it turns out right, you really will read their expressions. To a point where it's something worth paying attention to!

I'm not a big fan of the level-aspect method, especially in gun play. Where it's impossible to kill a 'higher ranked' character essentially. Despite this, the game is very good.

I did have a weird 'corrupted download' message, but if you run into this my solution was to close steam and restart, then voila, it was okay.

Another issue(I'm PC, mouse and keyboard) was the auto center while driving. Check out a nexus mod called Disable Vehicle Auto Center. You can 'remove' this issue with a simple .exe you can download there that allows you to use middle mouse to turn it on and off. The mod moves your cursor a little every half second, preventing auto center and is unnoticeable while driving. You'll get used to switching it off and on, especially once you're sick of auto center.

Overall, really cool game. A bit evil though, on the esoteric, transhumanism, lots of occultic symbolism if you know what you're looking at. Wish they could have stayed away from the 'brave new world' and just made a sci fi story. If you're with God though, none of that crap is worth a damn though.

The beginning was a disaster, for everyone else. I never had major issues, but I play on a 1070 so I wasn't expecting miracles.

I'm not blaming the Devs, I'm blaming shareholders and people who don't care about the game but only give a shit about the bottom line and making money.
When they will understand that gamers are willing to wait for a better product rather than get a half-assed rushed one earlier, it'll be too late.
The recent updates (after Edgerunners, for which we will never thank Trigger enough) brought a lot of new life to the playerbase, and consequently a massive increase in fantastic mods (truly there's tons out there).

Short Review: Yes 9/10


Long Review: the game has come a long way since launch, a lot of the major game-breaking, immersion breaking bugs are gone, the game still have bugs but they aren't as bad or noticeable as they were on launch.

Graphics:
The graphics look amazing especially maxed out with RayTracing
and the story is immersive and gripping.

Eastereggs:
There are some crazy eastereggs in this game, references to other games, such as portal
or some references or easteregg items relating to their Edgerunners Anime.

Modding:
There's also a vast rapid growing modding community, that are adding amazing custom and cut content into the game, theres some really crazy good mods which will either enhance the game experience and make it more immersive, or simply make the game extremely convenient and easy.

Edgerunners:
If you have Netflix i recommend you see the Cyberpunk Edgerunners Anime, its only 10 Episodes long and you can watch it in the span of a hour or two.
Anime is actually really good and one of the main reasons for the game's boost in activity
also many locations seen in the anime can be visited in-game.

Conclusion: if you have the money i think the game would make a great addition to your library (if your PC can handle the game that is)
if you don't have the cash simply wait for it to go onsale like it did for me as of the time of typing this review
otherwise i think it's a great game, that didn't deserve the hate it got

Note: If you got a really good PC you should try out the VR Mod for this game, its a little janky but quite immersive and will make the experience 10x more crazier.
Also
If you decide to watch Edgerunners the anime I recommend watching the english dub, it adds more flavor and only makes sense as Night City in 2077 is set in America.
(p.s you may recognize the antagonist's voice in the english dub)

I starting playing this game a month or so ago, so I didn't have to deal with the rocky launch. So this review is an objective look at the current game without all the previous drama. 

This game is a 10/10. Every single side quest feels like it has meaning. The story telling is phenomenal. Visually speaking I can't believe how large and detailed Night City is in this game. I have never, ever, played a story game a second time immediately after beating it the first time, and I did for this game. My first playthrough I went Katana/Sandevistan and on my second I went full netrunner. I'm constantly finding things I didn't see the first playthrough and it's been such an enjoyment. There's always going to be small things to nitpick, but as a whole, this game is a 10/10 in my book and the small issues I have don't take away from that. 

At first I was annoyed by the fact you can't fast travel from anywhere, but then I realized this is the only game I actually don't mind riding around in to my destination, especially because it might introduce you to something new en route.

Real Review:

POSITIVES:
Almost everything. The Writing, The Main story, the Unique Side Quest missions, the Delamain quests, that talking Smart Pistol named Skippy, Keanu Reeves, Voice acting (Just as Jackie Wells simply dying almost made me tear up). The Night City (The details and the architect of the city is superb, beautiful, and believably alive and what should other open-world games should do)
Steam Deck optimized. 
You can change Wardrobe without having to change the current stats for your Armor stats. But it's almost pointless because the game is always at First Person View. Aside from driving on motorcycle and viewing your character through mirror.

As for Bugs and Glitches, almost non-existent in the 1.6 Version:
*Aside from the Tutorial/Training mission where the Combat Bot T-posed when I attacked it. 
*That one scripted sequence where Panam follows me to tail the Wraiths to save Saul. The Panam zooms with speed when near reaching the destination. Wtf lmao.
*NPCs' animation when driving doesn't move the steering wheel when turning.
*When talking to Mr. Peralez along with Mrs. Peralez during that side mission, the audio glitched and no audio when he talks.

NEGATIVES:
I hated it when it tried to be Borderlands. Make constant micromanagements to Weapons and Wardrobe stats. Get the same-looking and same-sounding Weapon and Wardrobe (Armor) for the 5th time because it had higher DPS and Damage and had better Stats and more slots for attachments and mods. It took me 50 hours to find out that there's an Upgrade section within Crafting so it makes more sense to keep weapons longer.

STEAM DECK:
Bought STEAM DECK just for this game and it runs amazingly well for a portable PC because I don't have a gaming PC and my APU laptop runs like crap even on lowest settings. No crashes. Used my own settings for sharper quality image and for photo mode. 800p native Steam Deck screen resolution (AMD FSR Off), Medium Settings, Low Shadow Distance, High Texture and Crowd Density. Yes. There were frame drops of course down to 20-28fps when it involves rain and large crowd in Heywood, The Glen and in most vegetative areas in North Oak. Driving fast is a no issue at all. Obviously when driving to a crowded part of the city that is. 

Overall Score: 9.1/10

I played this game at launch and logged roughly 80 hours my first go round. It was a buggy mess, but the story and open world were so intriguing it kept me hooked. I ended up putting it down before completing it - I didn't want to finish the game with all of the bugs because I felt it wouldn't do it justice (and I didn't trust that the end-game experience would be satisfying with the state it was in). Now, through a series of updates and free content, I decided to re-download the game and start the game with a fresh character. Needless to say, the game is 10x more playable and I have thoroughly enjoyed getting caught back up in the world CDPR created. If you like their previous projects but held off because of the mess at launch, I think it's safe to say that there's no better time to give this game a shot. There's plenty to do - side quests, random encounters, gigs for different "fixers" in different parts of the city, and a deep main quest line. Highly recommend!
