For a quick answer. I would recommend this game others

                                      When the game came out in 2020, there were a lot of issues that was commonly spotted by streamers and other players alike that seemed to be too big of an issue to deal with if I bought the game at that time. Bugs like NPCs would ragdoll on the ground while talking in the middle of a mission, cars getting stuck under the asphalt/concrete road, side missions would not continue with the dialogue in order to finish it, etc. For quite a lot of people the game was unplayable.
                      But since then the game has been given improvements over time and has reached a new audience in 2022 with their show on Netflix; Cyberpunk Edgerunners. I highly recommend the show to many others, considering the game aside, because of how genuinely good the show it is with its variety of its cast members and how memorable they are. One of my personal favorites being David and Maine who at one point come across the same issue in the story which i will not spoil. With the release of the anime, CD Projekt Red also came out with its new update 1.16 that has major updates such as fixing the phone issue were it could constantly ring and couldnt reject the call, cars are more accessible, new weapons added, and so forth.
Of course not all games are perfect and Cyberpunk does have some small bugs like the cars being stock underground but rarely happens on occasion or the models would t-pose once or twice the entire playthrough.
                                           Frankly I really do recommend this amazing game that ive invested way too many hours in lately and I couldnt complain about the game. One ofsuggestion from the developing team is giving us the option to change the zoom settings on the map so we can see more of the map itself so we dont pass our exits when driving. Overall I love the game and im sure more people would too.

10/10

Yes, there are still occasional glitches and weird collision issues. But there is also a really solid game and it is amazing.
The gameplay is varied. Has your classic warrior/rouge/wizard type builds or play a hybrid. Stealth is very important for a few parts (especially for bonus rewards) you can face enemies in a number of interesting ways.
There are generally multiple ways of reaching your goals, depending on your build, adding to replayability and the temptation to explore and see what else is possible.
It feels like being in a real city, with distinct neighborhoods and districts. Give Night City a reskin and it could be a modern city.
Characters have believable goals and motivations. Do what they want and they'll help you out. Get in their way and they'll (try to) take you out. There aren't orcs/raiders/etc just looking to chase you down.
I care about these people and want good things for them, even when I know it's not always a possibility.
The story, in spite of a few flaws, grabs me and has interesting and rational twists and turns. The side stories are interesting and fill out the world nicely.
The endings are a gut punch. Try them all out and see the different ways things can go. Heck, the game wants you to.
So yes, I really love this game. I started playing at version 1.5, having avoided even buying it until I felt sure it would be properly updated. It's been a heck of a journey but I really like where it's ended up.

Tentative recommendation. I bought the game on sale for 50% off, and my first playthrough lasted 88 hours. That should say something. It has major issues which took me out of the experience.

Skill trees:

The highlights are the skill system. I was genuinely stumped. Most RPGs usually shoehorn you into a set of skills which are readily apparent and meant to work together to make a certain build. With Cyberpunk, you get enough skill points to max out 2 trees or get really good in 3 different trees. It allows a lot of hybrid classes. I played a stealth hacker who would rampage with a shotgun when thins went south.

Story:

The main story and the major character sidequests are quite compelling. I found those plotlines very well executed. The VA was amazing, and the NPCs oozed style and character.  They were very memorable and really made the world feel alive. The fixer sidequests - not so much. They were generic - here's a rando, go kill him. Go there, steal something without setting off the alarms. You finished all my missions, here's a legendary weapon. They were pretty boring at face value, but the actual level design was amazing. Even inconsequential missions had multiple ways to approach them.

World design:

Night city is the best in-game city ever made. It is gorgeously designed and instils an amazing sense of scale. The aesthetic is awesome. It blends high tech futurism with the dilapidated refuse of anarcho capitalism. There's literally a massive garbage pile spanning several in-game square miles. It's amazing. However, this is let down by the NPCs. They are super dumb copy-pasted mobs. They all say the same thing. There are places where NPCs are permanently stationed which gets really old really quick. It's really bad.

Loot:

Loot's super boring. You get new stuff thrown at you constantly. It's all boring blue and purple upgrades which you use for 2 missions then replace. The tech skill is pretty much mandatory if you want to keep any emotional connection to your inventory. You can't upgrade iconic items to the next rarity tier without certain skills in the Tech tree. Even then, it feels like a waste of time. You have to go around vendors to buy item components. This allows you to upgrade your iconic weapons until they are barely better than the blue and purple trash items that the game showers you with.

Bugs:

Here's where the game really lets itself down. It CDPR's credit, I only had one or two crashes in my 88 hours of gameplay. However, the game is nowhere near bug-free. It is absolutely riddled, head-to-toe, in visual and graphical glitches and bugs. Here's a very short list:

- Scripted NPC driving sequences - Car jumps around when you get in, and the NPC initiates the sequence.

- Changing your appearance with an outfit applied causes your character's "special bits" to clip through the clothing.

- Character randomly exits stealth when walking back from cover.

- Hiding a body causes a loot container to float in mid-air

- Bodies fail to ragdoll properly if the NPC dies on top of a physics object (like the thousands of trash bags you find everywhere). It causes the body to just float in mid-air.

- Infinite scrolling bug when disassembling weapons. If you scroll down and disassemble an item, it causes the UI to scroll to the top then try to scroll back to where you were. Then that repeats around 5-10 times per second. It's horrible

- Calling a fast vehicle often causes it to skid to a halt around 100 meters away from you, making you run after it to chase it down.

That's just a very VERY small number of the bugs I encountered. There were many more, and they aren't random things which happen maybe once every 5-10 hours. I was experiencing any number of bugs every 10 or so minutes. It's still a very broken game, even on PC.

Still, I give it a tentative recommendation because the good barely squeaked by to outnumber the bad.

It's been a while since the game first came out, and many people online have said how much better the game plays, so I decided to check it out. 

The game is definitely flawed, as there are a ton of noticeable glitches that take away from the game. There have been multiple times in which I would feel so immersed in the world but then suddenly something would happen that would completely break that immersion. This would include horrible cutscene animations while in cars or NPCs randomly glitching out. Also should be fair to mention how janky (think that's how you spell it) the driving is. Doesn't feel very smooth but at least it gets the job done.

But there is mostly where my gripes end. Ignoring the bugs that seem to plague the game, even after all the updates this game has been given, the experience is quite good. The game tries its best to immerse you in the corrupt and horrible world of Cyberpunk. There are a ton of quests that really stick to you and set the theme of the game. It doesn't shy away from showing the true horrors of the world. 

The gunplay is also fairly fun and interesting. I haven't delved far enough to say much about it, but so far it's been good. There seem to be a lot of upgrades that can definitely change the combat experience depending on what you prefer. I look forward to experimenting. 

Overall, it's a good game with flaws. If you're willing to overlook the negative things about this game, I believe you might have a positive experience with the game. If you're looking for something more polished, maybe look elsewhere.

BLUF:  Cyberpunk is a fun game on its own merit, but a spectacular game thanks to mod support.  

MODS!!!

*ahem*  Mod support on Nexus is great.  You can completely overhaul how the game plays to tailor to YOUR liking.  

Pro Tip: Complete all gigs in Watson in vanilla.  Whatever you don't like about the game, find a mod for a fix.  

Don't like how the vehicles handle?  There are mods for that.  

Don't like the bullet spongy enemies early game?  There are mods for that. 

Don't like being invincible late game?  There are mods for that. 

Want a customizable or more immersive HUD?  Want more crafting freedom?  Want to change appearance of NPCs?  Want more radio stations?  Yeah, there are mods for that. 

Are you annoyed by the cinematics when you're first launching the game or whenever you're loading a save?  Are you tired of the never-ending buzzing when you're in a menu?  Good god, why aren't there mute options in the vanilla!?!?  Well, thankfully, there are mods for that.

I waited a long time to pick this up. We can't ignore the elephant in the room so lets get to it.

The game had a god awful launch, barely playable. I was just sitting in the sidelines watching it all unfold. Seeing patch after patch be released I waited 2 years before picking it up.

I'm glad I did. Lets go over some obvious points:

Graphics.
Current gen is amazing, and I'm so excited to see what will be possible in the future, roughly 3 months before buying this game I built a new system. My old 2012 hardware just wasn't cutting it anymore. Handles the game well. With an RTX 3070 and Ryzen 5 5600x the game runs smooth at a capped 60FPS on a mix of high and ultra settings. (Temps for those who care, CPU at 50-62C with AIO cooler, and the GPU ran at an average of 61-67C with the stock cooler) The visuals in this game are just impressive to say the least. Can't go wrong with how the game looks.

Story:
I didn't have a lot of expectations for it, and I also avoided all spoilers and really anything with the story. I was pleasantly surprised! Is it a perfect story? No of course not. Is it cheesy and stupid? I would say no. Its well written, has a good pace. And the options you can take during it are really fun. Character building is this stories strong suit, you can really get invested in this game. Since its an RPG game, the replay value is there in types of builds as well as different endings. Solid story all around.

Gameplay: 
Gunplay is pretty standard, feels smooth and a lot of the weapons have a satisfying punch, melee is also fun! The hacking in the game isn't what I would call rocket science, and most of the time I ended up just blasting through enemies becuz fast = gud. 

Bugs I encountered:
Boss fights with enemies that can punch or launch you, I got sent through a wall and into a void every once in a great while. Its annoying but I just had to reload a save.

Physics can still be a little wonky in vehicles. 

NPC clipping, can be funny but can really take you out of a scene if its something serious going on.

Overall, I'd say I can recommend this game if your PC can handle it, its come a long way since launch.

That phrase is a lie, however, Cyberpunk 2077, from a technical standpoint, is still not perfect but has managed to become the game that it probably should have been at launch. Frame rate performance is what it should be, usually well over 60fps for my PC as opposed to 25FPS when the game first launched. There are still the occasional bugs, but most of them are the hilarious bugs that we have grown accustom to in this type of open world RPG. Nothing as game breaking as when I had first played the game in 2020 and the quests would not start or every NPC T-posing in the street. 

On my current and technically my first playthrough (bugs made me quit my first one after only a few hours), what has really hooked me is the game's story and setting. Previous to CP2077, the only CDPR game I had played was The Witcher 3. That game had a great main story with interesting characters that I found myself caring about and a world that was very detailed. While I have not finished CP2077 's main story line yet, I have already fallen in love with the game's world and characters. 

If you can allow yourself to approach this game for what it is, an RPG game with rich characters and a tragic world, and not as the next GTA, this game is highly enjoyable and immersive. I highly recommend Cyberpunk 2077 in its current state and I am excited about the future of this game and franchise.

Cyberpunk 2077 promises to be an epic action-adventure RPG set in a dystopian cyberpunk city. The reality is a bare bones shooter with a mediocre-at-best story. Player agency is at a minimum and dialogue choices largely boil down to how much of a passive-aggressive a-hole you want to be with the only major choice being how you tackle the final mission. RPG elements are surface level and most choices, like the PC's background, are meaningless. Combat is a mixed bag constantly hampered by janky ai. Night City offers little for the player to interact with outside of equipment shops, mission locations and a few other points of interest. Despite improvements since launch Cyberpunk 2077 still remains a bug-ridden shell of the game CDPR promised.

A lot of players said that this game is not completely. There is not finished buildings, bugs, story lines, still lying there for player to stuck, discover or sting to angry. But I am put 200+ hours in this "semi-product" game. It is true. 2077 build a cyberpunk world. I am always spend time in the NC, for hours and hours. I am recommend this game, if you are tired with the REAL CYBER WORLD, yes, I mean our real life world.

Played at launch on base consoles. obviously an inferior product compared to PC, but still a fun experience even with all of its flaws. Got it on PC when 1.6 dropped. Feels like a completely new game, but still kept all the fun that I had with it two years ago. If you enjoyed the game just a little bit but were put off by the glitches and bugs, or you didn't even try it because of the same reasons. Now is the time to jump in.

So again I'm playing a game more than a year after it was originally panned like Fallout 76 on PC and after the 1.6 patch and like the other the developers have come a long way in fixing it's issues. I very rarely encountered a bug and the only serious one was self induced by changing the general path of a mission with a shortcut and was eventually able to get past it. The games graphics are great it's story is compelling and interesting it has between the main, gig and side jobs over 200+ missions to do along 3 life paths and 6 possible endings with 4 difficulty settings.  Guaranteeing enough variability that you will very likely place this all the way through again. It also offers something unique in that if you choose during which ever ending you go down with the dialogue option that returns the character back the the story saved before you chose to finish up the last main mission which turns off access to side jobs and gigs giving you the ability  to go back and hit up the side jobs and gigs you did not play before while doing the main arc.  Further more they just released a trailer for a coming expansion next year. I finished my first play through in just over 70 hours on the lowest difficulty which only brought me to level 28 so not maxed out attributes and perks. Going to finish up all the secondary stuff before I consider replaying it again.
Finally with all the updates I am really enjoying this game!!

This game is really quite fun, I waited until about two weeks ago to pick up the game so that all the shitty launch stuff had been like 99% cleaned up and barely any full bugs remain and I can genuinely say I have a blast playing the game. I do highly recommend getting a mod that removes the main quest cause the whole 'johnny' character arc is honestly the least interesting thing about this game and that includes people watching randos eating pizza out of a cup. When the main quest segments pop up I mute the games audio and alt tab and every few minutes pop back and select literally any option to just get me the fuck out of the crappy plot that makes soap operas seem high quality and well written.

All jokes aside, games solid, fun to play, the main quest is honestly a little triggering if you don't like the game taking over your character and forcing you into like 30+ minute existential conversations that in the literal sense you could just walk away from but they won't let you because their writers ...got lazy? underpaid? No idea but the main quest sucks, fair warning. There are people who like it, this review is for folks coming in and don't like that stuff, those who do come on in the waters fine. For those who don't, look up if the mod exists yet when you read this, otherwise play until you finish the tutorial stuff + Jackie and then just don't ever progress the main quest and the game will be so much more fun for you. Seriously I'm just going to be restarting having slogged through the main quest only to find that it sucked as much at the end as it does at the beginning.

***Edit***

Having replayed the game after making a new character, it's just as bad or even worse the second time around, there's just so much "Game time" you spend watching a cutscene some dev made of another person playing the game you paid for. You then will frequently be given the great joy of playing johnny fucking sliverdick the omega douche alpha chimp for SIGNIFICANTLY longer than is fun and then keep playing as him for a while longer. There's going to be points in the game where for plot reasons you spend extended periods just hacking and coughing like you've caught covid once again in a 24 hour in game period and are going to go through the entire process for the next few minutes.

Overall I can barely give this game a positive rating, cause there are extended periods where you can fully ignore the main plot and the objectively shitty design therein, but if you couldn't ignore it (and it really tries to force it on you, every time you finish a quest it redirects you back into the main quest like a drug dealer trying to force the issue at fucking gun point) it's gonna be an honestly shitty experience unless you like watching a less interesting extended edition lotr marathon as done by keanu reeves who I love as an actor but honestly shouldn't have touched this in any way...

Definitely recommend for everyone to give this game a try at least once. CDPR you fucked up, but you did it.

Pros - Rich environment. Perhaps the richest ever created. Live neck deep in the squalor of Night City (That is why I bought this game a second time like a sucker, at least it was on sale). Varied character builds makes replay interesting. Multiple story endings.

Cons- Tediously long, on the rails, cinematic sequences (especially in replays). There should be a way to skip these at the beginning of a replay. Finite game play. Mediocre all around, still many bugs as of the time of writing, I've truthfully have never played a more mid tier game. Its not bad, just so bitterly mid. 

Basically, the game is fun until you have that in-game existential crisis where you realize how shallow the game truly is at its core. As soon as I realized that pretty much nothing happens inside the world outside of the main quest, it completely ruined all motivation to continue playing, as I knew once I completed the main story this game would instantly have zero content left to do. (All of the gigs are the same, either drive some place, or clear an area and hit F on something)

The driving is worse than the old Saint's Row games, its like your car doesn't move fast enough compared to how fast you are actually going. 150MPH feels like 45MPH, and the brakes on all the cars are absolutely abysmal. 

Soundtrack is complete garbo. Even for someone who loves synthwave, and outrun as music genres. Instead of actual decent music its all obnoxiously loud rap and death metal. I unironically don't like a single song in the whole game. I don't know why there isn't a channel for true synth music and not some wanna be punk trash. It would be fine if not every rap song was trying to sing Rap God at 10x speed, or had earrape instrumentals.

Turrets do way too much damage comparative to other enemies. I swear, turrets were the only enemies that posed a threat. Even enemies with tons of cyberware never did any interesting moves besides the occasional dash forwards at you. 

What's the point in choosing genitals when there are zero graphic sex scenes in the game, and your character is always wearing their undies? You'll show tits left and right but not dicks and vaginas? 

My game would have a stroke for like 5 seconds every time I exited out of the inventory screen before shortly returning to normal. (framerate would become slideshow levels of bad, otherwise it was smooth)

The melee finisher animations take you out of slow mo from the cyberware ability, then give you a full cooldown on it, screwing you over. (I did a slow mo ninja melee build, this shit pissed me off and got me killed so many times)

The braindance scenes were boring rather than interesting to me, and I think it's time developers come to a realization that sections in video games that you're required to search around with a camera and scan shit, are a fad and nobody likes them. Its the modern day on-rails turret section.

You are unable to complete some of the side gigs if you do not spec lots of attribute points into the technical tree. In a game where you can't max everything out so if you don't wanna specialize in that, fuck you, you can't 100% the game. Take some examples from Fallout New Vegas, regardless of what you specialize in, there is a method to complete your objective. You may get less reward depending on what it is, but there's still a way to complete it. I shouldn't have to spec 15/20 points into technical to open a fucking door with no other way in for a side quest. ESPECIALLY if you can't max everything out. 

Dialogue was extremely lacking, character kept trying to act like a kool kid the whole time, and none of the dialogue actually makes any difference besides Fingers.

Also fuck you devs for making Fingers the only ripperdoc to sell some of the best exclusive cyberware. Yet he is introduced as a pervert who works on prostitutes and has  multiple dialogue options implying that he sells faulty hardware, shortly followed by the option to punch him twice, somehow killing him in the process. That felt like a purposeful troll and made me have to go back 5+ hours of gameplay to go not kill him so i could get the good sandevistan that only he sells. Learn to write a proper story, every event leading up to that point had zero consequences for your actions and now half way through the story you throw in a random curb ball? Fuck off.

Also my 45 hours, like, 36 of them or so was AFK. I a little over half way in the story if I had to guess. I was level I think 20?? or so.

Cyberpunk 2077 is the pinnacle of futuristic, open world RPGs. I highly recommend this to anyone that wants an RPG that will provide dozens if not hundreds of hours of solid content. Despite the very troublesome state of the game at launch it is very playable. The story is incredible and it is very evident that CD Projekt Red poured heart and soul into making a lasting RPG. I have never played an RPG that truly felt this big. Sure there may be maps in other games that are bigger but Night City feels more expansive than games in the same category. Cyberpunk looks cool and the gameplay is even stronger. Overwhelming at first, but manageable as you progress through the first stages of the game. I can't wait to see what more the devs have in store for us.

Despite some negative reviews, I can say after 90 hours of play time, first of all I have not completed the story, yet.. This game just leaves you wanting more. Gig after gig, Job after job. Its not perfect by all means but its gotten much better from what I have heard about in the past. it has a amazing story behind it, and I started playing before watching the Netflix Cyberpunk Edgerunner series. Which by the way, I do not usually watch anime but HOLY shit that was such a good show. This game did not come without its bugs though, Had to restart my first play through, thankfully not too far into the game. If you can overlook sometimes (but very rare) frustrating bugs then you should definitely check out this game. Also from time to time the game would crash and of course revert me to my last save. Which at times could set me back pretty far. (Tip for newcomers, SAVE, SAVE, SAVE all the time!!!  Do the side jobs and don't rush through the story. Look in every nook and cranny, you'll never know what loot you will find.

It was rough on start and had problems all the way into the first year, but now after a few bug fixes and things of that nature as well as adding in a few things here and there has honestly revitalized the game, especially after the anime i gave the game another deep dive because why not and i honestly dont regret it (besides deciding it was a good idea to play on hard.)I have bias because i do have a higher end system so the lowest fps i get is 50 in the most CPU intensive areas on max which is still remarkable considering how advanced the graphics are.) There are still bugs here and there but honestly what game doesnt have them at this point, its like Skyrim. The bugs give it the characterization you can atleast see and laugh at because lets be real, we asked for the most intensive game to top even Crisis 3 and CDPR delivered. All in all, I recommend not for the first playthrough or the campaign, but everything in between, the small details that connect over time and the depth of characters that honestly dont even mean anything to the story, its all the side quests and lore that makes the almost 9 year wait worth it.

[b]Summary[/b]

This game is an fps open-world game a bit similar to GTA except it's more sci-fi and you can equip yourself with cybernetics.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]

As for the gameplay, in simple terms, you go around to do quests and gigs. While doing quests/gigs, you can choose whether you want to go loud or be sneaky sneaky. What I really love about the gameplay is that there are many ways I can do the quests, whether it is jumping in and go ham hacking and slashing my enemies or staying far away to snipe or just watch them die from viruses uploaded in their brain socket by me.

[spoiler][i]you can own an iguana and a cat and you can pet the iguana though sadly not the cat. Still love it 10/10 (─‿─)♡[/i][/spoiler] 

[b][u]Difficulty[/u][/b]

There are 4 types of difficulty, easy, normal, hard, and very hard. The difference between them is how aggressive the enemies are and how high their attacks and health are. On higher difficulty levels, you have to pay attention to develop your character properly and once you have developed your character, it will be much easier to come your quests

[b][u]Story-wise/Quests[/u][/b]

Aside from the goddamn sexual shit, the storyline is okay and the side quests are not there just for filler, each side quest has its own interesting story.

[b][u]BGM/Graphics[/u][/b]

They have a wide variety of bgm and each of the bgm is neat and the graphics are awesome especially when it's night in-game.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

By putting aside the small glitches and npc t-posing, it is a relatively good game. The number of details they have added in the game are goddamn (￣ー￣)ｂ example the secrets and easter eggs. I do hope they make a 
multiplayer option as its gonna be more fun playing with friends

Story, characters, and the builds/abilities make this game a great unique experience. The world the game is based in has colorful scenes and you can tell there was emphasis around the main plot in particular. I feel that the team probably had great confidence in the main story but leaves the biggest critique I have for the game. Lots of the RPG aspects that were promised seem to have been left out (probably due to time restrictions). I was really hoping to craft a more in depth V and have a better character backstory built by me. If you can get past some of the glaring faults, there is a fun game to be played. Gigs, side missions and the story are great fun. Right now I have a blade build and feel like a killing machine in slow motion with the cybernetics in game. I would say that abilities will make this game replayable, not the choices made in the story. (definitely not like FNV or Witcher 3 in that regard)

Having spent just under 100 hours and $59.99, here is the nitty gritty
Game concept rocks.
Keanu Reeves is amazing.
The atmosphere is so immersive.
and the alternative/cyberpunk vibe is so great for me.

However, no matter how great the game is, it's still not the game I saw at E3, and that sucks.
The developers are trying, but it's a sort of  attempt reminiscent of an elemental decay.
The development feels like it's on a half-life and theirs no turning back, and with more recent updates and events, they're passing their work on the the community.
Modding utilities and community made music won't make this that game.

Don't purchase this game, unless you know fully what you're getting into.
There's still bugs as of today, the game functions of course, but there's little things that entirely remind you this is a computer game in such a rich immersive environment that it hurts.
The developers seem to have better things to do than fix these things.
The community is apathetic or melancholy.
And the game is alternative Fallout 4 with worse optimization and far less support.

I recommend finding this game for as close to "free" as possible, because it's already uncared for.
But I do recommend it.

My review of Cyberpunk 2077:

Disclaimer: I have watched the anime AFTER completing the game and was still playing as I watched.
Disclaimer 2: I "only" have 45.5 hours in the game at the time of this review, I have had the chance to play it before getting it on Steam.

Overall it is one of my favorite games to come out in recent times, I played it a little after launch around the V1.45 build and it was janky, but good and enjoyable:
The atmosphere is absolutely gorgeous, which honestly is a big part of the experience for me personally;

The overall aesthetic of the game is absolutely gorgeous, I personally love the cyber-esque aesthetic

The game-play/story itself really got me involved in a lot of the characters, side missions and the likes.

It doesn't need as buff of a PC as people would like you to believe honestly, my specs can run it on Ultra at a steady 60FPS:
- Nvidia 1070 8GB;
- 16GB RAM;
- AMD Ryzen 7 1700X at 8 cores

The guns in the game feel very natural to the environment as well, adding to the already present immersion.

Overall, yes the game has a few bugs, yes it has some weird NPCs and it crashes every now and again for no obvious reason, HOWEVER: the game is very fun, immersive and to be honest I can't spend enough time on it, there is always something new to discover, a new side-quest line, a new iconic gun you want to hunt down, there is always something to do in Night City.

I would give Cyberpunk a solid 9.8/10, it's not perfect, but it is so far my favorite game I've played/received.

OK, so I am not someone who generally reviews games. I prefer to play them  rather than talk about them but on this occasion I feel it necessary to make comment only because perhaps if enough people speak up, this franchise could continue.

At launch, I played the game on an RTX 3090. It was  a good game and I didnt have many of the issues that others did with console versions and those using less powerful PC's. It was a great game that I enjoyed and would have recommended but it was poorly optimised and the developer should note that.

I have now played for the last two days on an RTX4090, and using that tech, this is likely the most beautiful game I have ever played. Set to Psycho level, the RTX graphics are simply phenomenal. A bit like Doom 3 before it, this game was clearly developed for a tech that did not exist as release. Whilst that may have been a bit dumb for the developer, it means that we now have a simply phenomenal game.

Please, please, please keep working on this title. With the current gen hardware, the game is amazing. Lets see some good DLC and a continuation of the franchise.

As reported by many, I can confirm to add my voice to the fact that the AI is pretty horrible, they roads drive like an ice rink, and there's lots of (largely minor at this point) bugs speaking to its lack of polish.  I wish it were better in those ways because the purpose is to transpose you into an interactive environment that you can believe you're a part of.  These failures serve as significant reminders that you're simply playing, not experiencing.  It's the difference between good and mastery

While it could be better, its probably also true that the developers would have gone under with this effort due to the "no one can get their hands on a PS5" conditions that affected their decisions and they deserve some slack for what they had to work with.  It's a fun game, full of worthwhile, engaging content.  I might actually play through with a different build and opposing gender with a less compassionate attitude because the dialogue is actually different enough and feels like it matters.  Full disclosure, I stopped caring about replayability years ago because I never actually play it again.  Buggy, but real feeling characters and textures make up for the polish and if you started late like I did, you don't have to worry about being bitter about the way it was at release.  It's worth a play now, I think.

Now that it's been a couple of years, they got it to the state they should have always had it, and guess what? CDPR is still very good at making videogames.  I know that capitalism is all about the quickest dollar but if you take your time and dont release garbage you might also have a huge hit?

When I first tried Cyberpunk 2077, it had already gotten waves of patches and content added. I ended up refunding it because of the frontloaded information and mechanics (that tutorial shard...). I did not have any knowledge of the lore the game builds on to push me through it.

Then Cyberpunk: Edgerunners got released. A means to understand the world of Cyberpunk, and enough to convince me to try again. I am very glad I did. What initially was a frustrating depth of mechanics became enjoyable, as I instead learned as I played rather than try to remember everything the tutorial shows. There is a lot to the game, far more than I could express in a review, but a few main things:

Quickhacking is great. Major DEUS Ex kinda stuff, and fits any playstyle depending on what ones you equip (as well as what you place in that cyberware slot). Melee character? Make their guns backfire, blind them, disable their movement. Sneaky beaky sort? Deafen and blind them, wipe their short term memory so they don't even react, or just knock them out with enough RAM upgrades Interact with stuff all over the enviroment to distract, redirect or debuff. Guns Blazing? Debuffs, stuns, turn robots on their owners, trigger traps, make things explode, make other things explode, make people explode.

While the street interactivity is a bit of a let down (only some food stands and shops are usable, stuff happens which you cannot do anything about though you can stop extortion and robberies if you see them), the Quests (Gigs, NCPD Scanner Hussles, Cyberpsycho Encounters) interact with each other and the main story all over the place. It really feels like your actions are reacted to, unless those actions are randomly dropping in from the sky in which case nobody acknowledges it, and acts like you took the intended route.

Johnny Silverhand. The ghost in your head, shows up and often provides his own perspective, advice, or direct help. Kind of like a companion, but with more depth since he is a main character who is always a story factor.

Gunplay feels bad up front, but it gets better. For me it mostly came down to using file tweaks to select a much finer sensitivity instead of large jumps, and using single fire guns with the aim assist mechanics disabled.

Addicting gameplay

Truly a phenomenal game, if this had come out this year, rather than 2020, it would easily make the top 20 lists of anyone who appreciates games as a unique form of art.
I have never played a game, or even enjoyed any kind of media, that has made me feel hatred for a fictional location like 2077 has, it truly captured the spirit of the original RPG and I can't really think of a different studio that could've done better to iterate on Pondsmith's works.

Alright so now for a more objective look:
The Mechanics:
Gunplay; pleasantly surprised by how satisfying it was to shoot all of the guns of this game. Speccing into pistols is fun as hell. Only detriment I'll say is that the ricochet feature barely ever comes into play, yet I find myself using near-exclusively power weapons because of how good and abundant they are.
Melee: well developed for a first person game mostly focused on shooting and hacking. But melee combatants are kind of stupid bulky thickheads who just run up and do the same attack animation every time.
Cybernetics in Combat: Stuff like Sandevistan is fun, but Quickhacks are too versatile to give up, especially when you get the legendary ones that grant passive abilities. I was a bit disappointed by the lack of variety in leg implants, however, equipping a smart weapon and double jumping around combat feels like I'm playing a very weird version of Titanfall. Other than that, get kerenzikov, it's just cheaper, smaller, more reuseable, sandevistan.

The Aesthetics:
Graphics and Environment: Night City is beautiful, and after I don't know how many patches, the game is actually pretty well optimised. I have a lower end of system capable of playing this game and can still play with a high level of detail while only having occasional spikes of frame loss (fewer than 1 per hour).
Music and Score: On my first playthrough I didn't appreciate the OST nor the radio tracks too much, on my second I really allowed myself to be absorbed in them. The OST, radio tracks included, is not the best I have ever heard, it is probably the most fitting soundtrack I have come across so far. The in-universe songs feel like products of the world, and the score feels like a soppy drunk polish rockstar kicked half an orchestra out and replaced it with their mates, in the best of ways. Oh, and the Mikoshi theme hits harder than Truth Revealed did in The Line.
Character Customisation: It has enough tools to make a unique V for each playthrough, however, is lacking in other respects, there is a lot of aesthetic cyberware that is present on some unique characters that V has no access to, and the body scars and tattoo options are abysmally limited. I don't know why pronouns are attached to voice, of all the arbitrary factors to attach them to voice is the least jarring, but it's still arbitrary. Why is genitalia customisation even in this game? I appreciate manscaping as much as the next lass or lad but you're only ever able to see it in game in a few frames between walking up to and backing away from a mirror, and most mirrors still aren't large enough to capture that, you can't even view it during "those" scenes.

Story and Missions:
Don't make the mistake I did, don't chase down the main plotline because of how V's deteriorating condition is presented, you'll reach the step right before the point of no return and realise you've barely met kerry and river.
But, I am saying this because I think that all of the side missions are worth playing in this game, the ones with arcs compliment the main story well, and the standalone ones can be fun or fucking terrifying or depressing. Everything from nicking the car of a wannabe batman, to finding out that a previously wholesome character is just as fucked as the rest of this City, to nailing a guy to the cross.
I've seen some say that this game isn't truly part of the cyberpunk genre, being a fun but flawed tangent to it instead.
To this I wholeheartedly disagree, this game dives deep into the meaning of the distinction between organic sapience and a talking few thousand lines of code forming a feedback loop, and whether that distinction even exists, a core theme of cyberpunk taking from the philosophy of cybernetics.
Your relationship with johnny changes how he interacts with you when shit gets dicey, keep an eye on that % in your menu, it does matter. As for the finale of this game, I experienced quite a few strong emotions while playing the endings; but that's likely due mostly to the order I played them in. Without spoiling anything, I played through the pills ending (if you know you know), the worst ending, the best ending, and then the cool endings. Temperance still fucks me up to this day. If you're a Judy fangirl like me, I'd recommend this order.
While I'm speaking of characters, all of them in this game are amazing, and they are beautifully voiced by both established and relative newcomers to the industry. With that said, I gotta recommend you choose femme V for Cherami Leigh's performance, I love masc V but you can tell he's a euro putting on an accent and it's enough to take me out of it on occasion.

Oh and Silverhand is Keanu's iconic role in my mind now, I always like that he essentially plays himself in most works, but in this he plays something barely recognisable as Reeves and it works. He pulls of being an arrogant arse and a genuine friend simultaneously, the fact that Silverhand is a class archetype from the RPG is just the cherry on top.

All in all, solid 9/10. If this game had the extra year or so that (from what's been reported) the devs wanted, it could have reached a 10 for me. It's definitely one of my favourite games of all time, possibly my favourite narrative in a video game.
As for bugs, went through playthrough 1 with nought. Got some more in no.2 but to be fair I did also mod Panam to be a lesbian so that might be on me.

Pleasantly surprised. Heard a lot of the negative stuff online but it was either over-exaggerated or the game has since been vastly improved. The gameplay mechanics and controls are solid for an FPS, though the driving needs some work. Also the pedestrians are pretty copy/paste and you'll see quite a few identical character models (sometimes including the same outfit). The story kicks ass. While it feels like some stuff has been stripped down and what you experience is a lighter version of something that originally went deeper, the game still connects successfully on an emotional level. Coming from the perspective of an audio engineer, the sound design of Cyberpunk's world is fantastic - from the explosions, vehicle sounds, music, dialogue and the impressively vast weapon effects to the well-placed silences, whispers, and even the footsteps of the player's character, the in-game audio pops out at you when something needs to be brought to your attention yet it gives you a rest when it requires subtlety. The pacing is pretty good for a story and world this big, and pretty much all of the training and the perk/attribute upgrades add something valuable and unique that helps to grab the player and immerse them into Cyberpunk's world. While crashes-to-desktop, random frame-drops, and graphical glitches do occur, they're rare enough as not to hinder the enjoyment of the game.

Overall an 8 out of 10, excellent experience and highly-recommended

Cyberpunk 2077 was among the most highly anticipated games in history. Its brought to us by the same developers of the Witcher games which, is probably what made this game as hyped as it was. With all this hype this game was destined to be a failure for some, for me however it was probably the best gaming experience I have had all year. Despite the amazing writing it is just average in some of its "RPG" parts, this did not hinder my enjoyment much, but it might lower yours significantly.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2871151275

The Characters are the heart of the game. The story is great and raises interesting points regarding AI, our possible future and body modification, but the characters in this grim world are what makes the ending so emotional especially with what happens while the credits roll.

However, V, is the in my opinion worst written one. The 3 live paths did introduce you to him but never really gave huge insights to any bits of his past. Every other character is believable, and you get to know them greatly, from goals, past to personal struggles you get to know everything about the people living in and around Night City.

The Characters of Cyberpunk 2077 are more than you might expect at first glance, the most prominent example here is clearly the man, the myth, the legend Johnny Silverhand. He is also the character most prominent throughout the story and the one that undergoes the most surprising but amazing development. The others are not much different though, they all are so well fleshed out and developed that once that ending hits, it really it's hard.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2872633456

 CDPR's worlds were always about stories and not about you interacting a lot with it. What you experience in this game you experience in the quests, not in any side activities. There is not much interaction with the world. Its mostly a stage for the characters to play on. You have an apartment, but it does not feel like "home" because you just can't do anything with it. Just don't go in it expecting it to be a Rockstar game, because it is not. However, the atmosphere in Night City is amazing, driving through the rain as never been better in any game i have ever played. Its also very detailed, you know by looking around in which district you are, what people live here and how they live.

A whip-smart, dark and ingeniously plotted story, stunning visuals, excellent voice acting (especially from Cherami Leigh as female V) and a vast, immensely detailed open world you could live in for a year: Cyberpunk 2077, two years on from its disastrous launch, is a truly outstanding game. Take your time over it, because the more you put in the more you'll get out. If it has one serious flaw it's the pacing of the main storyline, but that aside it's an absolute blast. Admittedly I'm an addict of the genre - I cut my teeth on Bladerunner and Neuromancer way back when most of today's gamers were just an itch in their daddy's ball sack (sic), but dive into this with your eyes open and I promise you'll be richly rewarded. Just don't treat it as another shooter, because it's way more sophisticated than that. And make sure you acquaint yourself with the lore before starting off or a lot of what's happening will wash right over you. Personally I enjoy playing from an entirely first person perspective, which works brilliantly here, and I never use fast travel. Wandering through the mean, neon-lit streets of NC late at night is a joy, especially when a sandstorm's brewing, or in the rain when the colours refract back off the wet tarmac and you can almost smell the heady aroma of synth beef and fried locust coming off the food stalls. Stay safe out there, Chooms!

I played a pirated copy at launch that I had to update myself, so I had a pretty rocky start.

All things considered, I very much like this game. The gameplay while basic, is engaging, and the characters are all well written and not the monkeys that reside around most RPG studios. The visuals are graphically impressive, and that is helped heaps by it's stellar art direction.

 This of course, had the *rockiest* launch that a game has had in recent memory. There is quite a few issues (that might not even be issues, depending on the person.) 
- The difficulty is done in a way that doesn't really reward skillful play, but instead jacks the numbers up and down.
- The bugs even now are still present. They aren't the truly game breaking ones that they used to be, but are more hairline fractures in the detail of the overworld.
- the gameplay is not going to be winning any awards because it's basically the standard package of shooter gameplay with a hacking interface built over it. sure it has more movement, but it feels like a lot of missed opportunities than anything else. There was a chance for some truly wack stuff
- Most of the main and sidequests are good, but there is a lot of filler content that seems a like it's padding for time
- The game is very easy to break, damage number wise. Quickhacking is also pretty busted, this game would be *hell* if it had Dark Souls style multiplayer.

This game got a lot of backlash when it was first released and rightly so - it was full of bugs, especially on consoles. The PC version has always been running quite decently though and now, after a few major patches, that's more true than ever. And then out comes a truly brilliant game. 2 years out and still fucking buggy with shit optimization and often dead ass world. The game does look good and can be fun at times. expect better from cdpr, but the sheer amount of content and upgradability is really enjoyable
So far I've only had one bug that didn't affect NPC pathing or gameplay at all, was just funny when it happened.

The game has problems- textures taking way too long to load in (preventing continuing story quests/talking to npcs), and just running down the road to face will have you running into swarms of polygonal humanoids, who will become normal in 10-30 seconds if you're lucky. Sometimes quests bug out- leaving you to either have to work around the error or reset to a previous checkpoint. AI can be dumb as a bag of rocks- but don't count on them ever missing if they do get you in their sights. And some encounters feel way unbalanced in the games favor, especially one side mission where I had to lob grenades from cover for five minutes to actually complete it. And this was a mission received very early on. Didn't beat it until the near the endgame. 

But, the story is fantastic. The characters, their stories, the world (when it loads in) is captivating, and I really do believe that the leveling system offers a lot of replayability, because each encounter can certainly be solved in a multitude of ways depending on your kit, whether that be stealth, tech, guns or just punching out your enemies. 

It's a unique kind of tale- asks fun questions about life, our world, its potential future. It's not a game I recommend buying at full price- But, assuming it becomes more playable over time, I advise you get it on sale- the further in time from this review the better.

Don't expect your perfect edgerunner fantasy- but if you buy it, buckle up choom- you're in for a ride.

Game is a lot of fun and the characters are written and acted very well. 

The major issue with this game is its "Save File" system which makes game save files critical to its stability. Why did CDPR choose this save file system to keep track of your loot? Because it's cheap (they don't need to host a database) but they did not bother to add a verification system, integrity check system, logic, etc. to the save game system. Nope, just a simple massive local running .DAT file that keeps track of your entire progress in the game. 

You know what is constantly crashing my game out of nowhere? I am crafting a weapon, upgrading it, and when I craft it again and click the Upgrade menu item it crashes. I can reproduce every single time haha... I am using in-game features and it crashes instantly. 
What's the fix? Load a previous save and hope for the best. That's right, you need to undo your own progress and literally hope that you got it right... in what world is this acceptable?

PSA: If you want the best chance of not having random crashes consider the following:
- Don't collect random junk to dismantle later (Yes you read that right, a loot game that can corrupt its own save file mechanism due to too many random items)
- Don't use any mods. (Mods are awesome - Hello flying cars!) but running Mods can permanently corrupt your save file and issues can arise immediately or later.
- Don't use stat modifiers or trainers. (Again they can corrupt your save file)
--- Starting to see a trend? ---
- Don't save manually too often. (Yep, even this can mess with your stability)

Basically folks, either you just play the main campaign and side missions or chance it by exploring and looting everything the game has to offer.

And even if you play "vanilla" you will constantly have to fear the game saves and wonder if a corruption is coming that will force to lose progress or outright have to start over from scratch. This renders the whole prospect of discovering hidden objectives and trying to be a completionist entirely moot.
deep story, lots of options on how to play the game

This game is a milestone of unfulfilled expectations and broken promises. Yet a game worth buying when on sales.

I love the genre, I loved the gameplay of The Witcher 3 and I wasn't expecting too much from this game after all this bad news after its release. I waited over a year before buying it on sales eventually.

As most people say, the story is memorable and well done. However, the open world is flat and dead. There is no relevant interactions beside the story and even the story has little to no impact on how the world reacts to the player. The interaction with the world feels pretty soon repetitive and nothing to actually care about. Yet, it looks good at a glance.

Combat is mediocre  and often feels random in its outcome. There are bullet spongs at every corner and hacking + steath is in most cases the best option to win quickly. (Or you use unballanced and OP builds to anhilate anything on sight.)

About hacking and stealth: Both are a strength of the game and I really enjoyed doing hacking supported stealth missions. For me, it felt ballanced and rewarding. Unfortunate, the game forces you to use brutal force in some missions.

Talking about rewarding gameply: The loot system is horrible. I have no idea what the devs were thinking, spamming the player with items that are easily overleveled ever 10-15 minutes. You found a legendary item giving a big upgrade? It will be replaced by any white item very soon. This is particually annoying if you are like me and trying to stick with a certain look. There is no elegant way to stick with your look AND have good items equipped at the same time.

About quality and bugs: Like most ppl say, this game is still full of immersion breaking bugs, ruining cool story sequences because NPCs bug out and doing hillarious things. This is not too often, but hard to overlook.

About driving: It is the worst thing I every tried in a PC-game. Anyother game I played sofare, did a better job. For people playing racing games, it is just insulting.


TL;DR: Buy it for the story and buy it on sales. You will not get disappointed. Expect something like The Witcher 3 and you will hate it.

Please do not listen to all the negative scuttlebutt. Give this game a try, and be amazed at how much it has to offer! The more i dig, the more fun I find. It's been a while since I've had so much fun playing computer games.

Edit after 140 hours played: 

The game is _still_ growing on me! It is rising to become one of the finest games I've played. And I've played computer games since the 80s. Well done CD Project Red (CDPR)! 

My heart bleeds for your talented developers who saw their game released in unfinished state and desevedly slaughtered by the market. The game should have been released after v1.5 / 1.6. I hope the game's renaissance currently going on helps the game achieve the fame it deserves.

This game is more than playable! It is stable and working very well. I've only experienced one crash and a couple of bugs. None game-breaking.

The only gripe I have is driving cars in this game. Works OK when going slow. Horrible and frustrating when going fast (unless driving in straight lines). Please CDPR: Learn from Saints Row 3. Super fun driving. 

It is stupid how V - the main protagonist - with his/her computer-enhanced-brain and super-reflexes can drive the future-tech cars so bad. The amount a car turns when I tap the arrow keys differ wildly. Some times I can not make the car turn 5 degrees without pressing arrow key ten times.  Other times the car spins because I tapped the arrow key one time too much. I've driven for probably three hours combined and still struggle. Drifting around corners is messy and fails too often to be fun. And it is stupidly difficult to avoid dead stop because I snag a small singpost (strange how huge signposts can be run down while a small post can cause dead stop. 

I have enjoyed all missions in the game so far. But I delayed the driving mission, fearing how it would annoy me and probably make me rage quit. The mission is well told, well designed, and could have been super fun if only the driving in this game was better designed. My advice: Drive casually and slow 90% of each race. Avoid max speed. There's no point in reloading a save if you crash and spend like 20 full seconds untangling / unflipping your car: The other contestants are waiting for you right around the next corner (!!!). Completely immersion breaking. But this taught me to appreciate all the other stuff that _works_ in this game. When stuff works it is invisible. Kudos CDPR!

There are some great mods for this game. Want your own radio station in your car with your own MP3s plaing from a radio station carrying your name? Want better headlights that actually illuminate the area when driving in darkness? Want trashbins to be able to accomodate more than two bodies? More clothing options? I am still googling regularly in the hopes of finding a better driving mod than the ones available so far.
Still a bit buggy, still not what we all hoped for. But a decent RPG. In any case worth picking up.

TL;DR Overall an amazing game, despite some very minor imperfections.

Very rarely have I put over 100 hours into a game, and I'm not sure that I've ever put that many hours into a game where I enjoyed every bit of it. I avoided Cyberpunk at first due to the reviews and CDPRs notoriously buggy launches, and while I did experience a couple of minor bugs, they were limited to basic visual things like clipping. Nothing at all was game-breaking whatsoever.

Main Story: The main story was interesting. There were some directions that story took, especially towards the end, that left me feeling a bit railroaded and disappointed by not considering my character and Silverhand's growth along the way in a satisfactory manner. However, overall it was still an interesting story that I wanted to see how it ended.

Side quests: I love CDPR's ability to really tie the side quests and seemingly random encounters into the larger story. Silverhand's dialogue in unexpected places among quests that totally didn't relate to him was cool and kept me immersed. Even when doing side quests that could feel a bit grindy I felt like they were mostly worthwhile. The supporting characters were great and I enjoyed their quest trees as well. Panam's and Judy's especially; however, I still found River's and others very enjoyable.

Combat: I really enjoyed the combat system. There is a lot of variety in weapons and combat style. Smart weapons, power weapons, melee weapons, cyberweapons (like mantis blades), and even talking weapons. While early on melee isn't really a viable option, as you progress and build your character you can totally take out squads of enemies with nothing but a sword. Very cool and a lot of fun.

Vehicles: The cars were cool, but terrible to drive. Handling was atrocious, and while I got better overtime it seems no amount of skill can fix the poor handling programmed into the game. 

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys single-player RPGs. This is probably the best single player RPG I've played in several years.

I got into this game on other platforms and accounts in it's initial release, I loved it then and I love it more now. Admittedly I got into the game knowing very little about what was promised vs delivered. I did not follow the production and development of this game. I went in blank and was absolutely amazed with the atmosphere, the game play, and in the end the characters/story really stole it for me. I was a big Mass Effect trilogy fan, I enjoy horror games like dead space. I've played some AC titles and other open world games like GTA. I'm an 80's - 90's sci-fi fan and I love 90's music like Nine Inch Nails. For me this game has been so rich, and I have put multiple runs (and purchases) in on different platforms. In the games current state I cant recommend it enough. There is a ton of detail and despite how in your face the world may seem the details are rich and run deep, its a game best played low and slow. Don't plan to hit it and quit it if you really want to enjoy it. As dumb as it sounds you really start to develop a "relationship" with the city. The more you take time to simply walk, or listen to the radio, or look around an alley with no obvious loot the more you see how much work went into the title. I hope you take the time to pick this game and up and enjoy it. It's good to support this team. It may not have come out of the gate as a 360 No Scope highlight real, but its absolutely a hit and its on target and in the end, this team killed it. Love it or hate it, its the only game like it. That alone is worth the price of admission. It's an experience.

Witcher 3 has been my favorite RPG game so far ... it seems like maybe Cyberpunk 2077 is a close second (but I haven't completed it yet .. and an expansion pack is coming soon .. so lets see :))

The game was so weirdly glitchy when it first came out that I quit playing. Retying it a year later and its a bit better, but still glitchy.  Every time I start the game there is a moment where all of the NPCs drop from about 12" above the ground and slump weirdly. The exact same weirdly deformed NPC isn't present on every block any more, but you still see the same handful of distinctive people multiple times on a block.  Every so often when I check my wardrobe or look in a mirror my character's breasts glitch through their shirt.  Cars are still all but undrivable. Really important things, like the location of transportation nodes, don't appear on the main map (only on the very limited range mini-map) so finding your way around quickly is still a massive PITA.

There have been a number of cosmetic free DLCs that add clothing, and they finally implemented a system where you can pick a "look" and apply it to whatever gear you're using - so to have decent armor you didn't have to look like an idiot.  And yet, who cares? Your style makes no difference to any NPC - you could be naked for all they care - and there are no other players to see it.

The story line is good (what I've seen of it) but it suffers from the same problem as all open world RPGs. The story tries to give you a sense of urgency, but the gameplay actively defeats the urgency. You have 2 weeks to live, I'm certain I've played over 7 days in the game world (I can't be certain because there is no way to track time other than counting day/night cycles), and yet my progress on the main you're-going-to-die quest is still much less than 50% because I haven't hit the triggers to advance it.

Cyberpunk 2077 may be the buggiest triple A game I have ever played, and this is coming from someone who played both Fallout 4 and Fallout 76 during launch week.

However, I still think that despite it's major flaws, it is still an amazing game and well worth playing. The story, the characters, the soundtrack, and the multiple play styles you can run with, from an adrenaline junkie running around with a katana, to a tank lugging around shotguns and LMGs, or a netrunner who clears entire areas out with a single quickhack.

I wish Cyberpunk received more time and care before it shoved out obviously too early, but I still love it in it's current state nonetheless.

Handling of weapons improved, NPC seem to be more talkative and visually appealing and there are actually random incidents around the city from accidents, crime scenes etc. which just makes Night City come alive.

The way Cyberpunk 2077 improved with the previous 2 updates gives me hope, and I believe we are in for some great surprises in the near future.

Greetings! Here at Thermohype, we're sure that almost everyone knows about the buggy mess that is "Cyberpunk 2077". However, this may not be the case for long!
The recent release of "Cyberpunk: Edgerunners" on Netflix has brought a lot of attention back to the game! In the last week, over 1 million players have gone through the
streets and slums of Night City. This is the MOST players they have seen since the failed launch in December of 2020.

    Now, what has led to this influx? The release of "Edgerunners" has sparked new interest in both previous and new players to the series. This has caused a massive
up-swing in traffic to the original title. 1 million players is nothing to scoff at. Cyberpunk's team has made it a point of fixing the game. While still buggy, the game
is being fixed and has shown great improvement! Again, it is still not a perfect game, but it does show promise. There has even been an update recently. This update has
added eastereggs from the show. Definitely a great marketing tactic!

    Could this mean the return of "Cyberpunk 2077"? That has yet to be fully realized, but the numbers seem to show a consistent interest amongst players.
I (the writer) have played a fair bit since the newest update. I do have to say, it's definitely a massive improvement. Could Cyberpunk be the next "No Man's Sky"?
We here at ThermoHype are keeping our eyes and ears open to see if that may be the case! The Cyberpunk team has said that they are still working on updates. For us
here, that's something to look forward to!

TLDR; I recommend it, it's a fun game. 


When I first started playing this game I got into the introduction to the first mission with Dex and then fucked off to go wander Night City at the first opportunity that I could. I hated the experience. 

I was in a massive city, surrounded by NPCs constantly, everywhere I went, and yet the experience was absolutely devoid of life. Sure, there were the occasional NPCs that would talk to you (about nothing in particular) or shout at you if you ran into them, but otherwise, it was just a city of blank slates.  The highways are massive and there are cars littered about going here and there, but even that experience felt hollow and vacant. I took some random turn off the highway and ended up in some bizarre corner with police cordoned off sections of roadway. Still nothing. It was just a lonely corner of some random road buried under the highway super structure shadow.
The game map feels massive and the set designs are, what I would call, damn near flawless. This is a beautiful game. Visually, you can get lost in it all just looking at everything. The problem with this game is when you dig a little deeper with adventuring and discover that it's almost all just superficial eye candy. Locked gates and trash strewn about entrances to hallways prevents you from straying too far off the beaten path.

You can tell this is the portion of the game that the devs were forced to sacrifice to release this game by the announced launch date. 

Where this games truly shines and where you can tell the devs weren't fucking around with is in the actual story, story missions and even the side quests. The game suddenly feels incredibly rich, vibrant and populated when you're going about accomplishing what the story wants you to accomplish. Tearing down the highway getting to the next mission location  on a motorcycle everything blurs and life springs up in the most unexpected way, in that it doesn't do anything else beyond what it already was doing. I don't know why the city felt more lived in all of a sudden, but racing off to location after location, averting disaster after disaster the city felt more alive. 
The music selection for this game is also par excellence that absolutely needs to be spotlighted more. Cruising the winding highways and random backroads of Night City would be vastly lonelier without those phenomenal radio stations distributing those amazing melodies and rhythms straight to my brain. Every bit a dopamine ride.

This isn't to say there isn't stuff to walk around and discover about the various characters and locations. The release of Edgerunners has proven that there's always been a veritable treasure trove of goodies to discover hidden throughout, be they tangible goods or noteworthy locales in back corners. 

This game had a legitimate rocky launch, there's no two ways about that. I"m 25 hours into this game and I'm enjoying the hell out of myself. This has been a most unexpected experience for me with gaming. CDPR feels like they're turning this game around, albeit, slowly (It's kinda like No Mans Sky in that regard). The updates have been clutch though, this game is playable now. It's beautiful. It's fun. I recommend playing it, especially if you're coming over after having recently watched the Edgerunner series.

I’ve loved this game long before it was “fixed” so I may be a little biased. The game ran great on my Xbox One X at release, and I have fond memories. Now, though, things have been dialed up to 11, especially on PC with a ray-tracing & DLSS enabled card. Wow, just wow. At times I feel like I’m playing the most polished open world game ever created. The highs are just that high. However, then come the dips from those glorious heights. Enemy AI, impotent cops, and a persistent issue with NPC variety continue to haunt the game, but they don’t come close to ruining the experience, especially after patch 1.6 (and I can import my Xbox save file finally!). I’m biased, I’ll admit. I’ve loved cyberpunk as a genre ever since reading Neuromancer in college and having my mind blown. So, when I say play this game immediately, despite its rough edges, keep that in mind. See you out there choom.

Great game, I have played it for 75 hours and still no where near the end of the story. There is so much to do, besides the main storyline. I enjoy the side missions more, and they are very fun. I know the game had problems on release, but after two years those are all fixed. I have no trouble playing the game, and the graphics are best I seen. The combat is also very fun, being action styled, not just a tab target, or click a button for auto attack. You have to aim and use utilities to defeat NPC. Even randoms on the street, when I merc for the police killing ganksters, my character has been defeated because I didn't plan correctly. I also have it on hard mode, which I would recommend. Easier settings make it just a story book, you enjoy the storylines, but there is no challenge and makes side missions boring. There is an even harder mode, but I think that is just for people that beat the game and want to try it. Playing it first time with that setting would be a waste, just as easy/normal modes would be.

I missed all the launch issues and am really enjoying the game on the current patch (1.6).  Has a GTA meets witcher 3 vibe (callable cars, magic/technlogy specing, etc.).  Got it on sale and have no regrets.

I've been playing since launch and started out on PS4. We all know the state of the game at launch, and it was especially bad on console. But lets be honest, I know that I've played many a game that launched in almost or just as terrible a state. *coughBETHESDAcoughBIOWAREcough* But despite all the bugs, pop ins, and game crashes, I persevered though it because the core of this game was one of the best I had ever played! I combined a lot of what I loved from other open world RPGs with a futuristic aesthetic I had been craving. The characters felt real! *play female V, the voice acting is much better* The story is a wonderfully bleak and tragic tale that will absolutely suck you in if you let it. And Night City is the MASSIVE mega city I always imagined and it's slammed full of detail! Yes there is a lot of duplication of npcs and environmental objects but in a world this large and crammed so full of what you would expect to see in a city of this size, shortcuts had to be taken and, at least to me, is understandable. And its getting better every patch. I've always been a huge fan of dystopian future movies and the cyberpunk genre and CP2077 definitely did not disappoint in that aspect. I immediately fell in love with the game and still am.

I finally got a PC right about when update 1.5 came out and have been playing it off an on ever since. You can definitely tell PC was the platform this game was designed for. Most of the major bugs had been ironed out before the 1.5 update came out but the quality of life updates and skill tree streamlining completely changed the feel of the game for the better. 

And now here we are at the 1.6 Edgerunner update and I'm in love all over again! This is the game we wanted and expected from the start! Is it a perfect game... no. But the realist in me knows there never will be. But for me, this one is pretty damn close and hits all those personal notes that makes a game stand out for me.

Also, GO WATCH EDGERUNNERS NOW!!! It will bring yet another level of enjoyment to the game... and sadness :.(

As a final note i'd like to say; Shame on you CDPR for releasing an incomplete mess of a game to us 2 years ago! But also, THANK YOU for never giving up on it and knowing that there were silent fans out there like me who were quietly enjoying your story and hard work, patiently waiting for it to become the work of art the we knew you intended it to be.

Cyberpunk 2077, what a ride it has been since launch. I remember playing this game at launch and I got lucky with the low amount of bugs and issues I had with the game at launch. 
I also never followed almost all of the marketing, when it comes to games, I only ever find out enough to understand if it'll be a game that I'll like.

The story at its core, is unlike most other games I've played, and is one of the biggest reasons why I keep on coming back to this title. The 3 different paths at the start whist are interesting, leave a lot to be desired, streetkid being the worse one overall with the lack luster beginning and the lack of impact throughout the game, whist Corpo did the most, despite its almost nothing beginning. The main story was great to run through, as well as the weight you feel whenever you completely any of its endings

Whist the RPG elements were mostly lost from this game, it felt like this story, and a lot of the other working parts of this game showed that at somepoint it may have had a lot more choice wise in the game. The side quests in this game were overall amazing, and you could always be sure that whenever you did one, you'll enjoy whatever the quest sent you on. 

The gameplay loop has overall improved since launch, and the handling is so much better. If this game had more time in the oven, it may have actually pulled off something great, though that was likely never gonna be, but the game we got instead, whist flawed and filled with empty promises, is still a great time and a joy to be had

It is pretty safe to say now that this game has been fixed, congrats, you can launch it and play without any major bugs!

With that out the way, I can now give my thoughts on it.

Cyberpunk is a world full of rich characters that you will come to grow and like, a lot of them have story arcs for you to work through between the main story and it is definitely worth pursuing all of them, just be careful you don't get friendzoned and nearly die of cringe. One thing I absolutely admire about this game when interacting with characters is that you are not forced into a fixed camera angle as you get through all the dialogue between the pair of you. You are free to move around, stand or look where ever you like, which can help with the RPG element greatly!

The open world is expansive enough and there are plenty of side quests to keep you busy, but there is not a huge variety in them and nine times out of ten you are just going to go in there and shoot 'em up, needless to say that some of the side quests can get mundane fast, the side quests that involve actual characters and interactions are the ones to really focus on.

The game offers a generous plethora of weapons, skills and builds, so you better decide what type of play style you are going for and stick with it. I went for a hacker / pistol build and trust me, if you max out all pistol skills, you won't need any other weapon, it's pretty op.
The driving mechanics are still something that is hard to master, it really is quite sensitive, so don't try any hard turns unless you want to do motorcycle mid air 360's.

The story fits quite well with the world around you, everyone is out for themselves, corporations are oppressive and everyone around you in some way is suffering. It's a grim and brutal world lying under all those cyber enhancements and neon lights and the game does a damn good job of reminding you that. While I can't always connect with the main character due to on the fly personality switches, there are plenty of characters you can meet that you will form a bond with, some more than others. The main plot itself is actually kinda short, I think the game expects you to do a lot of side quests between all the main ones and to be fair, you do need to level up a good amount to be able to survive against enemies in certain sections of the city but once you reach a certain level, everyone becomes fair game, main quests or otherwise. The main story is captivating but I think mainly due to the characters you share the journey with otherwise it could actually be seen as quite simple.

With Cyberpunk in a good position technically and all the dust settled, I would definitely check out this game if you are curious about it but I would also say, get it at a sale price too.
