I remember hearing about Cyberpunk 2077 around when it was announced. I was interested because I could tell that it would be a tough game to run - performance wise, and it had Keanu Reeves in it. Then when it came out... It was everywhere, and everyone said it sucked. It was a broken mess of a game that wasn't even finished, so I vowed to myself that I would never buy such a hunk of garbage. 

2 years later... 
I'm bored, it's a Saturday. I'm on Netflix wondering what to watch; I had watched A Silent Voice & Breaking Bad a few days earlier, they were both great in their own ways. Then, on the main screen of Netflix I see: Cyberpunk: Edgerunners. I think to myself, oh it's going to just be an advertisement by one of my favorite animation studios (Studio Trigger) that got paid to make this. I was wrong, the story swept me in like a storm and I was 200% engaged in all 10 episodes. 

1 day later...
I can't stop thinking about that show, the characters, and even more that was in it. I look on YouTube to people playing some Cyberpunk 2077. "It looks decent and actually pretty fun now," I said to myself. I saw on YouTube that you could get Rebecca's shotgun, David's jacket, etc. in Cyberpunk 2077 and I thought that was dope. I want this game now.

2 days later...
I see everywhere how the player count has increased to 50,000 concurrent players on Steam; just crazy, and the game was on sale at the time, right after patch/update 1.6, so at 10:15 P.M. I bought the game and sold some Counter Strike cases to pay for tax. I let it download and got on the game after I was done with everything I had to do the next day. 

Present day... 
This game is insane, I love everything about it, the details put into the game, and the constant care that CD Projekt Red has given it after the game's launch up to today & onward. They fixed their game, and made a true piece of art. I've played a lot of story-driven games in my day, but none come close to the absolute experience that this game has given me: emotionally, mentally, etc. I love this game and trust me when I say that the game is fixed now & it is my favorite game of 2022 so far. (even though it came out in 2020, patch 1.5 - 1.6 has made it a new game with all of the features and bug fixes that they've added) Also, they got over 105,000 concurrent players just a day and a half later!

Some thoughts:
This game has too much to do other than the main story and (at the time of writing this...) I've sunk almost 40 hours into it already after only 7 days. It is an open-world experience to level the fun and quality of games like: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Grand Theft Auto: V, and much more. This game is amazing and I 100% recommend buying it. 

P.S.
Also watch the anime, even if you don't like anime that much, but you like this game... It's so great and the story in both the game and the show are breathtaking. 11/10.

The game is not breathtaking, it's actually depressing. It's basically a dystopian porno for males. I can't say I would personally recommend it to anyone because it would just be too awkward, knowing the content. It is buggy (including game breaking bugs) with unpolished features even after all the updates (patch 1.6 as of writing this). I encountered so many bugs that I ran out of space to put them in this review, and will instead provide a count: 22 bugs, two of which were game breaking that I had to find a way around, sometimes with mods.

Character customization is surprisingly limited and did not allow me to achieve what I was wanting. The hair looks very plastic. You can't play a truly hairless character, so when I was hoping to play a sexless, inhuman android with no nipples, etc., no-can-do. You can only have a stubbly head, human chest and genitals, and normal colored skin. Only sexy, human-looking people with hair follicles allowed. No ability to swap out limbs, etc., no cool metallic skin like some of the NPCs have. The only real "cybernetics" you see are a few lines on your face during character creation. The clothing is bad, with much of it looking rubbery/shiny or shapeless, and the hats being so ugly that I've never had one in an outfit in the entire time I played.

I don't like the voice actress for the English-speaking Female V. She sounds like someone trying really hard to sound tough, but it comes off as cringe instead.

The game comes off as very "male gazey," for a game that painted itself as somehow inclusive. A quest pushed me and a female NPC into a strip club filled with women, and the stripper image in the room was female. Why not a male stripper? The game constantly references male masturbation and images/fantasies that males want, and prioritizes sexy women over sexy men. If this is the future where you can supposedly swap out body parts at a whim, it sure isn't acting that way.

As evidence to the above point: there is only one romanceable male option for a straight female. The sex scene prioritizes your female character moaning like she's in a porno over the male character that you are romancing, who is actively made to shut up during the scene. Why would I want to listen to my character moaning over the one I am romancing? Typical.

There are loads of female NPCs to romance and have sex with. "You can have a relationships/sex with women as both a man and woman," is not inclusive. Those are the top two porn categories for straight men. It's really imbalanced, and the romance system should have been done much better, with many more options. Having every romanceable NPC be "player-sexual," like other games have done, would have been the only choice that makes sense in a game that claims that people can just swap their body parts into another sex. Of course they have a character in-game that has done this, but your own character and other characters don't fit this mold. Very surface level and illogical.

You can't swap your camera view to see your character in third person except when in a vehicle. This is weird and disappointing for anyone who wants to see their character running around and in action. Driving in first person view in a car is awful. Your character can barely see over the steering wheel, like someone who is very short/small/elderly. I have no idea why such a terrible camera view was implemented.

Why is the button for crouching and skipping dialogue the exact same key? This leads to so many accidentally skipped dialogue lines while attempting to crouch in high pressure situations. The F key is used for everything as well, and you struggle to remember to press or to hold the key on computers to get the desired result. There are so many overlapping hotkeys and they really mess with and ruin your interactions. The fact that you cannot rebind all hotkeys in this game is crazy for 2022. Why? 

Lastly, after all of this: CD PROJEKT RED supports censorship in modding. They contacted a modder to tell him to take down his simple character model swapping mod. I strongly reject this behavior and believe that people should be able to mod their single player games however they want. Considering all the problems in this game, and the inability to make a truly inclusive game, CD PROJEKT RED should leave modders alone to fix their mess and poor choices.

After finally having seen pretty much all there is to see in Night City, I can confidently tell you that this is a good game. Combat isn't perfect, but it works enough to be very fun and addictive, as pretty much any build you work towards is guaranteed to be OP in the late game. The amount of choices you get to make is slim to none, and most of them don't actually matter until the endgame. There's still bugs and glitches here and there, but nothing like how it was on release, so it's perfectly playable and immersive.

This game is easily the MOST atmospheric game I've ever played. Most immersive too without being VR, which is astonishing. Every single street in Night City feels hand crafted, and nothing looks copy-pasted. Flow of missions happens pretty smoothly which adds to the immersion, similar to GTA V levels, except you could still walk away from conversation at pretty much any time unless it's a pre-made cutscene. The graphics are gorgeous, even without ray-tracing, and the sounds of Night City are perfect. Each weapon has its own unique animations and there's loads of detail packed not only in the weapons, but the cyberware as well. Once you start to learn more about the story in the deeper sense of the lore, the game really starts intriguing you to find out exactly what's next and how things happened to get where everyone is now. The character animations in pre-made cutscenes are essentially flawless, and some of the best animations I've ever seen. People seem lifelike during these scenes, they bounce their leg, they shift their eyes, they fidget, and most importantly, they express through their face accurately. Face animations are the real GOAT of this game and helps it tenfold.

All in all, grab this game if you're on the fence, it's totally worth it at this point, even for $60.

To sum up: I really enjoyed my 1st play though. From the gameplay to the story.

You've been lied to. The game is great and I'm enjoying it immensely! 
[[Pros]]
-A fantastic first jump into the Cyberpunk genre. Deep philosophical questions, everyone is a walking computer, bright neon everywhere.
-Mystery and layers to the stories makes it feel like many mini adventures strung together allowing you to have unique play throughs based depending on how you feel like playing.
-Guns galore and plenty of options from stealthy bois to boom boom.
[[Cons]]
-"Specific" world/ story design choices. This is basically the only problem at this point and it comes from getting too invested. I love the characters and story so much that I start getting frustrated when things don't follow my personal head canon.   Basically the story is great if you want to experience Cyberpunk in a very specific way and although the designers did a fantastic job giving you many different perspectives, all that variety sometimes makes the game feel like a museum tour more than a focused narrative. You got to "Go here" and "meet these people" a lot and it gets frustrating for me personally. I really can't stand the desert cowboys and would prefer a solely corpo based story, but that's kind of defeats the point of the game. There are a ton of different varieties to the Cyberpunk sub genre and Cyberpunk 2077 wants to show you all of them. From the bionic street thugs to the digital voodoo wizards, you'll see EVERYTHING, and I sort of wish I could control the narrative more so I could stay where I wanted and not interact with the parts of the game I don't personally like. Like I said, you might love this game for this or you might be like me and wish for a more focused story. It's not technically bad, but you'll have to see for yourself.
-The Open World is MASSIVE and the cars are terrible. It's so hard to drive on PC without crashing into things and that's lame because the shear size of the map makes it clear driving is part of the main experience. The world looks nice, but it's so big that a lot of things can feel samey over time. It's not the devs fault, it's a HUGE map to fill with content. No one can really fill it no matter how much time you have, but I wish they had taken a Mass Effect approach with limited zones so they could work on specific areas and develop them better while still having awesome sky boxes to imply there's a bigger world rather than having to try and fill that world and failing. The devs did as good a job as can be expected from this sandbox style and it's way more involved than Slyrim for example.
-NO CYBERNETIC OPTIONS?!?!!?!? Ok, so to be clear, there are a FEW options for your face and there are two bionic arm textures you can get, but you're going to feel like the most human thing in the game compared to the wild cybernetic attachments NPCs  and the gangs have. I really think this is on the update list because how can you not have endless cybernetic options in a CYBERPUNK game?!!?!?! Devs, PLEEEEEEEASE add this. I want to have spiked feet. I want to have laser eyes. I want to have a sledge hammer for an arm. Please.

[h2]Intro:[/h2]
I had been waiting for this game since that first E3 trailer waaaay back in 2013. I pre-ordered and waited through 3 delays so I could play on day 1. Obviously the release was a cluster, but for some strange reason I wasn't entirely disappointed. The game gripped me despite all the initial issues and backlash against CDPR. Here's my very opinionated review 280 hours in.

[h2]Best:[/h2]
The best part of this game is the world of Night City itself. Besides some crazy future tech, most characteristics of the city feel true to the direction the US is headed in the real world: corporate greed, disregard and abuse of marginalized groups, insane divisions between the classes. Night City is not a perfect caricature of near-future life in the US, it doesn't ignore society's problems. Instead it outs the spotlight on them and forces you to live them. This adds compelling motivation to many of the stories and quests in the game by showing the player the true price of living in NC.

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
The combat is very fun. There are a lot of options and except for primary attribute points you can respec all your skills. This means that if combat ever gets boring, the game leaves the door propped open for you to experiment with new weapons, skills, and hacks.

The cosmetic system is also a big plus. The most recent major update (1.6 as of now) added a layered wardrobe so you're not stuck looking like a clown during cutscenes, but can still have all the gear with the best stats equipped.

Walking around and exploring the world is surprisingly fun. There are so many random Easter eggs, pieces of lore, side quests and amazing characters to meet that it really adds a sense of unknown and wonder (even in a world limited to a single city). Sure there may be the occasional graphical bug and the crowds may act funky sometimes, but the sights and sounds create truly captivating role-playing experience (If you're into urban living). 

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
The main quest line could have used a little more love. The pacing feels off at certain points and it seems like the main characters magically have knowledge relevant to progressing the story. Everyone's motivations make sense, but just adding a few more missions to pad around the major events would have really driven the story home. There are tons of side quests, but not very many that provide insight into the main story.

Yes, there are still a large assortment of bugs and graphical glitches. Mostly these are visual and just affect immersion and don't really hinder your ability to play through the game. If you go racing around full throttle guns blazing like a maniac, you're likely to notice these glitches more, as the game tries to keep up, than if you play with a role-playing mindset.

[h2]Worst:[/h2]
The worst aspect of this game for me is thinking what could have been with better oversight and care from CDPR. Maybe if they hadn't teased the game so early, they could have given themselves an extra year or two to polish things up and let the developers' passion run wild. It feels CDPR over-promised and spent all 8 years struggling to meet their own expectations. It's just missing that final layer of love that only a few big RPGs ever get. I can only imagine how insane my first experience of the game would have been if it was free of major glitches, had a clean, user-friendly UI, and a more fleshing out of extras (looking at you public transportation).

[h2]Final Recommendation:[/h2]
[b]Until another game comes along that can offer a deeper and more compelling modern RPG world, I whole-heartedly recommend giving Cyberpunk 2077 a try.[/b] If you go in looking to pick bones, you probably wont have a very good time. If you go in looking to immerse yourself, you'll be in for a treat like no other (for now).

I came to this game late and reluctantly because of all the negative stuff surrounding it, but I am not going to talk about that in this review much at all as that horse has been beaten to death. |
So here is my honest review after starting a play through and logging 14 hours so far. 
I LOVE this game. The story is incredibly engaging and the characters have depth. The combat is difficult enough to be challenging, but not frustratingly overwhelming. The skill and perk system is well thought out and executed. The visuals are really stellar, and this might be an unpopular opinion, but I am glad it forces you into first person... the world just seems so much more engaging and real this way (I was a skeptic as well; why make such a robust character creation process to stick it in 1st person?) well, it works. 
Yes there are some minor bugs, but most games have them. Whatever "sins" this game had at launch and those first few months, they seem to have been addressed, and what is left is an absolutely beautiful and engaging game. 
I highly recommend.

I bought the game on the first day of release.
Cyberpunk 2077 for me is among the 5 best games ever released.
Here's why..

1 - The second best and most beautiful city I've ever seen in an open world game.
2 - The main story and side missions are phenomenal and of unprecedented imagination.
3 - The soundtrack and effects throughout the game are chilling.
4 - The crafting and loot system is the most addictive and intuitive you can find.
5 - Immensely varied character evolution system, which can shape our style of play in many ways.
6 - Weapons until you say enough, of all kinds, shapes and even a very very special one ))
7 - We have lots of cars, apartments, mods, clothes, cyberware and even pets))
8 - Exploring the city becomes something surreal, both day and night, with or without rain, a city that changes according to night or day. (There are certain areas that even give you a shiver at dawn)
9 - The most memorable characters we've ever seen in a game.
10 - Map with several secrets, zones that are completely explorable and a lore of the game that reading the SHARDS leaves us speechless.
11 - Even SR Hideo Kojima found it))
12 - Moments of pure tension, sadness and chills are portrayed in an epic way.
13 - Fantastic photography mode.
14 - This game is a playable work of art and an excellent RPG.
15 - Finally welcome to Night City)))

This game got a lot of bad press when it dropped. I'll admit, I wasn't sure they could pull it off. I was pretty convinced for a while that it just wasn't playable.

Some friends were streaming it recently. Weird, none of those game-breaking problems were happening. Didn't see that coming. Sure, the occasional silly animation bug, the occasional glitch or hiccup, even a crash after 6+ hours, but that's workable.

So I picked it up and gave it a go for myself.

Here's what I've found:
- Cyberpunk has SOME performance issues, they come and go even on a pretty solid machine. That's to be expected. This game has an extremely detailed world and I can forgive some occasional frame loss because of that. I just wish I knew why it happened seemingly at random, and then resolve itself after about a minute. 

- The animation bugs. Some of them are downright hilarious and catch you off guard, or last a split-second and make you do a double-take if you didn't blink and miss them. And if you run the same scene a second time, there's only a chance you'll see it again.

- The gameplay is pretty versatile. Options aplenty for how you WANT to play. Different prompts for if you've heavily invested in one stat or another, to get past the same problem.

- The characters are well played, show facial responses to a lot of what you tell them. Really makes you feel like [strike]Spiderman[/strike] you're in the world, talking to more authentic personalities.

I've had a field day with this one, and I think this world would be outstanding to explore with another person. Heard rumors there'll be something like that someday. I look forward to it.

This game allows you to create manual saves (in addition to autosaves) and then deletes them automatically when the batch of saves stacks to twelve or fifteen.  They are gone from the save game folder as well.  You  can't start more than one character without the game deleting the first character after an hour of playing the new character.

For a game with this much content and playtime to manage I feel this is just one example of a detail the developer didn't properly address, possible because they bit off far more than they could chew with this game.  I have some sympathy for that, but I remain disappointed with this purchase, and will think twice before trying the next game this developer puts out.

I bit the bullet last week, a year and a half after the release. I heard about the troublesome release (who hasn't) but I didn't have any expectations going in.
I wasn't waiting for the premiere and I haven't seen the Netflix show yet. But I had an itch for a bit of RPG so I got Cyberpunk 2077.
Right off the bat: I love it. I absolutely love the game. 

Those things that I love:
1. The world: it is huge, it is beautiful, and - most importantly - it is ALIVE. 
2. The story. It's gripping, it is emotional, it is gut punching.
3. The side quests. There is a heck a ton of them and they are all amazing. No fetch quests!! They also make me feel things. And also, for the first time in my gaming career, I failed the quest on purpose because I couldn't bear it. 
4. Judy, Panam, River, Jackie love'em!! 
5. So many things to do.
6. So many things to wear.
7. So many things to shoot with.
8. So many things to hit with.
9. So many things to drive in.
10. The phone: calling and messaging my chooms.
11. There are always at least two ways of doing quests.
12. The other characters not mentioned above. They are all GREAT even when annoying. Fantastic VA. Those NPCs live.

Things that I don't like:
- driving was awful at first but I got used to it
- gunplay was awful but I got used to it as well, although it is still not great
- my V seems to know more than me and it can be both hilarious and frustrating. Just today I met with a client and V exclaimed: OH IT IS YOU! Yet I, the player, have no idea who the hell we were talking to.
- So many things to wear yet most of them are goddamn awful
- the game DOES NOT explain the hacking minigame
- storywise the beginning is fantastic but gameplay wise it is tough. There are too many icons, information, choices, and buttons and you can easily get lost.
Basically, I would say it is EVERYTHING EVERYWHERE ALL AT ONCE.

Overall though? I love Cyberpunk. I am invested in the story and the characters although it makes me depressed at times and I feel inevitable gloom and doom. I am a sucker for happy endings but I am not sure if I can get one here.
Would I want to live in Night City? No, no I wouldn't but somehow I can't leave.

* Dialogue audio is often paced quite poorly with unintended awkward pauses or characters speaking over one another.
* Quest steps sometimes bug out (e.g. enter the elevator, but don't you dare enter it too soon, otherwise you'll have to exit and re-enter for the objective to trigger completion).

Qualms like those aside, the game delivers on the core fantasy of a cyberpunk city and I find myself by and large getting immersed in it. At the discounted 50%, I don't regret my purchase. Not sure I would have paid the full 100% price though.

It’s difficult to quantify just how good Cyberpunk 2077 is. It’s like trying to tell someone you’ve discovered the world’s best cheeseburger. We all know what a cheeseburger tastes like and, for the most part, they’re all fairly similar. But sometimes, a special, magical combination of ingredients comes together in a way that has to be experienced to be believed and understood. Cyberpunk 2077 is like that. It’s an open-world, first-person RPG with hacking but it’s also so much more. It’s a sublime experience from the moment it begins to the end of the (35+ minute) credits. No matter what kind of gamer you are and how you like to play, Cyberpunk 2077 caters to you.

Playing as mercenary V, players are dropped into the fictional Night City and let loose. V’s personality, skills and class are all shaped and developed by the player while playing. And they’re never locked in to one specific thing. Are you a gung-ho, guns blazing, wise-cracking arsehole? Cyberpunk’s got you covered. Do you prefer to sneak up on your enemies and stay tight-lipped? You’re covered too.

Do you want to tackle each and every situation, conversation, mission, combat scenario and traversal across Night City based on how you feel at any given moment? Well, that’s also an option. The freedom to play how you want and be who you want in Cyberpunk 2077 is nothing short of breathtaking and the fact it affords players this level of freedom while delivering a seamless, fluid and engaging experience is mind-blowing. Many games buckle under the weight of their own ambition, but Cyberpunk 2077 avoids this pitfall and instead, creates an experience which is never less than completely dictated by the player’s whims.

In Cyberpunk 2077, CD Projekt Red has created a phenomenal tour de force and a game that’s unlikely to be matched anytime soon. It is an important game and one that demands to be played.

[h1] Welcome to Night City (again) [/h1]

*Your classic steam review checkbox template is down below*

After preordering the game, playing it shortly after release, finishing the main story in 30ish hours [spoiler] (it's a thing I always do when playing a game for the first time: easiest difficulty, skip all of the sidequests/activities, except when I just try them for fun) [/spoiler] and forgetting about the damn thing - here I am again, playing for the second time after watching edgerunners (yep, they got me too).

I thought about writing a whole fekken manuscript on this one, but got lazy and reached the character limit (apparently there is one on steam lmfao), so here, long story short. 

-ABSOULTELY get it when there's a discount.

-Get yourself some time to breath and explore Night City. 
You will lose A LOT if you don't do sidequests/read notes or messages on PCs/explore all of the blue dialogue options. I never do that because it's fkn boring for me, but after watchin edgerunners I decided to give this game as much time as I can, and lemme tell ya - I'm happy that I didn't do this on release, because now I can dive into this game when it's in a more than playable and enjoyable state.

-Even if it's your first time playing - look out for the mods available. Some pretty impressive stuff is coming out, and there is more to come. You will surely find something that fits your style.

-Don't play this game on a difficulty below "hard". Trust me, I consider myself an "arcade" player, but CP feels too easy even for me on anything below hard (OR medium, ok, ok). It WILL be a bit of a pain in the ass in the beginning, but when you reach midgame with a nice build - it will become a walk in the park. I've been even considering getting a "hardcore" mod.

Bugs and glitches are for the overwhelming majority, fixed/corrected. Make sure to adjust your graphics setting to not get a "flatline error" I thought this was a glitch at first, turned out I had the highest graphics settings on and my PC, albeit a powerful Digitalstorm, couldn't keep up and it crashed over and over. After adjusting to "High" from "Ultra Ray Tracing" I have not experienced routine crashes, 1 in total out of 15 hours since the adjustment. As well, make sure your drivers are up to date. This reduced the number of "flatline error" crashes I experienced. So in all, make sure graphics are set properly and update drivers?

So after completing a playthrough of the most recent update of the game I can recommend the game since I can without a doubt say that it was fun. If you have loved previous CDPR games you will like this game too. Notice that you will most likely "only" like the game not love it.

The reason why you will probably not love this game is because even after all this time the game is still somewhat buggy (though I had no major game breaking bugs). 
....Another reason is that the game suffers from a somewhat boring "high dps screw defence or strategy meta" when it comes to combat which makes it lack in variety to deal with enemies (armor values are practically meaningless on higher difficulties for example)
....Another reason is that the (side-)characters in it are superbly written but the opportunities to actually interact with them are far and few (which is a damned shame). Like how awesome would it have been to have a Mass Effect type squad combat with the usual party banter to flesh the characters out? That would also have been way closer to the actual cyberpunk tabletop
.... Another reason is that it bothers me to no end that a significant portion of the game is to help the corrupt law enforcement (event the game itself makes it clear that they are corrupt) through NCPD scanner gigs. Like the entire setup makes V out to be this rebel type character but a significant part of the content of the game turns you into a glorified deputy sheriff. Such a strange game design choice.....
.... Though said last playthrough of the game made a better impression when it comes to the AI of enemies (compared to launch) it is till somewhat rudimental

But as I said: The game is still a lot of fun.....
.... You can actually try out a lot of different build options; even on higher difficulties (as long as they conform to the "high dps meta")
.... even the stealth gameplay is fun and suprisingly deep (especially when it comes to the hacking)
.... The characters are great and the overall "look and feel" of the cyberpunk universe is definitely there
.... Though it is a shame that most of the side missions are mainly driven by text logs and messages not through exposition of the ingame world (something that the witcher series did way better) they were fun though a tiny bit repetitive
.... The game world is nowhere near as packed with content compared to the Witcher 3 but it is still a lot for one playthrough if you do all side missions / acitivites

Again: if you loved the Witcher series you will like (not love) this game too.

Up front: Yes it is demanding in terms of hardware, no not ALL of the bugs have been fixed. That out of the way, I still enjoyed this game from launch day, though I do acknowledge that I seem to be part of the blessed minority who rarely encountered anything game-breaking. Even then, the worst of the bugs have been dealt with, and by now several features that weren't ready at launch have now been fully implemented. CDPR is very much committed to this and still has plans for it, and if you have the hardware to run it properly, there is a wealth of content waiting to be discovered. Night City is well worth simply walking through, and oftentimes some of the most hilarious, disturbing, or just downright depressing and horrifying conversations come from random citizens on the streets. The main story has plenty of twists, but you're doing yourself a disservice if you ignore the ocean of side jobs and gigs scattered from one end of the map to the other. Rewards aside, some of the most memorable parts of the game are entirely optional, and going over the city like a fine-toothed comb will always end up being rewarded. And all of this content was designed with multiple approaches in mind, whether you want to play it quiet, go in guns blazing, or even sit outside and kill everyone by looking at them through security cameras. 
Bottom line, this game is a diamond in the rough that's only getting more polished. Remaining bugs are largely superficial, and either easily ignored/fixed, or are genuinely amusing and not what I would personally consider detrimental. (Come on, a guy sitting on an invisible crate on a street corner like a mime is kinda hard to get genuinely worked up about) 
If your computer has the chrome to handle this rough beast, and ESPECIALLY if you've watched Edgerunners on top of that, I strongly suggest you give the current state of the game a look

What if you could save Jackie? Or betray Dex or even kill the arasaka's then steal the relic  and what would happen next? I got this game for PS4 on release day instead of PC as I figured the console would be better optimized (ha!) than it would probably be on my then PC. I had all the issues with it but knuckled up and dropped around 50 hours into it. I stopped after I heard a slate of patches were coming and figured I would be as well waiting since I was getting a new PC. 

So I got my beast of a machine and dropped the cash on the PC copy and transferred my saves. Only to have inconsistent crashing. CDPR insists that I disable any software that uses overlays (or any software at all really) my sound drivers and invoke an arcane ritual to boot it up. Sometimes I get to play 4 or 5 hours with no hitch. Then I reboot and it crashes when I pause or access inventory or change the time. It's the inconsistency that is frustrating and the fact this has been an issue for months. Sometimes I delete the cache and get a good session in. Other times can't even get past the logo. I have tried uninstalling and reinstalling drivers and files and briefly considered installing an older version of windows before realizing I should not be jumping through this many hoops to play a game. 

I WANT to love this game but it is so hard to play it's frustrating. I am leaving this negative review to add my pebble to the hopeful landslide of pressure to make fixing this issue a priority.

This is the first game I've ever bothered to write a review for over my many years of using Steam. This is one game that I've gotten very attached to and one I play almost every day. I have over five hundred hours in this game, and counting. I've been playing since launch and even now, years later, I find and discover new things to do and see every play-through. There is so much to do in this game and the story, characters, music, animations, and acting, among many other things, are amazingly done and very unique, things that I've never seen any other game studio do before. This game has always been a blast for me, and with the patches and updates made by CDPR over the years to iron out any bugs and imperfections (and add in new features and items that are REQUESTED by the community, yes they actually listen to their fan base), this game has become even better. I one hundred percent recommend this game to anyone who might be on the fence! It frequently goes on sale, as well! I am so, so stoked to see the future of this game and can't wait for more additions by CDPR in the years to come!

Patch 1.6 and Cyberpunk Edgerunners has sparked new interest in 2077, and for good reason. There is something appealing and catching in this game, but some major playability issues make it borderline unplayable:

- The incredibly bad implementation of the eye adoption effect makes it almost unplayable in the game-day time. Literally impossible to drive in first person view, nearly impossible to look into sunny areas from being in a dark area, and making my eyes and head hurt.
- Same for the sun reflections from shiny surfaces like glass or metal, which are incredibly and unrealistically bright, like laser beams right into your eyes.

I have read that a lot of people have the same issues but stil no fix from the developers.

I have tried every graphics and video setting in the game and nothing makes it better for these two critical problems. I have read that there is a mod that may help, but this is unacceptable from the devs.

There are also some other issues which are somewhat manageable (steering while driving is incredibly annoying, but can be made a little better via steering speed settings) or simply annoying (people and cars disappearing or spawning right in front of you; incredibly obvious scripted traffinc during missions; the other characters are incredibly hard to see in the darker areas because they are indistinguishable from the surroundings).

Reading the reviews, I have been lucky that only one of my missions has been broken so that I have not been able to finish it, but luckily this part of the mission was somehow respawned after the recent patch, so I could finish it after the patch - not sure if would have been possible otherwise.

I knew this game was special when i saw it, but i just didn't have the money or the rig to handle it at the time, and now that an influx of people came in, may it be through the beauty that was Edgerunners, or those driven by curiosity, i'm glad that they're able to get into and experience Cyberpunk in both a better mindset of the game, alongside being able to get into it when the game is less buggy than it used to be.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an amazing experience that i originally expected to be, with the story of the game being my original draw to the game in the first place, and it didn't disappoint one bit. Pre 1.5, the game was pretty janky all things considered, but still held the same amount of world and story depth that i had expected and more, with pretty immersion breaking bugs that may take you out of the experience here and there. When 1.5 rolled around, there were a ton of fixes and general improvements to the game, alongside more interactivity with the world, namely the new apartments, as well as general balancing and polishing.

All in all, i'm glad that Edgerunners helped allow people to see the beauty of CDPR's Cyberpunk, alongside how everyone was able to give Cyberpunk a second chance despite its infamous history. I'm grateful to CDPR for sticking by Cyberpunk and acting on its potential, and i'd like to thank everyone again for giving this magnificent game a second chance, even if it is still buggy here and there.

TLDR: Game is 8 out of 10. Kinda Boring at some parts. 

For those who can read: 
Waited a long time to write my review as I wanted to give the devs proper time to fix the game. After almost 2 years since release I can say that CP2077 is a playable game and was a fun experience albeit a bit boring sometimes. Some Callouts - 

- I wish it had been third person or at the very least had the dialogue done in 3rd person cutscene/cinemateic style like Witcher 3 had, would have made the game more enjoyable especially since you almost never see any of the gear you are wearing and the conversations with NPCs felt very odd. 
- The "filler" quests/tasks like GIGS, NCPD Scanner and Hustles, Cyber Psychos and- wait that's it. Just those three things? I know you can save all your money and buy all the cars but thats still not much (Close to 1.7 Mil eddies for all cars). 
- Driving needs work, never really felt like i had mastered the games driving mechanics after 100+ hours
- Visually stunning and the theme is of course amazing, who doesn't like Futuristic cyberpunk aesthetic? 

Overall  had a great experience with the game but it lacks depth compared to something like The Witcher 3. Wouldn't pay a full 60 for it but if you can snag it on sale for atleast 30% off, get it! ( And if your machine can run it)

[h1] VERY MINOR SPOILERS [/h1]

I was one of the many people who played this game near it's launch date back in December 2020, and...

Well, let's just say that I didn't have many kind words back then.

To say the least, the game was [b]HELLA[/b] buggy at launch, from small bugs, like cars randomly flying in the air, to literal game-breaking bugs, some to the point where it was impossible to finish the game to 100% completion. Now, because of these bugs, and several more bugs and just general issues, this game was berated by people online, even resulting in CDPR getting several class-action lawsuits, and even being the victims of a cyber-attack [i](how ironic)[/i].

But, that was (nearly) two years ago, and whilst I still think that the game has quite a bit to go before it turns into the game that fans were promised just a few short years ago, I think that the game is in a very playable state at the moment, and I strongly urge people to give the game a second try after its updates and patches.

Now, I don't want to dwell too much on the past, which is why in this review, I will be mainly be talking at length about how the game feels and plays today, after the latest patches.

[h1] Cyberpunk 2077: A Comprehensive Review [/h1]

[b]What I Like[/b]
First off, I [b]LOVE[/b] the atmosphere and art-style of this game. It really does feel like a breath of fresh air compared to most other RPGs I've seen and played. Night City in general screams of a city that seems like the perfect paradise that most people would be looking for, when really, it hides a dark secret, that only residents of the city would know. Another thing I really like is that each district of the city has their own vibe, like with Japantown having virtual cherry blossoms and things traditional to Japanese culture, whilst the City Center has things for the rich, such as large buildings, and designer clothing stores. It's the small things like that which really sell the atmosphere of the game, which makes the city feel more immersive.

Gameplay is a big thing when it comes to games like this for me, which is why I am very pleasantly surprised to see that this game feels very nice to play, and has a lot of replayability. This is one of the biggest selling points of the game for me, the fact that it not only fun to play, but doesn't feel repetitive is one of the best things that a game can be.

Another thing that's feels good to mention is the amount of new features the game has gotten since release. Back in December 2020, the game felt basically empty, with V (the main character) only being able to own 1 apartment, and having very little decor in said apartment, aside from a plush toy you would get from signing up for a GOG.com account. This has changed drastically, with there being 4 new apartments that V can rent, and being able to decorate the original apartment, with new colors and moods. More new features include:

-Ability to customize appearance (hair, makeup, etc) in apartment mirror, and being able to customize more thoroughly (eye color, face geometry, [spoiler]...genitals (yes, really.)[/spoiler], etc) at ripperdocs.
-Transmog system (ability to customize and wear outfits without affecting armor)
-New quests
-Cross-progression saves
-Many improvements to vehicles, economy, and combat

And the last thing that I want to add on to this list of features I like in CP2077 is the modding capabilities. I think modding is a must when it comes to games like this, and seeing all of the mods available for this game really adds to the whole game in general. And thankfully, that will just continue to get even better, thanks to the recently announced REDmod modding tools, and I can't wait to see what modders will do with better access to official modding tools.

Whilst there are many things that I like about this game, and more that aren't listed here, there is one glaring issue...

[hr][/hr]

[h1] The Big Issue [/h1]

Trying not to get into too many details, I do really like the story of this game. It has the right amount of witty dialogue, scary settings, and feels. But, I feel like this game focuses too much on the main story, and too little on the other concepts of the universe. One of the first examples that comes to mind is [spoiler]right after Jackie's death, when Dexter shoots V in the head, and you suddenly wake up as Johnny Silverhand, on a mission to invade Arasaka, getting killed by Adam Smasher in the process.[/spoiler] After this segment, we can see Johnny being interrogated by a few big names in the game, all occurring in an unknown room. What was that place? Was it some sort of afterlife? Do only people who are reserved as legends end up there? What even happened in between the player arriving in this space, and Johnny waking up in V's body? It's things like these that make me think about all the deeper parts of the game, and more so, how very little they're talked about. There are many more examples of this, especially in the context of cyberpsychos and how cyberpsychosis even works. These are not explained in the game, which could lead to new players who aren't familiar with the lore of the game being very confused. I know I was confused for a long time. This leads to the game not portraying the main issues of Night City very well.

Whilst this is a big issue for me, there is some hope...

[hr][/hr]

[h1] A Silver(hand) Lining [/h1]

CDPR have already said that they are committed to the Cyberpunk franchise, and will continue to build the story, whether that will be through updates, expansions, or straight-up sequels is still up in the air... well, except for the fact that there will be a full expansion for CP2077 coming out next year...

But, that's not the point. What I'm trying to say is that I hope that with the expansion, and whatever comes after, that the concepts of this game and the universe of Cyberpunk in general can be explained more thoroughly.

But thankfully, there is a way to get deeper into the story of Night City.

As of the writing of this review, there is a new original anime series titled [b]Cyberpunk: Edgerunners[/b] on Netflix, which explains some of the concepts of the universe, whilst also offering a great story to go along with it. I strongly urge anybody who wants to know more about the lore of Cyberpunk, or even anybody who wants more from Cyberpunk to watch the anime. as I believe it shows off both the best and worst parts of Night City better than the game could ever do.

The game is top-end, I advise everyone.

Overall worth the price, especially since it goes on sale so often. Don't go into this game expecting a magnum opus of game development, it's only above average.

[h1] the gunplay [/h1]
Feels more like an RPG than a FPS; enemies above your level take [i]several[/i] headshots to kill on harder difficulties, and enemies generally just feel like bullet sponges. There are really only about two dozen weapons in the game with various stats applied, and you encounter the same weapons over and over again. The only variety you can find is in the weapons from quests and legendary loot. Picking up some random guy's weapon just gives you the same 3 weapons over and over again.

[h1] the progression [/h1]
Since it prioritizes RPG elements over anything else, the progression in this game is actually very fun. Unfortunately, it's VERY easy to "optimize the fun out of the game."

What do I mean by that? It means that it's possible to grind out levels on generic missions for long enough that you end up so powerful that you can kill enemies with little to no effort and breeze through the main story. You end up playing the boring missions to progress to the point that the good missions become a breeze.

[h1] story [/h1]
story's good, but the "branching paths" like what was advertised just aren't there. While some missions have different paths to take (aka the good ones), the others have Fallout 4's system, where your options ultimately boil down to

A.) yes
B.) sarcastic yes
C.) yes (correct path that gives you items)
D-F.) give me information

The three paths you can choose at the start of the game change nothing but the prologue missions. They give you one extra response here and there, but overall you can experience pretty much the same exact game no matter what path you choose. No matter what you do, you're always "mercenary V who has the ghost of keanu reeves in their head."

[h1] graphics [/h1]
The game looks beautiful. Better than quite a few other open world games. A big problem is that the animations for V are dogshit and need to be reworked. There is no third person mode, but you can still see V's shadow and watching your shadow while you do certain animations like swim is VERY immersion breaking. Pre-baked animations make everything feel wrong, if you've ever played the original half-life that's about how it feels. At least this game has ragdolls.

The low amount of enterable buildings while exploring the open world is annoying, and it makes the world feel as deep as a puddle. The city, while it uses very few copy and pasted buildings, ends up feeling very same-y. There's a large amount of sex shops, which does fit with the aesthetic of the game, but as dunkey put it, it would've been cool to see something more interesting than a store called peepee, like a stadium or a zoo.

The lack of a proper physics engine is to this game's detriment. While NPCs can ragdoll, there are several pre-baked animations that play that can hurt immersion after seeing them so many times (like the animation that always plays when you get run over by a car).

The game's AI is horrible, you can literally watch as most of the AI you come across just walks in circles. I'm not asking for reactive AI, but something better than every single AI playing a second-long loop of a fear animation when you point a gun at them while the rest of the city ignores you would be a good start.

Playing this game feels like there's this illusion of a living city, but the moment that you apply pressure or investigate further, the illusion breaks. 

NPCs driving you around is a nice touch as opposed always driving myself, and it creates new story opportunities, but it would be nicer if I had something like a zoom camera to look around at the city with or something like V checking their neural implants and customizing themselves in the car, like having your inventory accessible while the car is still running and moving around.

[h2] closing notes: [/h2]
I hate how this game folds under any pressure you apply to it. The open world is barely immersive at all. The updates definitely improve the game by a lot, but some more immersion features would be nicer.

I'm placing this positive review because they finally added transmog (the best update feature by far), and V no longer looks like a walking freak show. Also, download mods. I recommend "annoy me no more" (with reasonable police disabled), "enhanced police," "Shadow Hair" (which makes V's shadow not be bald) and "immersive first person." Redscript and Cyber Engine Tweaks are both required for script extensions.

Update:
After messing with the games graphical settings I'm able to consistently play the game without many issues. It still crashes occasionally, and there are a still a few minor bugs here and there, but it's actually pretty rare at this point. CDPR did release some recommendations as far as PC specs and graphical settings go, and following that guide really helped. This game is super heavy on both GPU and CPU, so if you're having issues and aren't running literally top of the line specs I'd recommend dropping your settings.

yeah so a lot of people say that the game is not replayable as their are only 3 endings? i think they might be new gen gamers who arent used to deep indepth games which require you to 'live' in the game as opposed to just casually play it if that makes sense. what ive learned about this game is the details in almost every aspect of the characters and writing as well as various options are easily missed and very rewarding once found, im talking about new dialogue options based on specific dialogue from a side quest that impacts a main quest for example. 

600 hours in and there are still little things im noticing for the first time its truly remarkable. now granted, a lot of these are 'in the moment' rewards so they wont change the ending of the game unless you get the 'secret' ending but thats not the point, i cant think of any RPGs which have more than 3 endings and ive played skyrim, mass effect and many others.

the point is that night city is somewhere i really feel immersed in, i choose my character and become that role, its a feeling i havent had in an rpg in the longest time honestly and its masterfully done in this game. the immersion is just S tier.

now the game has some flaws, the ai drivers and peds are NOT gta v level which is a shame and its something i hope is enhanced as time goes on however they have full mod support now and a community of very motivated, selfless and talented modders. not all of them are even found on nexus too. but either way, vanilla or heavily modded this game is a masterpiece even with its rugged edges around certain ai characteristics.

[h1] When you look at Night City... Night City also look into you [/h1]

Well... A lot as been said about this game.
According to my experience, I have to say that:
- In my first run I think I got 1% of the reported bugs (Was I lucky?)
- Sometimes I had that "feeling of unfinished business"  too

[b] But everything is nothing compared to the experience that this amazing game gave me. [/b]
There is something in the streets of Night City. Something that if it ever reaches you it never go out. And that feeling is worth every minute spent in-game.

I have explored a lot. Maxed out what I could and there is a point when you are almost invincible (this might have been fixed or leveled in the latest patches). 

In conclusion, if you love exploring every nook and cranny, if you like simple gameplay and rich storytelling, you have to play it. 

I think anyone should take a walk in Night City at least once in their life!

I’ve been holding off on this review because I’ve been waiting to see how the devs would fix this game.
It’s been… let’s see… a long time now and I’m still waiting.

Would I recommend this game? Hell no. Not anymore, not after patch 1.6

Since the last update, I’ve had suicidal cops jumping in front of my car. So my drive to the mission is interrupted by dodging the police. Cars randomly fall on my head in middle of a fire fight. Textures go from terrible, to crap, to terrible depending on where I view them from; was not like that before the patch. Certain enemies have become immortal, so I might have to decapitate them and await the quickening I think. To top it all off, I’ve watched random accidents occur in slow motion or had pedestrians run away in fear simply because I walked out of a building. I've also come across plenty of people who just spawn in the middle of the road, waiting for me to Carmegeddon them for laughs.

1.6 is like putting a plaster on a stab wound and calling it a day. Yes yes yes, I know, Witcher 4 is taking up most of the staff at CDPR, but the modding community had done a lot already to sort this mess out. Just chuck some credits their way and work with what they had created. I mean, they’ve even reinstated the mass transit system and it looks amazing, from what I’ve seen.
In essence the game has already been fixed, but those fixes are only available to the few who know how to implement them.
If you have not bought this game yet, then save your money. Spend it on Witcher 3 instead, that game is absolutely amazing. Ignore Cyberpunk.

Edit:
Once the game ends one gets a chance to continue from the last save, prior to the final mission. My last save was just before I took on the final main mission, the point of no return. So now I can play it again choosing the different approaches offered... Wonderful, more endings to explore. Nice

I bought this just after the 1.5 patch was released. I've played through both male and female V, and I gotta say, this is a great game. With the 1.6 patch being released it's even better! Nice to see a studio continue supporting their product instead of abandoning it.

As much as I like the Cyberpunk Aesthetic and running around as a G-58 Dian wielding Chinese Mercenary death-squading all the various gangs and rival corporations, the game inherently is lacking in role playing elements considering it claims to be an RPG. I think the lack of faction storylines really hurt the game considering you hardly actually interact with any group in Night City outside of shooting up their hideouts and offices (With the only exceptions being the Arasaka and Aldecados endings). The character backgrounds were also something that could have been greatly expanded on considering they usually just result in occasional bartering options for extra money. The game has come a long way from launch in terms of performance but remains quite buggy especially concerning audio triggers. I still enjoy Cyberpunk despite these flaws but the only time you should ever consider getting the game at this point if you are interested would be if its on sale at half off or more.

In summary 10/10

The game was in an awful state on release but i bought and finished it because of hype and here i am reinstalling it to see how much improvement they have done and the first cut-scene is full of t-posing headless NPC's and the first gun i was given had no textures and was fully see through, seemingly no improvement 0/10 i feel ripped off.

A lot of the gameplay/technical  issues seemed to be fixed. When the game first came out it provided a great linear story - but ugh, don't look over here or go over there. But right now it's very enjoyable to play in the open-world doing side missions and gigs; it feels like it's all starting to come together. One of the first things that I did on this playthrough was I stole a Quadra and right away I zoned into it because it felt really good to drive - collisions, acceleration, braking/skidding - it's just pretty awesome to drive around this game in first person now. Some of the police AI working to some extent, very smooth frame rates and even some emergent dynamic stuff going on - while I was on a gig, I was shooting at some punks and the cops joined in, as one of the cops was running across the street a frightened driver floored his van and ran him over at a pretty high speed - it looked brutal. 

Rockstar has been working on their RAGE engine for 20 years, so I can only see great things coming from CPR pulling themselves up by their bootstraps (up past their eyeballs) creating this engine and game. No other developer has tried something this ballsy and although CP2077 might not be the dark cyberpunk RPG I thought it was going to be, it is finally turning out to be a pretty good open world looter shooter romp with tons of high quality atmosphere and I hope we get to the point where they can drop meaningful expansions.

This game is hard call to make a choise do i like it or not. It is very good game but at the same time it is most irritating and frustrating game i've ever played. Let me try to explain. Game is made very well: story i good, graphics are very good and game is build very well meaning you really feel like you are in some sort of cyberpunk type world. Atmosphere is so good that i can allmost touch it: busy street's with all kinds of people from normal to freaks with cyber implants; echoing halls with lots of shadows and places to hide while you enemies voice is echoing in emptyness. Big open world with lots of things to do and places to explore.
But then the other side. First of all, this game needs some serious horsepower under the hood to run well. Update 1.6 made it run a bit worse which is a shame since game is allready very demanding. Hopefully this will be fixed soon. Second thing that makes me allmost break my keyboard is that when ever there is a story line mission for you to do, you can be sure that there is a _long_ cutscenes whic you are not able to skip. You can skip dialogues but not the videos. Yes cutscenes are made very well like everything else in this game but they are so long and detailed that it makes me seriously wounder were developers planning to make a movie or a game. And to make things worse,  you have to sit there and watch all cutscenes because time to time developers decided to drop a one single line of dialogue which you have to choose and in the end these choises dont make videos or end any different. So you cant leave game running and go watch tv. This is so super irritating that i have to fight hard not to give this a negative. Second thing is that these videos are very violent and you have no choise to skip any of them, like in one video you have to watch yourself been shot in the head twice. Third thing to complain is music: thru the whole game music is playing everywhere you go. Yes you can turn off music playing inside car and turn off copyrighted music but still there is all sorts of music playing in streets, music in alley, music in market places, everywhere. I love music but too much is too much and most of the time its just ruining the atmosphere.

I'm giving it a recommendation because of the hard work making this game but with a notice about cutscenes and some serious violence, which you have no option to skip. Very well made game with some bugs still remaining.

One of the best games I've ever played.  It had a rocky start, but even then it was a master class game.  Highly recommend, worth a few playthrus.  The various endings are all pretty decent.

Honestly if you just manage your expectations and don't read any of the hype, this game is an awesome fun time that I can't step away from. Yes, it's a bit empty. Yes, it's not the OPENWORLDNEXTGENEXPERIENCEOMG that was promised. But it is a REALLY fun RPG shooter looter slasher hackathon, like Deus Ex and Borderlands had a kid and just let them do what they wanted without hot housing them. 

Hacking people in slow motion, blinding them, setting them on fire and then slicing them to pieces with a monofilament electrified arm whip and then gunning down the rest of them with flaming bullets never gets old. The driving is pleasantly suprisingly satisfying. Really recommend this if you're into the mood, they got the vibe down pat.
